{{short description|British writer and scholar}} {{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox writer | name = Frank Laurence Lucas | image = F-L-Lucas.jpg | image_size = | alt = elderly man, profile, smoking cigarette | caption = Lucas in 1957 | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1894|12|28}} | birth_place = [[Hipperholme]], Yorkshire | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1967|6|1|1894|12|28}} | death_place = [[Cambridge]] | resting_place = | occupation = Academic, writer, critic | education = | alma_mater = [[Trinity College, Cambridge]] | period = | genre = Essay, literary criticism, fiction, poetry, drama, [[polemic]], travel writing | subject = | movement = | notableworks = [[Style (book)|''Style'']] (1955), ''The Complete Works of John Webster'' (1927) | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = | influences = | influenced = | awards = [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] (1946); [[Benson Medal]] (1939) | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | portaldisp = }} '''Frank Laurence Lucas''' (28 December 1894 – 1 June 1967) was an English [[Classics|classical]] scholar, literary critic, poet, novelist, playwright, political polemicist, Fellow of [[King's College, Cambridge]], and intelligence officer at [[Bletchley Park]] during [[World War II]].
He is now best remembered for his scathing 1923 review of [[T. S. Eliot]]'s ''[[The Waste Land]]'',<ref>Lucas, F. L., 'The Waste Land': ''New Statesman'' review, 3 November 1923. Scan of full review, British Library: [https://www.bl.uk/collection-items/review-of-the-waste-land-by-f-l-lucas-from-the-new-statesman]. Extracts: shubow.com [http://shubow.com/blog/herr-doktor-t-s-eliot.html]</ref> and for his book [[Style (book)|''Style'']] (1955; revised 1962), an acclaimed guide to recognising and writing good prose.<ref>Epstein, Joseph, 'Heavy Sentences', ''[[The New Criterion]]'' [https://www.newcriterion.com/articles.cfm/Heavy-sentences-7053]; Walther, Matthew, 'The Art of Writing Well', ''New English Review'' [https://www.newenglishreview.org/print.cfm?pg=custpage&frm=110481&sec_id=117345]</ref> His ''Tragedy in Relation to Aristotle's [[Poetics (Aristotle)|'Poetics']]'' (1927, substantially revised in 1957) was for over fifty years a standard introduction.<ref>[http://www.lib.udel.edu/ud/spec/exhibits/hogarth/series.htm 'Hogarth Press', University of Delaware Library Special Collections]</ref> His most important contribution to scholarship was his four-volume old-spelling ''Complete Works of [[John Webster]]'' (1927), the first collected edition of the Jacobean dramatist since that of [[William Hazlitt (registrar)|Hazlitt]] the Younger (1857), itself an inferior copy of [[Alexander Dyce|Dyce]] (1830).<ref>Lucas, F. L., ed., ''The Complete Works of John Webster'', London, 1927; vol.1, p.1</ref> Eliot called Lucas "the perfect annotator",<ref>Eliot, T. S., 'John Marston' in ''Elizabethan Essays'', London, 1934</ref> and subsequent Webster scholars have been indebted to him, notably the editors of the new [[Cambridge University Press|Cambridge]] Webster (1995–2007).<ref>Gunby, David; Carnegie, David; Hammond, Antony; DelVecchio, Doreen; Jackson, MacDonald P.: editors of ''The Works of John Webster'' (3 vols, Cambridge, 1995–2007)</ref>
Lucas is also remembered for his [[Anti-fascism|anti-fascist]] campaign in the 1930s,<ref>'F. L. Lucas: Writer with Love of Liberty', ''The Times'' (London, 2 June 1967)</ref><ref>Annan, Noel, ''Our Age: Portrait of a Generation'' (London, 1990)</ref> and for his wartime work at [[Bletchley Park]], for which he received the OBE.<ref>[https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/37412/supplement/281/data.pdf ''The London Gazette'', 9. Jan. 1946: thegazette.co.uk]</ref>
==Biographical==
===Early life and the War=== [[File:The German Withdrawal To the Hindenburg Line, March-april 1917 Q4938.jpg|thumb|left|200px|[[Miraumont]]-sur-Ancre (March 1917), taken in the British advance of 25 Feb. 1917. The Official History mentions "a daring and resourceful reconnaissance on the crest south of Miraumont by Lt. F. L. Lucas, 7/Royal West Kent, on the afternoon of Feb. 22, conducted whilst British shrapnel was bursting behind him", which brought the first indication of the German retreat to the [[Hindenburg Line]].<ref>Falls, Cyril, ''Military Operations, France and Belgium, 1917,'' (''History of the Great War Based on Official Ducuments'') (London, 1940), p.95</ref>]] [[File:Frank Laurence Lucas, 2 Lt Royal West Kent Regt., 1914.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Lucas in 1914]] F. L. ("Peter") Lucas grew up in [[Blackheath, London|Blackheath]] and was educated at [[Colfe's Grammar School|Colfe's]], where his father F. W. Lucas (1860–1931)<ref>Frank William Lucas, blackmanfamily.org [https://www.blackmanfamily.org/p12528.htm], lewishamheritage [https://www.picasaweb.google.com/lewishamheritage/FacesOfLewisham#5324897559954593442]</ref><ref>Duncan, Leland L., ''A History of Colfe's Grammar School, Lewisham, with a Life of Its Founder'' (London, 1910); Duncan, Leland L., ''The History of Colfe's Grammar School, 1652–1952'', ed. H. Beardwood (London, 1952)</ref> was headmaster, and from 1910 at [[Rugby School|Rugby]], where he was tutored by the [[Sophocles]] scholar Robert Whitelaw (1843–1917) in his last year before retirement.<ref>[https://www.archiveshub.ac.uk/data/gb12-ms.add.8480 Robert Whitelaw, Rugby School: archiveshub.ac.uk]</ref> He won a scholarship to [[Trinity College, Cambridge]], in 1913 to read for the [[Classical Tripos]], adding the [[Pitt Scholarship]]<ref>''The Cambridge Review'', 11 February 1914, p.283</ref> and the [[Porson Prize]]<ref>''The Cambridge Review'', 11 March 1914, p.372</ref> in 1914. In January 1914 he was elected [[Cambridge Apostles|Apostle]] – the last Apostle elected before the War<ref name="Skidelsky vol.1">Skidelsky, Robert, ''John Maynard Keynes: The Economist as Saviour, 1920–1937'' (London 1992), p.6</ref> – coming under the influence of [[G. E. Moore]].<ref name="Paul Levy Apostles">Levy, Paul, ''G. E. Moore and the Cambridge Apostles'' (London and New York, 1979)</ref> Believing Cambridge threatened with the fate of [[The Rape of Belgium|Louvain]],<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''The River Flows'' (London, 1926), p.170, 173</ref> he volunteered, aged 19, in October 1914<ref name="Paul Levy Apostles"/> and was commissioned in November,<ref>4 November 1914,[https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/28965/page/9022/data.pdf ''The London Gazette'', 6 Nov. 1914: thegazette.co.uk]</ref> serving from 1915 as second lieutenant in the 7th Battalion The [[Royal West Kent Regiment]] in France. From August 1915 he was in the Somme trenches opposite [[Fricourt]] and [[Mametz, Somme|Mametz]]; he was wounded by shrapnel in May 1916. He returned to the front as lieutenant<ref>Lieutenant, 17 July 1916: ''Army List, November 1917'', p.1356a [https://www.digital.nls.uk/british-military-lists/pageturner.cfm?id=104133584] [https://www.digital.nls.uk/british-military-lists/pageturner.cfm?id=104133584]</ref> in January 1917, went into battle near [[Grandcourt, Somme|Grandcourt]] on 17 February in the [[Operations on the Ancre, January–March 1917|Ancre Offensive]], was mentioned in despatches on 22 February, and was gassed on 4 March. In all he spent seventeen months in war-hospitals. By September 1917 he felt that the cause of honour and justice had been lost in the lust of Victory<ref>Lucas, F. L., 'September 1917' in ''Poems, 1935'' (Cambridge, 1935)</ref> ("We were too ready to go on fighting without offering terms" <ref>Lucas, F. L., ''Journal Under the Terror, 1938'' (London 1939), p.257</ref>). Passed fit for garrison duty at [[Chatham Dockyard|Chatham]], he sought the help of fellow-Apostle [[John Maynard Keynes]] to return to France,<ref name="Skidelsky vol.1"/> and from August 1918 to the Armistice he was Staff lieutenant in the [[Intelligence Corps (United Kingdom)|Intelligence Corps]] ([[Third Army (United Kingdom)|Third Army]] HQ), examining German prisoners near [[Bapaume]] and [[Le Quesnoy]]. His life hung in the balance in November 1918 shortly after the Armistice, when his lung wounds reopened in the [[1918 flu pandemic|influenza pandemic]].<ref group=note>Lucas's war memoirs are contained in his ''Journal Under the Terror, 1938'' (1939) [pp.12-19, 38-39, 95-96, 235-236, 257-259], in ''The Greatest Problem'' (1960) [pp.26–27, 143-151], and in the final chapters of ''The River Flows'' (1926).</ref> He returned to Cambridge in January 1919. Fell-walking in the Lake District "on Easter morning [1919] on [[Kidsty Pike]], between Hawes Water and Hayes Water, a blinding spring sun on snowy ridge beyond ridge, from Fairfield to Blucathra, brought a moment of such ecstatic intoxication that, were I a mystic, I should have called it a mystical experience."<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''The Greatest Problem, and Other Essays'' (London, 1960), p.257</ref>
===Career=== Resuming his undergraduate studies, Lucas won a Chancellor's Medal for Classics and the [[Browne medal|Browne Medal]] (1920), and revived meetings of the Apostles, suspended since 1914, becoming Society Secretary and contributing nineteen papers.<ref>Deacon, Richard, ''The Cambridge Apostles'' (London, 1985)</ref> He was elected to a Fellowship at King's College in 1920 before he had completed his degree,<ref name="Tillyard"/> [[John Maynard Keynes|Keynes]] paying for him to holiday in Greece with [[W. J. H. Sprott|Sebastian Sprott]] on the eve of his [[Tripos]].<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''The Greatest Problem'' (London, 1960), p.271</ref> He took a starred [[British undergraduate degree classification|first]] <ref group=note>At that time a pass in the fifteen papers of Part I of the Classical Tripos was equivalent to a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] degree. Lucas proceeded to his [[Master of Arts|M.A.]] in 1923.</ref> and began his career as a Classics lecturer in October 1920. In the spring of 1921 he spent three months in Greece as a student of the [[British School at Athens]], researching the site of the [[Battle of Pharsalus]] in [[Thessaly]] (see '''Pharsalus''' below). Back in Cambridge he switched that year<ref name="Wakeman J 1975">Lucas, F. L., autobiographical essay in ''World Authors, 1950–1970: A Companion Volume to Twentieth-Century Authors'', ed. John Wakeman (New York, 1975), pp.882–884</ref> to teaching for the English Tripos (instituted in 1919).<ref name="Wilkinson, L. P. 1980 p.102">Wilkinson, L. P., ''Kingsmen of a Century, 1873–1972'' (Cambridge 1980), p.102</ref> He was a member of the Cambridge University English Faculty from 1921–1939 and from 1945–1962, and a University [[Reader (academic rank)|Reader]] in English from 1947–1962. At the invitation of [[Desmond MacCarthy]], literary editor of the ''[[New Statesman]]'', Lucas reviewed poetry and criticism for that journal from 1922 to 1926, having begun his career as reviewer with the [[Athenaeum (British magazine)|''Athenaeum'']] in 1920–21, its last year. Early reviews and essays were collected in his ''Authors Dead and Living'' (1926). Among them was a review of Housman's ''[[Last Poems]]'' (1922)<ref>Lucas, F. L., 'Few, but Roses', ''New Statesman'', 20 October 1923, p.45–47; reprinted in ''[[The Dial]]'', September 1924, Vol. LXXVII, No 3; in ''The Living Age'', 319:419; and in ''A. E. Housman: The Critical Heritage'', ed. Philip Gardner (London, 1992)</ref> that, unusually, met with the approval of the poet himself.<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''The Greatest Problem, and other essays'' (London, 1960), p.191</ref> His move from Classics to English and his edition of Webster (1927) were inspired in large part by [[John Tresidder Sheppard|J. T. Sheppard]]'s March 1920 [[Marlowe Society]] production of ''[[The White Devil]]'', which made a powerful impression on him: "What could make the Cambridge production of ''The White Devil'' in 1920 seem, to at least two who saw it then without preconceptions, the most staggering performance they had ever known?" he asked in the ''[[New Statesman]]''.<ref>''New Statesman'', 1 March 1924</ref> "[Lucas] has been lucky in finding a writer [Webster] who takes his standpoint," T. E. Lawrence remarked, "and sums up life rather in his fashion."<ref>Lawrence, T. E., 1928 letter to E. M. Forster, in Wilson, Jeremy, & Wilson, Nicole, eds., ''T. E. Lawrence, Correspondence with E. M. Forster and F. L. Lucas'' (2010), p.133</ref> Lucas' preference, however, lay with [[Comparative Literature]], and after Webster he turned to his ''Studies French and English'' (1934; revised 1950) (he was ''Membre Correspondant Honoraire de L'Institut Littéraire et Artistique de France'' <ref>Biographical Notes, ''The English Association, Poems of To-day: Third Series'' (London 1938), p.xxvii.</ref>), and later to studies of Scandinavian literature.<ref>Lucas, F. L., 'Iceland' (essay on the Icelandic Sagas), ''Cornhill'' magazine, July 1935; reprinted as Chapter VI in the 1936 and 1937 editions of ''The Decline and Fall of the Romantic Ideal''</ref><ref>Lucas, F. L., ''The Drama of Ibsen and Strindberg'' (London, 1962)</ref><ref>''August Strindberg: Inferno''; translation by Mary Sandbach, introduction by F. L. Lucas (London, 1962)</ref> He served as committee member for the [[Cambridge Greek Play]] (1921–33)<ref>Cambridge Greek Play: ''Oresteia'' [https://www.cambridgegreekplay.com/plays/1921/Oresteia]; ''Bacchae'' [https://www.cambridgegreekplay.com/plays/1930/bacchae]; ''Oresteia'' [https://www.cambridgegreekplay.com/plays/1933/oresteia]</ref> and continued to write on Greek and Latin literature. As part-time Librarian at King's (1922–36) he accessioned the donated papers of [[Rupert Brooke]]. His students at King's included [[George Rylands]], [[John Davy Hayward|John Hayward]], [[F. E. Halliday]], [[List of teachers of Malvern College|H. C. A. "Tom" Gaunt]], [[Alan Clutton-Brock]], [[Julian Bell]], [[Winton Dean]] and [[Newman Flower|Desmond Flower]]. By Cambridge English students in general he was known as "F. L.".<ref>[[E. M. W. Tillyard|''The Granta'', 25 January 1939, p.195]]</ref> [[File:King's College - Gibbs' Building.jpg|thumb|left|150px|The Fellows' Building, King's. Of King's Lucas wrote: "Never in my experience of half a lifetime has it declined for one moment from that tradition of humanism, tolerance, and freedom in which I believe it unsurpassed throughout the Universities of the world."<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''The Search for Good Sense'' (London, 1958), p.15</ref>]]
Following the publication of his Webster, scholars turned to him for editorial advice: he helped in the preparation of Hayward's [[Nonesuch Press|Nonesuch]] ''Donne'' (1929), Housman's ''[[More Poems]]'' (1936), [[Theodore Redpath]]'s ''Songs and Sonets of John Donne'' (1956), and Ingram and Redpath's ''Shakespeare's Sonnets'' (1964).<ref group=note>"F. L. Lucas ... who scrutinised almost all our edition with keen eye, saved us from some definite mistakes, and made a great number of perceptive suggestions which have vastly benefited the edition." W. G. Ingram & Theodore Redpath, ''Shakespeare's Sonnets'' (London, 1964), p.xv</ref> He also performed an editorial and advisory role for [[Christopher Sandford]] at the [[Golden Cockerel Press]], where he introduced [[Porson (typeface)|Victor Scholderer's New Hellenic typeface]] (1937).<ref>Cave, Roderick, & Manson, Sarah, ''A History of the Golden Cockerel Press, 1920–1960'' (London, 2002) p.232</ref> A number of his verse translations from Greek and Latin, with engravings by [[John Buckland Wright]], were published in collectors' editions by the Golden Cockerel Press and [[Folio Society]].<ref>Reid, Anthony, ''Checklist of the Book Illustrations of John Buckland Wright'' (London, 1968)</ref> In the middle years of his career he was in demand as an invitation lecturer, giving seven BBC wireless talks in 1930, on [[Dorothy Osborne]] and on the Victorian Poets, delivering the 1933 Warton Lecture on English Poetry to the [[British Academy]], lecturing at the [[Royal Institution]] on Classicism and Romanticism (1935) and at the [[Royal Society of Literature]] on travel writing (1937), and, as part of a [[British Council]] drive to counter Soviet propaganda, lecturing in German on European literature to packed halls at the British Information Centre in West Berlin in October 1948 during the [[Berlin Blockade]].<ref>Lucas, F. L., 'A Week of Berlin', ''Manchester Guardian'', 19 October 1948 and 20 October 1948; enlarged and reprinted in ''The Greatest Problem, and Other Essays'' (London 1960)</ref>
In later years Lucas won acclaim for his translations from the classics (see '''Verse translation''' below) and for his book ''Style'' (1955). He also turned encyclopedist, contributing articles on 'Poetry', 'Epic', 'Lyric', 'Ode', 'Elegy' and 'Pastoral' to the 15-volume 1950 [[Chambers's Encyclopaedia]], among others, and serving on the editorial board of the Encyclopædia Britannica's ''[[Great Books of the Western World]]'' series (1952). As he told [[Nikos Kazantzakis]], who visited him in Cambridge after the War, ''Je ne lis plus; je relis'' [:I no longer read; I reread].<ref>Kazantzakis, Helen, ''Nikos Kazantzakis: A Biography based on his Letters'' (Oxford, 1968), p.447</ref>
For Lucas's anti-fascist campaign in the Thirties and his wartime service in Intelligence, see '''Appeasement''' and '''Bletchley Park''' below.
===Personal life=== From February 1921 to 1929 Lucas was married to the novelist [[E. B. C. Jones]] (1893–1966), known as "Topsy" to her friends. She was the sister-in-law of his former supervisor at Trinity, [[Donald Struan Robertson|Donald Robertson]]; he got to know her after reading and admiring her first novel, ''Quiet Interior'' (1920).<ref>Jones, E. B. C., ''Helen and Felicia'' (London, 1927), dedication</ref> Jones dedicated two novels to Lucas and based two characters on him – Hugh Sexton, gassed in the War, in ''The Singing Captives'' (1922), and Oliver in ''The Wedgwood Medallion'' (1923), a Cambridge classics graduate now studying the Elizabethan drama. Lucas based the character Margaret Osborne in [[The River Flows (novel)|''The River Flows'']] (1926) on her – a semi-autobiographical first novel that shifts some of his experiences of 1919–1920 to 1913–1915. The character Hugh Fawcett ("the best brain in the Foreign Office" but not much use as a matchmaker<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''The River Flows'' (London 1926), p.17</ref>) was based on [[John Maynard Keynes|Keynes]].<ref>Davenport-Hines, Richard, ''Universal Man: The Seven Lives of John Maynard Keynes'' (London 2015)</ref> Through the Apostles Lucas was associated with the [[Bloomsbury Group]],<ref name="Jones, Peter 2006, pp.301-327"/><ref group=note>"Then I went to [[Trinity College, Cambridge|Trinity]], and talked for some hours with Lucas, who appeared to me decidedly fascinating – though exactly why I'm blessed if I know." – [[Lytton Strachey]], May 1920, ''The Letters of Lytton Strachey'', ed. [[Paul Levy (journalist)|Paul Levy]] (London, 2005)</ref> Virginia Woolf describing him to Ottoline Morrell as "pure Cambridge: clean as a breadknife, and as sharp".<ref>Woolf, V., ''Letters'', 5.357</ref> To Lucas, interviewed in 1958, Bloomsbury had seemed "a jungle": {| class="wikitable" align=right style="margin:0 0 1em 1em" |+Book dedications |- | ''Euripides and his Influence'' || 1923 || [[E. B. C. Jones]] |- | [[The River Flows (novel)|''The River Flows'']] || 1926 || [[W. J. H. Sprott|Sebastian Sprott]] |- | ''Works of John Webster'' || 1927 || [[John Maynard Keynes]] |- | ''Tragedy in Relation to Aristotle's 'Poetics' '' || 1927 || [[Clive Bell]] |- | ''Time and Memory'' || 1929 || [[E. M. Forster]] |- | [[Cécile (novel)|''Cécile'']] || 1930 || [[T. E. Lawrence]] |- | ''Marionettes'' || 1930 || [[Desmond MacCarthy]] |- | ''Eight Victorian Poets'' || 1930 || [[John Davy Hayward|John Hayward]] |- | ''The Art of Dying'' || 1930 || [[Virginia Woolf]] |- | ''The Wild Tulip'' || 1932 || [[Julian Bell]] |- | ''Thomas Lovell Beddoes'' || 1932 || [[George Barnes (BBC controller)|George Barnes]] |- | ''George Crabbe'' || 1933 || [[Roger Fry]] |- | ''[[The Bear Dances]]'' || 1933 || [[Leon M. Lion]] |- | ''Studies French and English'' || 1934 || [[Charles Mauron|Marie Mauron]] |- | ''The Decline and Fall of the Romantic Ideal'' || 1936 || [[Gordon Bottomley]] |- | ''The Delights of Dictatorship'' || 1938 || [[Henry Nevinson]] |- | ''The Iliad. Verse translation in selection'' || 1950 || [[D. W. Lucas]] |- | ''Literature and Psychology'' || 1951 || [[Wilhelm Stekel|Hilda Stekel]] |- | ''Greek Poetry for Everyman'' || 1951 || [[George Boas]] |- | ''Greek Drama for Everyman'' || 1954 || [[Herbert John Clifford Grierson|Herbert Grierson]] |- | [[Style (book)|''Style'']] || 1955 || [[Charles Tennyson (civil servant)|Charles Tennyson]] |- | ''The Search for Good Sense'' || 1958 || [[Harry Hinsley]] |} :"The society of Virginia and Leonard Woolf, Duncan Grant, Clive and Vanessa Bell, and Lytton Strachey was far from being in the ordinary sense a happy family. They were intensely and rudely critical of each other. They were the sort of people who would read letters addressed to others. They tormented each other with endless love affairs. In real crises they could be generous, but in ordinary affairs of life they were anything but kind ... [[Goldsworthy Lowes Dickinson|Dickinson]] and Forster were not really Bloomsbury. They were soft-hearted and kind. Bloomsbury was certainly not that."<ref>Stone, Wilfred, 'Some Bloomsbury Interviews and Memories', ''Twentieth Century Literature'', Vol.43, No.2 (Summer, 1997), p.190; Lucas' words as reported in Wilfred Stone's notes</ref> Jones's admiration for [[George Rylands]] undermined the marriage by 1927.<ref>[[Noel Annan|Annan, Noel]], ''The Dons'' (London 1999), p.180</ref><ref name="Jones, Peter 2006, pp.301-327">Jones, Peter, '[[Dora Carrington|Carrington]] (and Woolf) in Cambridge, 1928', ''Transactions of the Cambridge Bibliographical Society'', Vol.XIII Pt.3, 2006, pp.301–327 [https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/41154955?uid=3738032&uid=2129&uid=2&uid=70&uid=4&sid=21102496134011]</ref> After affairs with [[Dora Carrington]] (d.1932)<ref name="Jones, Peter 2006, pp.301-327"/> and Shelagh Clutton-Brock (d.1936),<ref>''Selected Letters of Vanessa Bell'', ed. Regina Marler (London 1994)</ref> in December 1932 Lucas married the 21-year-old [[Girton College, Cambridge|Girton]] Classics graduate and sculptor Prudence Wilkinson (1911–1944). His travel writings, accounts of their long walks through landscapes with literary associations, date from the years of his second marriage (1932–1939): ''From Olympus to the Styx'' (1934), a book on their 1933 walking tour of Greece (one of five journeys he made to that country), 'Iceland', a travelogue on their 1934 journey to the [[Sagas of Icelanders|saga]] sites, included in the original edition of his ''The Decline and Fall of the Romantic Ideal'' (1936);<ref>'Iceland', ''Cornhill'' magazine, Aug. 1935, reprinted in the 1936 & 1937 eds. of ''The Decline and Fall of the Romantic Ideal''</ref> and journal-entries on their visits to Norway, Ireland, Scotland, and France.<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''Journal Under the Terror, 1938'' (London 1939)</ref> In these years they were frequent visitors to the home in [[Saint-Rémy-de-Provence]] of [[Charles Mauron|Marie Mauron]], whose Provençal stories Lucas translated. ''From Olympus to the Styx'' argues for the return of the [[Elgin Marbles]]: :"Considering what was to come, the much-abused 'theft' of the sculptures from the Acropolis by Lord Elgin was an undoubted blessing, though it was carelessly carried out, especially in removing the Caryatid from the Erechtheum; it would none the less be a graceful act for England to return them now to Athens."<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''From Olympus to the Styx'' (London, 1934), p.146</ref> Prudence Lucas, as well as sharing these interests, designed the costumes and sets for the first production (1938) of his Icelandic tragedy [[Laxdœla saga|''The Lovers of Gudrun'']]. Her nervous breakdown in 1938 is touched on in Lucas's ''Journal Under the Terror, 1938'' (1939); Lucas sought help from, among others, [[Wilhelm Stekel]], whom he met in London in 1939,<ref name="Lucas, F. L. 1951"/> but the rift proved irreparable. The emphasis on psychology in his post-war books – ''Literature and Psychology'' (1951), ''Style'' (1955), ''The Search for Good Sense'' (1958),<ref>[http://www.neglectedbooks.com/?p=1086 ''The Search for Good Sense'', by F. L. Lucas], [[The Neglected Books Page]]</ref> ''The Art of Living'' (1959), the essay on 'Happiness' in ''The Greatest Problem'' (1960), ''The Drama of Ibsen and Strindberg'' (1962) – reflects an interest shared with his third wife (1940–1967), the Swedish psychologist Elna Kallenberg (1906-2003),<ref>[https://www.runeberg.org/vemarvem/sthlm45/0411.html Elna Kallenberg, runeberg.org]</ref> whom he married in 1940 – "the stranger who came to me from beyond the sea when I most needed her"<ref>Lucas, F. L., dedication to ''Critical Thoughts in Critical Days'' (London 1942)</ref> (Elna Kallenberg had flown from Sweden, with special permission from the [[Home Office]], to join him in late 1939).<ref name="Wilkinson, L. P. 1967">Wilkinson, L. P., 'F. L. Lucas' in ''King's College Report'', November 1967</ref><ref name="Wilkinson, L. P. 1980"/><ref>Cohen, R. H. L., & Pottle, M., 'F. L. Lucas' in ''The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', 2004</ref> They had two children, Signe and Sigurd. [[File:D W Lucas and F L Lucas, c.1906.jpg|thumb|right|200px|D. W. Lucas and F. L. Lucas, c.1906]] Lucas returned time and again in his books to the theme of happiness, and in 1960 summed up his thoughts on happiness thus: :"Vitality of mind and body; the activity to employ and maintain them; the zest and curiosity that they can animate; freedom to travel widely in nature and art, in countries of the world and countries of the mind; human affections; and the gift of gaiety – these seem to me, then, the main causes of happiness. I am surprised to find how few and simple they are."<ref>Lucas, F. L., 'Happiness', in ''The Greatest Problem, and Other Essays'' (London 1960)</ref>
F. L. Lucas lived at 7 Camden Place, Cambridge, from 1921–25; at 20 West Road, Cambridge from 1925–39; at High Mead, [[Great Brickhill]] from 1939–45; and again at 20 West Road, Cambridge, from 1945 until his death in 1967. The dissident Czech academic [[:cs:Otakar Vočadlo|Otakar Vočadlo]] (1895–1974), Lucas's Prague correspondent in 1938-39 (see '''Appeasement''' below) and a [[Nazi concentration camps|concentration camp]] survivor,<ref name="Otakar Vočadlo King's">[https://www.kings.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/finance/support/international-studentships.html Otakar Vočadlo, kings.cam.ac.uk]</ref><ref name="vocadlo cz">[https://www.dva.cz/2015-02-01/vocadlo/ Otakar Vočadlo, dva.cz]</ref> celebrated his restoration, during the [[Prague Spring]] of 1968, to his Chair of English at Prague, by giving a course of lectures on Webster in memory of Lucas, whose support for the Czech cause in 1938–39 had not been forgotten.<ref name="Wilkinson, L. P. 1980 p.102"/>
[[D. W. Lucas]], the classical scholar (1905–85), Fellow of King's College, Cambridge, University Director of Studies in Classics, and Perceval Maitland Laurence Reader in Classics, was F. L. Lucas's brother.
==Literary criticism==
===Approach=== Except in reviews of work by contemporaries, early examples of which appear in ''Authors Dead and Living'' (1926), Lucas adopted the [[Historicism|historical and biographical approach]] to criticism and examined the views of earlier critics, whose dogmatism he was swift to rebut. He increasingly linked his studies to developments in Psychology, notably in ''Literature and Psychology'' (1951). "The real [[Lex non scripta|'unwritten laws']]," he observed, "seem to me those of human psychology."<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''The Art of Living'', p.165 (London, 1959)</ref> Centrally, he discussed the writer's psychology as revealed through style. "Even science has invented no pickle for embalming a man like ''style''," he noted.<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''Journal Under the Terror, 1938'' (London, 1939), p.36</ref>
The poets to whom he returned most often in publications were Tennyson (1930, 1932, 1947, 1957) and Housman (1926, 1933, 1936, 1960), but he ranged widely over Classical, European and English literature. Conscious that books can influence for good or ill, he admired authors he saw as defenders of sanity and good sense – men like Montaigne and Montesquieu – or as compassionate realists, like Homer in the ''Iliad'', Euripides, Hardy, Ibsen and Chekhov. "Life is 'indivisible'," he wrote. :"A public tends to get the literature it deserves: a literature, to get the public it deserves. The values men pursue in each, affect the other. They turn in a vicious, or a virtuous, circle. Only a fine society could have bred Homer: and he left it finer for hearing him."<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''Critical Thoughts in Critical Days'', London, 1942, p.50</ref> His criticism, while acknowledging that morality is historically relative, was thus values-based. "Writers can make men ''feel'', not merely see, the values that endure."<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''Literature and Psychology'' (London, 1951), p.333</ref> Believing that too many modern writers encouraged men and women to flee to unreason, decadence and barbarism, he condemned the ''[[Julien Benda|trahisons des clercs]]'' of the twentieth century,<ref name=autogenerated3>Lucas, F. L., ''Critical Thoughts in Critical Days'', London, 1942</ref> and used his lectures and writing to campaign for a responsible use of intellectual freedom. "One may question whether real civilisation is so safely afloat," he wrote in his last published letter (1966), "that we can afford to use our pens for boring holes in the bottom of it."<ref>Lucas, F. L., [[Revolt in the Vendée|'La Vendée']], ''Times Literary Supplement'', 12 May 1966</ref> The writer or artist serving up "slapdash nightmares out of his Unconscious",<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''Journal Under the Terror, 1938'' (London, 1939), p.44, p.74</ref> "in an age morbidly avid of uncivilised irreticence",<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''The Drama of Ibsen and Strindberg'' (London, 1962), p.314</ref> not only exhibited his own neuroses, but fed neurosis in others. Literary critics, too, had to take more responsibility. "Much cant gets talked," he noted of the [[Structuralism|Structuralists]], "by critics who care more for the form and organisation of a work than for its spirit, its content, its supreme moments."<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''Greek Poetry for Everyman'' (London, 1951), Preface p.xvi</ref> The serious note in his criticism was counterbalanced by wit and urbanity, by lively anecdote and quotation, and by a gift for startling imagery and epigram.
What Lucas wrote about Housman's ''Name and Nature of Poetry'' in 1933 (though he contested some of its ideas) sums up what he himself aspired to as a literary critic: "… the kind of critical writing that best justifies itself before the brevity of life; that itself adds new data to our experience as well as arguing about the old; that happily combines, in a word, philosophy with autobiography, psychology with a touch of poetry – of the ‘poetic’ imagination. It can make acceptable even common sense. There are sentences here which recall the clear-cut Doric strength of the ''[[Lives of the Most Eminent English Poets|Lives of the Poets]]'' ..."<ref>Lucas, F. L., 'Poetry Examined by Professor Housman', ''Cambridge Review'', 8 June 1933, p.469</ref>
His Cambridge colleague [[T. R. Henn]] noted that Lucas's approach and style were influenced by the [[Lytton Strachey|Strachey]] of ''Books and Characters'' (1922).<ref>Henn, T.R., review of ''Authors Dead and Living'', ''The Cambridge Review'', 21 May 1926</ref>
===Controversy=== Lucas's impatience with the "obscurantism" and coterie-appeal of much modern poetry made him in the interwar years one of the foremost opponents of the new schools. "As for 'profundity'," he wrote, "it is not uncommonly found also in dry wells; which may likewise contain little but obscurity and rubbish."<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''Cambridge Review'', 24 May 1958, p.576</ref> He opposed also what he saw as the narrow dogmatism of the [[New Criticism|New Critics]], those "tight-lipped Calvins of art",<ref name=autogenerated3 /> as he called them, of ''[[The Criterion (magazine)|Criterion]]'' and ''[[Scrutiny (journal)|Scrutiny]]''. Discussions of [[I. A. Richards]]'s criticism appear in his essay 'English Literature' in the volume ''University Studies: Cambridge 1933'' <ref>Wright, Harold, ed., ''University Studies: Cambridge 1933'' (London, 1933)</ref> and in Chapter 4 of his ''Decline and Fall of the Romantic Ideal'' (1936), and of Eliot's in the 1929 essay 'Modern Criticism',<ref>Lucas, F. L., 'Criticism', ''[[Life and Letters]]'' Nov. 1929</ref> reprinted in his ''Studies French and English'' (1934). An anonymous ''[[New Statesman]]'' review (29 December 1928) of Eliot's criticism, however, to which [[F. R. Leavis]] replied<ref>Leavis, F. R., 'T. S. Eliot: A Reply to the Condescending', ''Cambridge Review'', 8 February 1929</ref> apparently believing it was by Lucas, and which Leavis's biographer says "was certainly by Lucas",<ref>MacKillop, Ian, ''F. R. Leavis: A Life in Criticism'', p.103 (Harmondsworth, 1995)</ref> was in fact by Richard Ellis Roberts.<ref>''The Cambridge Mind: Ninety Years of The Cambridge Review'', eds. Eric Homberger, William Janeway and Simon Shama (London 1970), p.235</ref><ref>Harding, Jason, ''The Criterion: Cultural Politics and Periodical Networks in Inter-War Britain'' (Oxford, 2002), p.66: books.google.co.uk [https://books.google.com/books?id=iS4RAufyKBwC&pg=PA66&dq=F+L+Lucas+The+Cambridge+Review&hl=en&sa=X&ei=QpTyUeGIDsa90QWTrYDQDg&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=F%20L%20Lucas%20The%20Cambridge%20Review&f=false]</ref> Lucas had stopped reviewing for the ''New Statesman'' in 1926 and never reviewed anonymously.<ref group=note>''The New Statesman'' published 48 signed Lucas reviews from April 1922 to Jan. 1926. He returned, briefly, for two signed reviews of authors he found congenial, [[Robert Browning|Browning]] (22 Nov. 1928) and [[Thomas Lovell Beddoes|Beddoes]] (10 Dec. 1928).</ref> His critique of [[Q. D. Leavis]]'s ''Fiction and the Reading Public'' (1932) in ''University Studies: Cambridge 1933'' was described by F. R. Leavis's biographer as "improper": "senior academics do not use quasi-official publications to attack graduate students".<ref>MacKillop, Ian, ''F. R. Leavis: A Life in Criticism'', p.196 (Harmondsworth, 1995)</ref> (The volume, though printed by the [[Cambridge University Press|University Press]], was not published there; its editor stressed that the contributions were "unofficial" glimpses into the "intense mental activity" of each Cambridge department;<ref>Wright, Harold, ed., ''University Studies: Cambridge 1933'', Introduction p.ix (London, 1933)</ref> and published theses are not normally considered exempt from criticism.)
===Lucas and Eliot=== Lucas's 1923 review of ''The Waste Land'', much reprinted in the decades since his death,<ref>''T. S. Eliot: 'The Waste Land', A Casebook,'' ed. C. B. Cox and Arnold Hinchliffe (London, 1968, Nashville, 1970); ''T. S. Eliot: The Critical Heritage,'' ed. Michael Grant (London, 1982); ''T. S. Eliot: The Contemporary Reviews,'' ed. Jewel Spears Brooker (Cambridge, 2004)</ref> was omitted from his ''Authors Dead and Living'' (1926), a collection of ''New Statesman'' pieces, probably because he had ended by saying the poem should be left to sink. Remarks elsewhere confirm that he had not changed his opinion.<ref group=note>Sentences repeating opinions from the ''Waste Land'' review appear in 'The Progress of Poetry' (''Authors Dead and Living'', p.286) and ''Journal Under the Terror, 1938'', p.172</ref> Described by [[F. W. Bateson]] as "brilliantly wrong-headed",<ref>''[[Review of English Studies]]'', Vol.14, 1938 (no.54, April), p.233</ref> the review is better known today than it was during Lucas's lifetime. His only other comment on the poem occurs in his essay 'English Literature' in the volume ''University Studies: Cambridge 1933'',<ref>Wright, Harold, ed., ''University Studies: Cambridge 1933'' (London, 1933), p.272</ref> where he contested [[I. A. Richards]]' view of it in ''Science and Poetry'' (1926): "''The Waste Land'' is praised [by Richards] for its 'complete severence' from '''all'' beliefs', when it is really a yearning cry for them, and at its close some sort of faith is so clearly impending that it has been praised by others as a great religious poem (such are the triumphs of obscurity)." ''The Letters of T. S. Eliot'' <ref>Eliot, Valerie: Haughton, Hugh: Haffenden, John; eds., ''The Letters of T. S. Eliot'' (London 2012, 2013), vols. 3&4</ref> includes correspondence between Eliot and Lucas but no reference to the review. Historians of ''The New Statesman'' have regretted that [[Desmond MacCarthy]] invited Lucas to review modern poetry, one of them declaring Lucas "a disastrous choice" for a ''Waste Land'' review.<ref>Smith, Adrian, '' 'The New Statesman': Portrait of a Political Weekly, 1913-1931'' (London 1996), p.206</ref> (Disastrous, that is, for the journal's avant-garde image.) After 1923, though attacking obscurantism in general terms, Lucas largely ignored Eliot's poetry, aside from a retrospective dig in 1942 at 'The Hollow Men' ("hollow men whimpering under prickly pear trees, conceited still amid their grovellings because a prickly pear remains an exotic and highly intellectual plant" <ref name="Lucas, F. L. 1942 p.45">Lucas, F. L., ''Critical Thoughts in Critical Days'' (London, 1942), p.45</ref>) and at 'Sweeney among the Nightingales' ("the nightingales of Aeschylus now exhibit to a ravished public their 'droppings'; for to the sewer all things are sewer" <ref name="Lucas, F. L. 1942 p.45"/>). On the later Eliot he was silent. He had no time for mystical poetry, regarding religion as an aberration of the human mind.<ref name="Wilkinson, L. P. 1967"/>
In 1928 Lucas had been stung by Eliot's review in the [[The Times Literary Supplement|''Times Literary Supplement'']] criticising aspects of the Introduction to his ''Webster''.<ref>'John Webster', ''Times Literary Supplement'', 26 Jan. 1928, p.59</ref> He replied vigorously in the same journal,<ref>'John Webster', ''Times Literary Supplement'', 2 Feb. 1928</ref> only to find Eliot extending his criticisms in another review in [[The Criterion (magazine)|''The Criterion'']].<ref>Eliot, T. S., 'Mr Lucas's ''Webster'' ', ''The Criterion'', June 1928, pp.155-158</ref> Lucas counter-attacked in his 1929 essay 'Modern Criticism',<ref>Lucas, F. L., 'Criticism', ''[[Life and Letters]]'' Nov. 1929, reprinted in his ''Studies French and English'' (1934)</ref> ridiculing Eliot's literary-critical [[Obiter dictum|''obiter dicta'']] and hieratic tone. In later impressions of his essays, Eliot made minor changes or added clarifications to sentences Lucas had ridiculed, and praised the textual and historical scholarship of the 1927 ''Webster''. Lucas left the Introduction out of his 1958 revised editions of the two major plays, but demand for the unabridged 1927 ''Webster'' continued, and it was reprinted on both sides of the Atlantic in 1966.
===Reputation=== Lucas's standing as a literary critic was probably at its highest in the 1930s. "In three respects," wrote the ''[[Times Literary Supplement]]'' in 1934, "Lucas rises pre-eminent from the crowd of contemporary critics: in his care for style, for dignity and grace in his method of presentment: in his learning in the literature of several languages: and in the balance, the sanity of his judgment."<ref>''Times Literary Supplement'', review of ''Studies French and English'', 22 February 1934, p.123</ref> Post-war, reviewers were often more hostile.<ref name="Wilkinson, L. P. 1967"/><ref name="Wilkinson, L. P. 1980">Wilkinson, L. P., ''Kingsmen of a Century, 1873–1972'' (Cambridge 1980)</ref><ref>e.g. [[Anthony Thwaite]] (1958), G. D. Klingopulos (10 April 1959), and [[Bernard Bergonzi]] (24 June 1960) in ''[[The Spectator]]'' ; John Raymond (1 March 1958), [[Walter Allen]] (16 July 1960), and [[M. C. Bradbrook]] (8 June 1962) in the ''[[New Statesman]]''.</ref> Many post-war reviews amounted to reprisals by the Leavisite camp: "There is an air of breezy Bloomsbury superficiality and cultural omniscience about this book that is distressing," wrote one. "His is the type of over-cultivated fuddy-duddy mind that has done – and is doing – great damage to our whole culture in general and to literary appreciation in particular."<ref>John Raymond, ''[[New Statesman]]'', 1 March 1958</ref> Probably because, [[psychoanalytic literary criticism]] aside, Lucas scorned most new trends – he described the critical theory of the 1950s as "largely pseudo-scientific bubble-blowing"<ref>Lucas, F. L., 'The Menace of Science to the Humanities' in ''The Greatest Problem, and Other Essays'' (London, 1960)</ref> – his criticism has long been out of fashion and is mostly out of print. {| class="toccolours" style="float: right; margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 2em; font-size: 85%; background:#FDD9B5; color:black; width:30em; max-width: 40%;" cellspacing="5" | style="text-align: left;" | "His criticism is the table-talk of a man of the world of fine taste and faultless memory. And he has to an exceptional degree the gift of creating and communicating an enjoyment of literature. It is impossible to put his books down without a grateful determination to reread those masterpieces of literature he describes and illustrates so engagingly."<br> |- | ― [[F. W. Bateson]], ''[[Review of English Studies]]'', 1938<ref>From a review by F. W. Bateson of ''The Decline and Fall of the Romantic Ideal'', ''[[Review of English Studies]]'', Vol.14, 1938 (no.54, April), p.235</ref> |- | style="text-align: left;" | |} "The literary world has passed on," wrote L. P. Wilkinson, "but that does not mean that what supervened was better; and just because of his uncompromising brilliance the whirligig of time may bring in his criticism again. His [[Style (book)|''Style'']] (1955) has a permanent value in any case, unaffected by trends."<ref name="Wilkinson, L. P. 1980"/> ''Style'' is now back in print (2012).<ref>Henkel, Harold, [[Regent University]] Library: ''Style'', by F. L. Lucas, librarylink.regent.edu [http://librarylink.regent.edu/?tag=f-l-lucas]</ref> His two earliest books, ''Seneca and Elizabethan Tragedy'' (1922) (his Fellowship dissertation) and ''Euripides and His Influence'' (1923), not yet superseded in similar concise form, continue to be reprinted. The editors of the new Cambridge Webster (1995–2007) praise "his customary accuracy and astuteness" in matters of dating, authorship, and textual scholarship.<ref>Gunby, David; Carnegie, David; Hammond, Antony; DelVecchio, Doreen; Jackson, MacDonald P.: editors of ''The Works of John Webster'' (3 vols, Cambridge, 1995–2007), Vol.2, p.500</ref> "With its voluminous and marvellously wide-ranging notes," writes D. C. Gunby, "Lucas's four-volume, old-spelling edition remains essential reading for those who love scholarship and, more, love the plays of John Webster".<ref>Gunby, David, ''John Webster: Three Plays'' (Harmondsworth, 1972), p.32</ref>
==Verse translation== {| class="toccolours" style="float: right; margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 2em; font-size: 85%; background:#f7e2c5; color:black; width:30em; max-width: 50%;" cellspacing="5" | style="text-align: left;" | :''' ''THE SPRING OF HERMES'' ''' : :Beside the grey sea-shingle, here at the cross-roads' ::meeting, :I, Hermes, stand and wait, where the windswept orchard ::grows. :I give, to wanderers weary, rest from the road and ::greeting: :Cool and unpolluted from my spring the water ::flows. |- | style="text-align: left;" | – '''[[Anyte of Tegea]]''', ''Anth. Pal.'', IX.314, trans. Lucas |} Lucas dedicated much of his time to making classical (mainly Greek) poetry accessible to modern readers through verse translations. His companion volumes ''Greek Poetry for Everyman'' (1951) and ''Greek Drama for Everyman'' (1954) contain some 20,000 lines. No single translator had attempted before to bring together in homogeneous volumes so much of the best of Greek poetry from Homer to the 6th century A.D., with the introductions and notes needed by the non-classicist. The translations were praised for their grace and fidelity – "the sense and the imagery are minutely reproduced" ([[Classical Association|''The Classical Review'']] )<ref>Kirk, G. S., ''The Classical Review'', Dec. 1952</ref> – and were hailed by the press as Cambridge's single-handed answer to the [collaborative] ''Oxford Book of Greek Verse in Translation''.<ref>Mortimer, Raymond, ''Sunday Times'', Jan.1951; Garrod, H. W., ''The Spectator'', 6 January 1951</ref> Lucas's versions, however, presuppose a taste for a poetic style closer to [[William Morris|Morris]] than to Pound. Reviewers generally preferred his translations of lyric, Alexandrian and later poetry to the 7,000 rhymed lines from Homer, which were omitted from the second edition ([[Everyman Library]], 1966). "Lucas makes the plays deceptively easy to read and appreciate," wrote a reviewer of the second volume,<ref>Shepherd, R. M. H., ''Phoenix'', Vol.12, No.4 (Winter 1958), pp.189–193</ref> "by smoothing away the austerities and complexities of the Greek – qualities which some modernists conscientiously preserve or even exaggerate." The translation of [[Hippolytus (play)|''Hippolytus'']] remains in print in the [[Penguin Books|Penguin]] selection, ''Eight Great Tragedies'', ed. [[Sylvan Barnet]].<ref>[http://www.penguin.ca/nf/Book/BookDisplay/0,,9780452011724,00.html?sym=TAB Barnet, Sylvan (ed.), ''Eight Great Tragedies'' (Toronto)]</ref>
==Original writing==
===Novels=== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:F L Lucas, River Flows - wrapper.jpg|thumb|right|200px|First edition wrapper of ''The River Flows'', 1926, listed as "unknown" in ''A Checklist of the Hogarth Press, 1917-38'' by J. Howard Woolmer and Mary E. Gaither (London 1976)]] --> Of Lucas's novels the best received was [[Cécile (novel)|''Cécile'']] (1930), a tale of love, society and politics in the France of 1775–1776. Lucas dedicated the book to [[T. E. Lawrence]], a friend and admirer.<ref>[http://www.castlehillpress.com/publications/2010_forster_prospectus.shtml ''T. E. Lawrence Studies'']</ref><ref>Lucas, F. L., ''Journal Under the Terror, 1938'' (London, 1939), p.356-7</ref> He wrote two further historical novels, ''[[Doctor Dido]]'' (1938), set in Cambridge in 1792–1812, and [[Battle of Bailén|''The English Agent: A Tale of the Peninsular War'']] (1969), set in Spain in 1808; and a novella, ''[[The Woman Clothed with the Sun]]'' (1937), on the [[Buchanites]] of the 1780s–90s. The three novels focus on a love-affair between an Englishman and a Frenchwoman (Lucas was a self-confessed ''gallomane''<ref>Lucas, ''Style'' (1955), Preface</ref>); the Scots novella takes the form of an account, written by a Scottish minister in middle age, of his youthful bewitchment by [[Elspeth Buchan]] and of his curious sojourn among the Buchanites. A theme common to all four is the tension between fragile [[Age of Enlightenment|18th-century rationalism]] and, in varying forms, [[Romanticism|Romantic]] "enthusiasm" and unreason. For his semi-autobiographical first novel, [[The River Flows (novel)|''The River Flows'']] (1926), see '''Personal Life''' above.
===Poems=== As a poet Lucas was a polished ironist. Early collections (''Time and Memory'', 1929, ''Marionettes'', 1930, ''Poems, 1935'') were mostly personal lyrics or satires, but he came to specialise in dramatic monologues and narrative poems based on historical episodes "that seem lastingly alive" (''From Many Times and Lands'', 1953).<ref>"I try to find episodes in history that seem lastingly alive: and try to make them live on paper" (Lucas, ''Journal'' [1939], p.229)</ref> His First World War poems, including [[Cheshire Regiment|'''Morituri'' – August 1915, on the road from Morlancourt']] (1935) and (below) ' "The Night is Chilly but not Dark" ' (1935), offer a retrospect of his experiences at the front.
:On nights when the moon creeps shrouded up the sky :And hedge and holt lie glimmering ghostly grey, :A voice still whispers in me, far away – :''A good night, this, for wiring'' – and suddenly :There rises from the dead that shadowy hell, :The barbed-wire rasps, uncoiling through my hand, :The flares dance flickering over no-man's-land, :A dull machine-gun raps from La Boisselle. :Then fades the phantom, and once more I know :Our spider-webs of wire are rust by now, :Our battlefields reconquered by the plough, :And hands that worked with mine, dust long ago.
The inclusion of 'Beleaguered Cities' (1929) in various mid-twentieth century anthologies of English verse made it probably Lucas's best-known poem.<ref>Lucas, F. L., 'Beleaguered Cities' in ''Time and Memory'' (London, 1929); reprinted in ''Poems of Our Time'', ed. Richard Church and Mildred Bozman (London, 1945, 1959 [Everyman Library]); poemspictures.blogspot.com [http://poemspictures.blogspot.com/2006/05/beleagured-cities-by-fl-lucas-1894.html]</ref> Others that have gained currency through anthologies include 'The Destined Hour' (1953), a re-telling in verse of the old [[Samarra|'appointment in Samarra']] fable,<ref>Lucas, F. L., 'The Destined Hour' in ''From Many Times and Lands'' (London, 1953); reprinted in ''Every Poem Tells a Story: A Collection of Stories in Verse'', ed. Raymond Wilson (London, 1988; {{ISBN|0-670-82086-5}} / 0-670-82086-5); www.funtrivia.com [http://www.funtrivia.com/bb.cfm?action=details&qnid=17406&boardid=19&start=20]</ref> and 'Spain 1809', the story of a village woman's courage during the French occupation in the [[Peninsular War]].<ref>Lucas, F. L., 'Spain 1809' in ''From Many Times and Lands'' (London, 1953); reprinted in ''The Harrap Book of Modern Verse'', ed. Maurice Wollman and Kathleen Parker (London, 1958), and in ''The Penguin Book of Narrative Verse'', ed. David Herbert (Harmondsworth, 1960)</ref> His most ambitious poem was [[Ariadne (poem)|''Ariadne'']] (1932), an epic re-working of the [[Labyrinth]] myth, extracts from which were read on the [[BBC Home Service]] in 1934.<ref>Passages from 'Ariadne' by F. L. Lucas, read by Nesta Sawyer, 6 Sept. 1934: [https://www.genome.ch.bbc.co.uk]</ref> Simon Tidworth in ''The Quest for Theseus'' summarises: "Lucas invents another sweetheart for [[Theseus]], Aegle, one of the sacrificial maidens who accompany him to Crete. The real stroke of originality is to make the Minotaur Minos himself in a bull-mask. On Naxos [[Ariadne]] learns of Theseus's earlier love for Aegle, and decides to leave him while the image of her own love is still fresh. An ordinary love-affair is not what she wants; she has to seek the Ideal [Dionysus]." <ref>Tidworth, Simon, ''The Quest for Theseus'', ed. Anne Ward (London, 1970)</ref>
===Plays=== Lucas's most successful play was the thriller [[Land's End (play)|''Land's End'']],<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''Four Plays'' (Cambridge, 1935)</ref> set in Cornwall in the mid-1930s ([[Westminster Theatre]], February–March 1938, 29 performances, with [[Cathleen Nesbitt]], [[Cecil Trouncer]] and [[Alan Napier]] among the cast) – "as full of drama as an egg is full of meat", noted ''[[The Stage]]''.<ref>''[[The Stage]]'', 3 March 1938; p.10</ref> One of [[Paul Scofield]]'s earliest roles was in the [[Birmingham Repertory Theatre|Birmingham Rep]]'s revival of the play in March–April 1945.<ref>[https://www.cms.birmingham-rep.co.uk/rep100/3253 ''Land's End'' at the Birmingham Rep, birmingham-rep.co.uk]</ref> Lucas's radio play ''The Siren'' was first broadcast on the [[BBC Third Programme]] in 1948, with [[Catherine Lacey]], [[Frith Banbury]] and [[Deryck Guyler]] in the cast;<ref>''The Siren'' by F. L. Lucas, BBC Third Programme, 19 & 21 Jan. 1948, genome.ch.bbc.co.uk [https://www.genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/2bb29082ba214e89a947f9980e59c995]</ref><ref>[https://www.suttonelms.org.uk/r3-1948.html Third Programme, Drama, 1948: suttonelms.org.uk]</ref> a second production followed on the [[BBC Home Service|Home Service]] in 1949, with [[Cathleen Nesbitt]] and [[Hugh Burden]].<ref>''The Siren'' by F. L. Lucas, BBC Home Service, 10 Oct. 1949, genome.ch.bbc.co.uk [http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/105b6bba2d294055a7b3e73f8af34c78]</ref> The play dramatises [[George Sand]]'s amorous escapades in Paris and Italy with [[Alfred de Musset]] and Dr. Pietro Pagello<ref>Williams, Stephen, ''Plays on the Air: A Survey of Drama Broadcasts'' (London, 1951)</ref> – the subject of the 1999 film [[Children of the Century|''Les Enfants du Siècle'']]. His political drama [[The Bear Dances|''The Bear Dances: A Play in Three Acts'']] was the first dramatisation of the Soviets on London’s [[West End theatre|West-end stage]] ([[Garrick Theatre]], 1932, with [[Elena Miramova]], [[Abraham Sofaer]] and [[Olga Lindo]]). This play, though it closed early in London, was revived by various repertory theatres in the North of England in the later 1930s. It was an attempt at ideological disinfectant, written at a time when Cambridge University (in Lucas's words) "grew full of very green young men going very Red".<ref name="Wakeman J 1975"/>
==History, politics and society==
===Pharsalus=== Outside literature, Lucas is remembered for his solution to one of the more contentious problems of ancient topography. His "north-bank" thesis<ref>Lucas, F. L., 'The Battlefield of Pharsalos ', ''Annual of the British School at Athens'', No. XXIV, 1919–21 [https://www.jstor.org/stable/30102514?seq=1]</ref> on the location of the [[Battle of Pharsalus]] (48 B.C.), based on his 1921 solo field-trip to Thessaly and on a re-examination of the sources, dismissed a dozen previous theories and is now widely accepted by historians.<ref>Holmes, T. Rice, ''The Roman Republic and the Founder of the Empire'' (Oxford, 1923); Fuller, J. F. C., ''Julius Caesar: Man, Soldier and Tyrant'' (London, 1965); Sheppard, Simon, ''Pharsalus 48 B.C.: Caesar and Pompey – Clash of the Titans'' (Oxford, 2006)</ref> John D. Morgan in his definitive 'Palae-pharsalus – the Battle and the Town'<ref>Morgan, John D., ''The American Journal of Archaeology'', Vol. 87, No. 1, Jan. 1983</ref> writes: "My reconstruction is similar to Lucas’s, and in fact I borrow one of his alternatives for the line of the Pompeian retreat. Lucas’s theory has been subjected to many criticisms, but has remained essentially unshaken."
===Appeasement=== {{rquote|right| Are our minds clear, or are we drifting foggily into another 1914? It was because England hedged then, that we all but perished in the ditch beyond. | F. L. Lucas, ''The Week-end Review'', 16 Sept. 1933 }} In the 1930s Lucas was widely known for his political letters to the British Press with their outspoken attacks on the policy that came to be known as [[appeasement]]. Following the inaction of the [[League of Nations|League]] over [[Japanese invasion of Manchuria|Manchuria]], he called repeatedly for "a League within the League", of nations pledged to uphold international law and oppose aggression. "Since the War," he wrote in 1933, "British policy has been shuffling, timid, ignoble."<ref>Lucas, F. L., letter, ''The Week-end Review'', 21 October 1933</ref> Having read ''[[Mein Kampf]]'' in the unexpurgated original and taken its threats as a statement of intent, he urged in September 1933 that Nazi Germany be prevented from re-arming. "[[Treaty of Versailles|Versailles]] was monstrous", he wrote in ''The Week-end Review'', :"but one thing surely comes first: Germany must not be allowed to re-arm. How prevent it? By an international police-force? It would be ideal. Unfortunately it does not exist. The French have urged it. We in our muddle-headedness want neither it nor the alternative – war. Are we prepared to see France do its work instead and take action in Germany? – or are we going to sit sanctimoniously on the fence, disapproving, but secretly relieved? I devoutly hope the first. Germany must not re-arm; even if the French had to invade it once every five years, that would be better than the alternative."<ref>Lucas, F. L., letter, ''The Week-end Review'', 16 September 1933</ref> A hatred of war, he argued in 1936, "can be no reason for being false to ourselves, in the name of an aimless amiability that cries ‘peace’ where there is none."<ref>Lucas, F. L., letter, ''Cambridge Review'', 14 February 1936</ref> And in 1937: "We have not kept agreements we made; we have made agreements we should not; we have tried to cheat our way to security, and now the security proves a cheat. We have forgotten the wisdom which says that since we cannot foresee where any road will lead in the end, we should stick to the straight and honest one."<ref>Lucas, F. L., letter, ''Manchester Guardian'', 6 September 1937</ref> Despite the prevailing [[pacifism]] of the time – and he exchanged views with "passive pacifists" in the correspondence-columns – such sentiments struck a chord. "This is the voice of the England I love," wrote a correspondent from Prague in 1938,<ref group=note>Lucas's Prague correspondent was Otakar Vočadlo (1895-1974).</ref><ref name="Otakar Vočadlo King's"/><ref name="vocadlo cz"/> "and for whose soul I was trembling when I heard about the welcome given Mr Chamberlain on his return from Munich."<ref>Letter in reply to Lucas's 'The Munich Agreement–and after', ''Manchester Guardian'', 4 October 1938; quoted in Lucas, ''Journal Under the Terror, 1938'' (London, 1939)</ref> Not everyone admired the letters, however: the pro-appeasement ''[[The Times|Times]]'' refused to publish him after 1935 (he described the Editor's office as "an annexe of the German embassy"<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''Journal Under the Terror, 1938'' (London 1939), p.308</ref>), and when he condemned the Italian invasion of [[Abyssinia Crisis|Abyssinia]] and the democracies' inadequate response, he received abusive and threatening replies from Fascists, including one from [[Ezra Pound]]. Lucas put Pound's letter on display at the Cambridge Anti-Fascist Exhibition. {| class="toccolours" style="float: right; margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 2em; font-size: 85%; background:#c6dbf7; color:black; width:30em; max-width: 40%;" cellspacing="5" | style="text-align: left;" | :''' ''SPLENDID ISOLATION'' ''' ( "The British policeman should stick to his own beat." – ''Evening Standard'', 22 April 1935 )<br> : ... :Paris may pass in gas and flame and blood – :We shall sit safe behind our sundering flood. :Berlin may build a Holier Inquisition – :It will but mean an extra-late edition. :Hitler be hailed through all a wrecked Ukraine – :We shall just read, and turn to golf again. :For God, the day our guardian seas He took, :Gave us the broad breast of a [[Max Aitken, Lord Beaverbrook|''Beaverbrook'']]; :Round us, though fails the Channel – never fear! – :Still lie the stainless depths of [[Harold Harmsworth, 1st Viscount Rothermere|''Rothermere'']]. |- | style="text-align: left;" | [From a verse-satire by '''F. L. Lucas''' on the non-interventionist British [[Media proprietor|press barons]]; ''New Statesman and Nation'', 11 May 1935, p. 669] |}
As well as letters to the press (some forty in all) his campaign included satires, articles, books, public speaking, fund-raising for the [[British Red Cross|Red Cross]], petitions to Parliament, meetings with émigrés like [[Haile Selassie I|Haile Selassie]] and [[Stefan Zweig]], and help for refugees. In these activities he was inspired by the example of "that grand old man"<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''Journal Under the Terror, 1938'' (London, 1939), p.265</ref> [[H. W. Nevinson]], "one of the most striking personalities I have ever known",<ref name="Lucas, F. L. 1951">Lucas, F. L., ''Literature and Psychology'' (London, 1951), Preface</ref> "whose long life has been given to Liberty".<ref>Lucas, F. L., dedication to ''The Delights of Dictatorship'' (Cambridge, 1938)</ref>
Believing that future readers would be interested in what it had been like to live through such times, Lucas kept and published in March 1939 a diary for 1938, ''Journal Under the Terror, 1938''. (The "high source" he refers to in ''Journal'' was probably [[Harold Nicolson]].<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''Journal Under the Terror, 1938'' (London, 1939), p.310</ref>) ''Journal'' is notable for its candid remarks on pro-Nazi and pro-appeasement figures in the British Establishment. Of Chamberlain at [[Munich Agreement|Munich]] he wrote (30 September): :"Even if what he did were the right thing to do, this was not the way to do it."<ref>Lucas, F. L., Letter, ''Manchester Guardian'', 4 October 1938</ref> "The surrender ''might'' have been necessary: the cant was not. Any statesman with a sense of honour would at least have stilled that hysterical cheering and said: ''My friends, for the present, we are out of danger. But remember that others, who trusted in us, are not. This is a day for relief, perhaps; but for sorrow also; for shame, not for revelling.'' But this Chamberlain comes home beaming as fatuously as some country-cousin whom a couple of card-sharpers in the train have just allowed to win sixpence, to encourage him."<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''Journal Under the Terror, 1938'' (London, 1939), p.277</ref>
The outcome he feared was an Anglo-German peace agreement – an accord between Nazis and the British Establishment: "One day a little note from [[Berghof (residence)|Berchtesgaden]] will appoint [[Charles Vane-Tempest-Stewart, 7th Marquess of Londonderry|Lord Londonderry]] to 10 Downing Street. And that will settle everything."<ref>Lucas, F. L., Letter, ''Journal Under the Terror, 1938'' (London, 1939), p.146</ref> Though he welcomed the Government's about-turn on appeasement in March 1939, he doubted the genuineness of the conversion. "The noble lords of our Fifth Column still go marching on."<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''Journal Under the Terror, 1938'' (London 1939), Note, March 1939</ref>
The Nazis had noted Lucas's letters. In August 1939 he received a reply from [[Goebbels]], advising him to heed public opinion.<ref>Lucas, F. L., letter, ''Manchester Guardian'', Tuesday, 15 August 1939</ref> As a leading anti-fascist campaigner, he was placed by the Nazis on their [[The Black Book|''Sonderfahndungsliste G.B.'']] [:''Special Search List G.B.''] of Britons to be arrested and liquidated.
===Bletchley Park=== [[File:F L Lucas Bletchley Park letter.jpg|thumb|right|200px|A 1939 Lucas letter from 'Room 47, Foreign Office' [:Bletchley Park], throwing a correspondent off the scent.]] A brilliant linguist<ref name=Tillyard>Tillyard, E. M. W., ''The Muse Unchained'' (London, 1958), p.80</ref> with infantry and [[Intelligence Corps (United Kingdom)|Intelligence Corps]] experience from 1914–18, proven anti-fascist credentials and a scepticism about the Soviet Union, Lucas was one of the first academics recruited by the Foreign Office – on 3 September 1939 – to [[Bletchley Park]]. He was one of the original four members of [[Hut 3]], whose organisation he set up,<ref name="rollofhonour.bletchleypark.org.uk">[https://www.rollofhonour.bletchleypark.org.uk rollofhonour.bletchleypark]</ref> and from March to July 1942, when the Hut was run by committee, acting head.<ref>Briggs, Asa, ''Secret Days: Code-breaking in Bletchley Park'' (London 2011)</ref> He remained a central figure there, working throughout the war on the [[Enigma machine|Enigma]] decodes as translator, intelligence-analyst and (from July 1942) head of the Research Section, ''3G'' [:Hut 3 General Intelligence], on the busy 4 p.m. to 1 a.m. shift.<ref name="Smith, Michael 2011">Smith, Michael, ''The Secrets of Station X'' (London, 2011)</ref><ref name="Hinsley and Stripp 2001">Hinsley, F. H. and Stripp, Alan, eds., ''Code-breakers : The Inside Story of Bletchley Park'' (Oxford, 2001)</ref> His main activities in ''3G'' were cracking Axis covernames and covernumbers in decodes, analysing German "proformas" (supplies and ammunition returns), and writing general intelligence papers.<ref name="Jackson, John 2002 pp.77-78">Jackson, John, ed., ''The Secret War of Hut 3'' [based on [[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|National Archives]] documents HW3/119 & HW3/120] (Military Press, Milton Keynes, 2002), pp.77-8</ref><ref>Annan, Noel, ''Changing Enemies: The Defeat and Regeneration of Germany'' (London, 1995): nytimes.com [https://www.nytimes.com/books/first/a/annan-enemies.html]</ref>
Among the intelligence-reports he produced was a study of Hitler's intentions in the east in May 1941, which contrasted with the Foreign Office view that the Germans were just "building up pressure [on the U.S.S.R.] to extract more raw materials".<ref name=autogenerated4>Millward, William, 'Life in and out of Hut 3' in ''Codebreakers: The Inside Story of Bletchley Park'', eds. F. H. Hinsley & Alan Strip (Oxford 1993), p.24</ref> "It becomes harder than ever to doubt," Lucas wrote, :"that the object of these large movements of the German Army and Air Force is Russia. From rail movements towards Moldavia in the south to ship movements towards Varanger fjord in the far north there is everywhere the same eastward trend. Either the purpose is blackmail or it is war. No doubt Hitler would prefer a bloodless surrender. But the quiet move, for instance, of a prisoner-of-war cage to Tarnow looks more like business than bluff."<ref>The National Archives PRO HW 1/3; Smith, Michael, ''The Secrets of Station X'' (London, 2011), p. 126</ref>
Other Lucas papers ranged from practical suggestions, such as the proposal that the Salonica-Athens railway be cut in the [[Mount Oeta|Oeta]] gorges viaducts (carried out in [[Operation Harling]]), to psychological overviews later in the war, like 'Hitler as seen by Source' [:through decodes] and 'German Morale as seen by Source' (his old special subject from 1918 Intelligence Corps days).<ref name="Jackson, John 2002 pp.77-78"/>
[[File:"Hut 3", Bletchley Park - geograph.org.uk - 1592920.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Hut 3, Bletchley Park, in 2009 (photo: Ian Petticrew)]] He also wrote confidential Special Reports for the Bletchley Park Director-General, one on Second Front rumours in German signals, and another, with [[Peter Calvocoressi]], in early 1945 on the failure of Allied intelligence to foresee the [[Battle of the Bulge|German counter-offensive through the Ardennes]] in December 1944. Lucas and Calvocoressi concluded that "the costly reverse might have been avoided if Ultra had been more carefully considered".<ref>[[Harry Hinsley]]'s words, in ''Codebreakers: The Inside Story of Bletchley Park'', eds. F. H. Hinsley & Alan Strip (Oxford 1993), p.11</ref> For its part, Hut 3 had grown "shy of going beyond its job of amending and explaining German messages", believing that "drawing broad conclusions was for the intelligence staff at SHAEF, who had information from all sources", including aerial reconnaissance.<ref>Calvocoressi to [[Neil Leslie Webster]], in Pearson, Joss ed. ''Neil Webster's Cribs for Victory: The Untold Story of Bletchley Park's Secret Room'' (2011), p. 67</ref> E. J. N. Rose, head Air Adviser in Hut 3, read the paper at the time and described it in 1998 as "an extremely good report" that "showed the failure of intelligence at SHAEF and at the Air Ministry".<ref name="autogenerated4"/><ref>Smith, Michael, ''The Secrets of Station X'' (London, 2011), p.272</ref> The report is not known to have survived. It was probably the "Top Secret [intelligence] digest", a post-mortem on that failure, referred to by [[Kenneth Strong|General Strong]] (1968), "both record-copies of which were destroyed".<ref>Strong, K. W. D., ''Intelligence at the Top: the recollections of an Intelligence Officer'' (London, 1968), p.175-6</ref><ref>Bennett, Ralph, ''Ultra in the West'' (London, 1979), p.179</ref> Lucas and Calvocoressi "expected heads to roll at Eisenhower's HQ, but they did no more than wobble".<ref>Calvocoressi, Peter, ''Top Secret Ultra'' (London 1980)</ref><ref>'Peter Calvocoressi: Political writer who served at Bletchley Park and assisted at the Nuremberg trials', independent.co.uk [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/peter-calvocoressi-political-writer-who-served-at-bletchley-park-and-assisted-at-the-nuremberg-trials-1905181.html]</ref>
The most "exciting" work he did at Bletchley Park, he recalled, was handling operational signals on Axis convoys to North Africa from July 1941 and deducing convoys' routes using decrypts, maps, pins and pieces of string.<ref>'History of Hut 3', Public Records Office documents, ref. HW3/119 and /120; Smith, Michael, ''Station X: The Codebreakers of Bletchley Park'' (London, 1998); Smith, Michael, ''The Secrets of Station X'' (London, 2011), p.195</ref> The high standards of accuracy and clarity that prevailed in Hut 3, his chief maintained, were "largely due to [Lucas's] being such a stickler" for them.<ref name="Wilkinson, L. P. 1967 p.21">Wilkinson, L. P., 'F. L. Lucas' in King's College Report, November 1967, p.21</ref>
In out-of-hut hours Major Lucas was Officer Commanding the Bletchley Park [[Home Guard (United Kingdom)|Home Guard]], a "rabble of egg-heads" that he turned, contrary to stereotype, into an efficient unit that outwitted the local regular forces in military exercises.<ref name="Wilkinson, L. P. 1967 p.21"/><ref name="Hinsley and Stripp 2001"/> From June 1945 to the end of the War he was head of the Hut 3 History Section, compiling a 'History of Hut 3', now documents HW3/119 and HW3/120 in the [[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|National Archives]].<ref name="rollofhonour.bletchleypark.org.uk"/> He was awarded the [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] in 1946 for his wartime work.<ref>[https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/37412/supplement/281 The London Gazette Publication date: 28 December 1945 Supplement: 37412 Page: 281]</ref><ref group=note>Non-Intelligence-specific reflections on his wartime years and work at Bletchley Park are contained in ''The Greatest Problem'' (London 1960) [pp.43, 117, 151, 270–271, 278] and in the autobiographical essay in ''World Authors, 1950–1970: A Companion Volume to Twentieth-Century Authors'', ed. John Wakeman (New York 1975) [pp.882-884].</ref>
===Demographics=== In later years Lucas took up the cause of population-control, "a problem not talked about nearly enough", discussing the dangers of world [[Human overpopulation|overpopulation]] in ''The Greatest Problem'' (1960). Having laid out the statistics to 1959 and future projections, he argued that the "reckless proliferation" of ''homo sapiens'', as well as impoverishing the world by environmental damage and species-extinctions, would be damaging to the individual and to society: :"The finest human qualities are endangered, because the size of populations increases, and ought to be diminished; the size of states increases, and ought to be diminished; the size of cities increases, and ought to be diminished. Vast communities lead to small individuals; and the real worth of any community lies in the worth of its individuals... The individual comes to feel himself a mere drop in the ocean; and feeling impotent, he grows irresponsible... Vast democracies cannot keep the virtues of democracy."<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''The Greatest Problem, and Other Essay'' (London, 1960), p.321</ref><ref>Lucas, F. L., ''The Art of Living'' (London 1959), p.176-7</ref>
If population-growth went unchecked, he felt, "the damage to national efficiency might drive governments to act more intelligently";<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''The Greatest Problem, and Other Essay'' (London 1960), p.326</ref> but better would be "a concentrated drive for population-planning, despite the formidable practical, scientific and psychological obstacles". "Far more, however," he added, "depends on the individual and his power to realise his own plight. Hence the need for constant and frank discussion, instead of leaving the subject, as now, in a conspiracy of uneasy silence; and the need for patient and tireless propaganda against man's reckless propagation."<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''The Greatest Problem'' (London, 1960), p.330-331</ref> {| class="toccolours" style="float: right; margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 2em; font-size: 85%; background:#dbf7c5; color:black; width:30em; max-width: 40%;" cellspacing="5" | style="text-align: left;" | '''Axiom'''
"The more populous the world and the more intricate its structure, the greater must be its fundamental insecurity. A world-structure too elaborately scientific, if once disrupted by war, revolution, natural cataclysm or epidemic, might collapse into a chaos not easily rebuilt."<br /> |- | style="text-align: left;" | ― F. L. Lucas, ''The Greatest Problem'' (1960), p. 319-320 |}
He singled out the [[Holy See|Vatican]] for particular criticism. "Common sense percolates," he had written in 1934, "despite the Roman Church; which with its half-cynical sense of reality will doubtless end by swallowing the inevitable, as with Copernicus and Darwin, and evolve some doctrine of Immaculate Contraception."<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''From Olympus to the Styx'' (London, 1934), p.254</ref> He later pointed out the illogicality of the doctrine declaring it lawful to juggle with the [[Calendar-based contraceptive methods|calendar]]<ref>''Moral Questions Affecting Married Life'': Addresses given 29 October 1951 to the Italian Catholic Union of midwives, and 26 November 1951 to the National Congress of the Family Front and the Association of Large Families, National Catholic Welfare Conference, Washington, DC [https://www.(ewtn.com/library/PAPALDOC/P511029.HTM]</ref> but otherwise unlawful to practise [[Christian views on contraception|contraception]].<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''The Greatest Problem'' (London, 1960), p.329</ref>
He was not optimistic about post-war immigration to the UK, believing that in the modern world the problem of over-breeding was not solved by migration, which in turn could bring new social problems. "Persons of liberal principles are shocked if one views this influx with misgiving. But the advantages are far from certain. Principles, however liberal, are no substitute for common sense."<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''The Greatest Problem'' (London, 1960), p.318</ref>
In ''Literature and Psychology'' (1951) he had conjectured that the end of civilisation might come, not from war or famine, but from a decay of man's intelligence and self-control under the strain of a too artificial way of life.<ref>Lucas, F. L., ''Literature and Psychology'' (London, 1951), p.140</ref> His only science-fiction story, 'Last Act' (1937), set in a not-too-distant future, had depicted the beginning of the end for "the desolator, Man", in an overpopulated, over-technological, and rapidly overheating biosphere.<ref>Lucas, F. L., 'Last Act', in ''The Woman Clothed with the Sun, and Other Stories'' (London, 1937; New York, 1938), p.343</ref>

... My dream is of a British statesman who could say to his countrymen: "You are sick of war, weary of entanglements. There are some who would have you renounce both. I offer you instead a heavier load of foreign responsibilities, a risk of new war. Because that is the only road to lasting peace. Since the War, British policy has been shuffling, timid, ignoble. Be bold at last, and give a lead to Europe, by offering to form with France and whatever other European states will join, a League within the League, of nations pledged to submit all disputes to the League, but pledged also to fight without hesitation in defence of any member of the group who is attacked. If Germany will join, so much the better; though Germany as she is never will. If America, better still; for the present America is a broken reed. All the more honor for us to accept a responsibility if she refuses.
"The way will not be easy. We shall often regret the day we pledged ourselves to bear taxation in peace and face death in war for interests and frontiers not our own. But no interest is more really our own than the reign of law between nations."
That is little likely to happen. Only an Abraham Lincoln takes risks of that sort with a nation. But this is not because the ordinary politician is wiser; it is because the ordinary politician does not realize the latent force of idealism, all the stronger with the decay of the religions which gave it other outlets, ready in the world of to-day for any leader with the courage to use it; and so easily abused accordingly by the rulers of Moscow and Berlin. |- | style="text-align: left;" | [From a letter by Lucas to ''The Week-end Review'', 21 October 1933] |} *''The Greatest Problem, and Other Essays''; <small>an essay on world [[Human overpopulation|overpopulation]], literary essays [Tolstoy, Housman], and autobiographical pieces</small> (Cassell, London, 1960) *''The Drama of Ibsen and Strindberg''; <small>literary criticism</small> (Cassell, London, 1962) *''August Strindberg: Inferno''; <small>translation by Mary Sandbach, introduction by Lucas</small> (Hutchinson, London, 1962) *''The Drama of Chekhov, Synge, Yeats and Pirandello''; <small>literary criticism</small> (Cassell, London, 1963) *''Greek Poetry''; <small>verse translations; revised and renamed edition of 1951 volume, without the passages from Homer</small> ([[Everyman Library]], Dent, London, 1966) *''Greek Drama for the Common Reader''; <small>verse translations; revised and renamed edition of 1954 volume</small> (Chatto & Windus, London, 1967) *''Greek Tragedy and Comedy''; <small>verse translations; renamed paperback edition of 1967 volume</small> (Viking Press, New York, 1968) *''The English Agent: A Tale of The Peninsular War''; <small>novel</small> (Cassell, London, 1969)
