{{Infobox spree killer | name = Laurie Dann | image = Laurie dann.jpg | image_size = 150px | image_caption = | birth_name = Laurie Ann Wasserman | birth_date = {{Birth date|1957|10|18}} | birth_place = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|1988|05|20|1957|10|18}} | death_place = [[Winnetka, Illinois]], U.S. | occupation = Babysitter | spouse = {{marriage|Russell Dann|1982|1985|end=div}} | parents = Norman and Edith Wasserman | date = May 20, 1988 | fatalities = 2 (including herself) | injuries = 6 | weapons = [[.22 Long Rifle|.22 caliber]] [[Beretta]] [[pistol]], [[Smith & Wesson]] [[.357 Magnum|.357 caliber]] [[revolver]] }}
'''Laurie Dann''' (née '''Wasserman'''; October 18, 1957 – May 20, 1988) was an American murderer who shot and killed one boy, [[Nick Corwin]], and wounded two girls and three boys in a [[Winnetka, Illinois]] elementary school. She then took a family hostage and shot another man, non-fatally, before killing herself.
==Early life== Dann was born in [[Chicago]] and grew up in [[Glencoe, Illinois|Glencoe]], a north suburb of Chicago. She was the daughter of an accountant, Norman Wasserman, and his wife, Edith Joy.<ref name=Day>{{cite book | last =Egginton | first =Joyce | title =Day of fury: The story of the tragic shootings that forever changed the village of Winnetka | publisher =William Morrow and Company | year =1991 | location = New York | pages = | url = | doi = | isbn = 0-688-09085-0 }}</ref><ref name=MOI>{{cite book |author1=Joel Kaplan |author2=George Papajohn |author3=Eric Zorn | title =Murder of Innocence: The tragic life and final rampage of Laurie Dann | publisher =Warner Books | year =1990 | location = New York | pages = | url = | doi = | isbn = 978-0-446-36002-9}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1988-06-05/news/8801040887_1_student-winnetka-police-laurie-dann | work=Chicago Tribune | first1=George | last1=Papajohn | title=The Many Faces Of Laurie Dann | date=1988-06-05}}</ref>
Those who knew Dann described her as shy and withdrawn.<ref name=Day/><ref name=MOI/> She graduated from [[New Trier High School]] in [[Winnetka, Illinois]], in 1975.<ref name=MOI/> Her grades were poor in high school, but she was able to attend [[Drake University]] in [[Des Moines, Iowa]]. When her grades improved, she transferred to the [[University of Arizona]] with the goal of becoming a teacher. She began dating a [[Pre-medical|pre-med]] student, and the relationship soon became serious, but she was becoming possessive and demanding.<ref name=MOI/> In the summer of 1977 she attended the [[University of Wisconsin]] in Madison, taking a course in home economics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-1988-06-05-8801040887-story.html#|title=THE MANY FACES OF LAURIE DANN|first=George Papajohn and Joel Kaplan. Ray Gibson, William Recktenwald, John O`Brien, Steve Johnson, Barbara Mahany and Stevenson Swanson contributed to this|last=report|publisher=}}</ref>
In 1980, with the relationship failing, Dann moved back to her parents' home. She then transferred to [[Northwestern University]] to complete her degree, but she dropped out of all her classes and never graduated.<ref name=Day/><ref name=MOI/>
==Marriage and divorce== She met and married Russell Dann, an executive in an insurance broker firm in September 1982, but the marriage quickly soured as Russell's family noted signs of [[obsessive-compulsive disorder]] and other strange behavior,<ref name=Day/> including leaving trash around the house.<ref name=MOI/> She saw a [[psychiatrist]] for a short period, who identified her childhood and upbringing as a cause of her problems.<ref name=MOI/>
Laurie and Russell Dann separated in October 1985.<ref name=Day/> The divorce negotiations were acrimonious, with Laurie claiming that Russell was [[domestic violence|abusive]]. In the following months, the police were called to investigate various incidents, including several harassing phone calls made to Russell and his family.<ref name=MOI/> In April 1986, Laurie Dann accused Russell of breaking into and [[vandalism|vandalizing]] her parents' house, where she was then living. Shortly after, she purchased a [[Smith & Wesson]] [[.357 Magnum]], telling the salesman that she needed it for self-defense. The police were concerned about her gun ownership and unsuccessfully tried to persuade Dann and her family that she should give up the gun.<ref name=Day/>
In August 1986, she contacted her ex-boyfriend, who was by then a [[Residency (medicine)|resident]] at a hospital, and claimed to have had his child. When he refused to believe her, Dann called the hospital where he worked and claimed he had [[rape]]d her in the emergency room.<ref name=MOI/><ref name=NYT>{{cite news | last =AP | title =Police Still Unraveling Trail Left by Woman in Rampage | work = | pages = | language = | publisher =New York Times | date =1988-05-22 | url =https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?sec=health&res=940DE2DA1231F931A15756C0A96E948260 | accessdate =2007-02-14 }}</ref>
In September 1986, Russell Dann reported he had been stabbed in his sleep with an [[icepick]]. He accused Laurie of the crime, although he had not actually seen his attacker. The police decided not to press charges against Laurie based on a medical report which suggested that the injury might have been self-inflicted, Russell's abrasive attitude towards the police, and his failed [[polygraph]] test.<ref name=Day/><ref name=MOI/> Russell and his family continued to receive harassing hang-up phone calls, and Laurie was arrested for calls made to Russell's sister. The charges were dropped due to lack of evidence.<ref name=MOI/>
Just before their divorce was finalized in April 1987, Laurie accused Russell of raping her. There were no physical signs supporting Laurie's claim, although she passed two polygraph tests.<ref name=MOI/> In May 1987, Laurie accused Russell of placing an incendiary device in her home.<ref name=Day/> No charges were filed against Russell for either alleged event. Laurie's parents believed her claims and supported and defended her throughout. By this time, Laurie Dann was being treated by another psychiatrist for [[obsessive-compulsive disorder]] and a "chemical imbalance"; the psychiatrist told police that he did not think Laurie was [[suicide|suicidal]] or homicidal.<ref name=MOI/>
==Final year== Dann worked as a babysitter, and some employers were happy with the care she provided their children.<ref name=NYT/> Others made complaints to the police about damage to their furniture and the theft of food and clothes. Despite the complaints, no charges were pressed. Dann's father did pay for damages in one case.<ref name=MOI/>
In the summer of 1987, Dann sublet a university apartment in [[Evanston, Illinois]]. Once again, her strange behavior was noted, including riding up and down in elevators for hours, wearing rubber gloves to touch metal, and leaving meat to rot in sofa cushions. She took no classes at the university.
In the fall of 1987, Dann claimed she had received threatening letters from Russell and that he had [[sexual assault|sexually assaulted]] her in a parking lot, but the police did not believe her. A few weeks later, she purchased a [[.32 S&W Long|.32-caliber]] [[Smith & Wesson]] revolver.<ref name=Day/>
With her condition deteriorating, Dann and her family sought specialized help. In November 1987, she moved to [[Madison, Wisconsin]], to live in a student residence while being observed by a psychiatrist who specialized in obsessive-compulsive disorder. She had already begun taking [[clomipramine]], a drug for OCD, and her new psychiatrist increased the dosage, adding [[lithium carbonate]] to reduce her mood swings and initiating [[behavioral therapy]] to work on her phobias and ritualistic behaviors.<ref name=MOI/> Despite the intervention, her strange behavior continued, including riding elevators for long periods, changing television channels repetitively, and an obsession with "good" and "bad" numbers. There were also concerns about whether she was [[bulimic]].
Dann purchased a .22 semi-automatic [[Beretta]] at the end of December 1987. In March 1988, she stopped attending her appointments with the psychiatrist and behavior therapist.<ref name=MOI/> At about the same time, she began to make preparations for the attacks. She stole books from the library on [[poisons]], and she diluted [[arsenic]] and other chemicals from a lab. She also shoplifted clothes and wigs to disguise herself and was arrested for theft on one occasion. Both her psychiatrist and her father tried to persuade her to enter the hospital as an inpatient, but she refused.<ref name=MOI/>
Dann continued to make numerous hang-up phone calls to her former in-laws and babysitting clients. Eventually, the calls escalated to death threats. An ex-boyfriend and his wife also received dozens of threatening calls. In May 1988, a letter, later confirmed to have been sent by Laurie Dann, was sent to the hospital administration where her ex-boyfriend then worked, again accusing him of sexual assault. Since the phone calls were across state lines, the [[FBI]] became involved, and a federal indictment against Dann was prepared. However, the ex-boyfriend, fearful of publicity,<ref name=Day/> and concerned about Dann getting bail and then attempting to fulfill her threats against him, decided to wait until other charges were filed in Illinois.<ref name=MOI/><ref name=NYT/><ref name=newsweek/> In May 1988, a [[janitor]] found her lying in the fetal position inside a garbage bag in a trash room. This precipitated a search of her room and her departure back to Glencoe.<ref name=Day/><ref name=MOI/><ref name=newsweek/>
==Attacks== During the days before May 20, 1988, Laurie Dann prepared rice cereal snacks and juice boxes poisoned with the diluted arsenic she had stolen in Madison. She mailed them to a former acquaintance, ex-babysitting clients, her psychiatrist, Russell Dann, and others. In the early morning of May 20, she personally delivered snacks and juice "samples" to acquaintances, and families for whom she had babysat, some of whom had not seen her for years.<ref name=Day/><ref name =MOI/> Other snacks were delivered to [[Alpha Tau Omega]], [[Psi Upsilon]], and [[Kappa Sigma]] [[fraternity house]]s and Leverone Hall at [[Northwestern University]] in [[Evanston, Illinois|Evanston]].<ref name=Day/><ref name =MOI/> Notes were attached to some of the deliveries.<ref>Sources ascribe similar notes to different recipients. For example, Associated Press articles mention that a note "Love your little sisters. Enjoy" was sent to a family, while a Chicago Tribune article, and Kaplan et al. book suggests that similar notes ("Love, your little sisters. Enjoy" and "To the ATOs, from your little sisters") were received by fraternities. Similarly, a longer text "I'm going to be in Glencoe when your in town-look forward to seeing you guys. I was going to send you coffee cake, but I was making rice crispy treats for school and decided to send some. Enjoy. Love, Laurie" was sent by mail according to the Kaplan et al. book, and attached to the fraternity deliveries according to the Egginton book.</ref><ref>Ray Gibson and Linnet Myers, "School Killer Left A Trail Of Poison Fraternities, Homes Receive Tainted Food", ''Chicago Tribune'' (22 May 1988) 1.</ref><ref name=TS>{{cite news |last=AP |title=Woman sent poisoned snacks before school shooting spree |work= |pages=, |language= |publisher=Toronto Star |date=1988-05-22 |url=http://www.theawarenesscenter.org/lauriedann.html#poisoned |accessdate=2007-02-14 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070213052715/http://www.theawarenesscenter.org/lauriedann.html |archivedate=2007-02-13 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The drinks were often leaking and the squares unpleasant-tasting, so few were actually consumed. In addition, the arsenic was highly diluted so nobody became seriously ill.<ref name=Day/>
At about 9:00 a.m. on the 20th, Dann arrived at the home of the Rushe family, former babysitting clients in [[Winnetka, Illinois]], to pick up their two youngest children. The family had just told Dann they were moving away.<ref name = MOI/> Instead of taking the children on the promised outing, she took them to Ravinia Elementary School in Highland Park, Illinois, where she erroneously believed that both of her former sister-in-law's two sons were enrolled (in fact, one of Dann's intended targets was not even a student at the school). She left the two children in the car while she entered the school and tried to detonate a fire bomb in one of the school's hallways. After Dann's departure, the small fire she set was subsequently discovered by students, and quickly extinguished by a teacher. She drove to a local daycare attended by her ex-sister-in-law's daughter and tried to enter the building with a plastic can of gasoline, but was stopped by staff.
Next Dann drove the children back to their home and offered them some arsenic-poisoned milk, but the boys spat it out because it tasted strange to them. Once at their home, she lured them downstairs and used gasoline to set fire to the house, trapping their mother and the two children in the basement (they managed to escape).<ref name=Day/><ref name =MOI/><ref name=trib>{{cite news |author1=Robert Enstad Steve Johnson |author2=Maria Hunt |author3=Ray Gibson |author4=Dennis Odom |author5=David Ibata |author6=Joel Kaplan |title=Scared Town Comforts Families - Special Services Soothe The Pain in Winnetka |pages= |language= |work=Chicago Tribune |date=1988-05-23 |url=http://www.theawarenesscenter.org/lauriedann.html#Scared |accessdate=2007-02-14 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070213052715/http://www.theawarenesscenter.org/lauriedann.html |archivedate=2007-02-13 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> She drove three and a half blocks to the Hubbard Woods Elementary School with three handguns in her possession. She wandered into a second grade classroom for a short while, then left. Finding a boy in the corridor, Dann pushed him into the boys' washroom and shot him with a .22 semi-automatic [[Beretta]] pistol. Her [[Smith & Wesson]] .357 Magnum revolver jammed when she tried to fire it at two other boys, and she threw it into the trash along with the spare ammunition. The boys ran out of the washroom and raised the alarm.<ref name=Day/> Dann then reentered the second grade classroom where students were working in groups on a bicycle safety test. She ordered all the children into the corner of the room. The teacher refused and attempted to disarm Dann, managing to unload the Beretta in the struggle. Dann drew a .32 Smith & Wesson from the waistband of her shorts and aimed it at several groups of the students. She shot five children, killing eight-year-old Nicholas Corwin and wounding two girls and two boys before fleeing in her car.<ref name =MOI/>
Dann was prevented from leaving the area by car because the roads were closed for a funeral cortege. She decided to drive her car backwards down the nearby street, but the road dead-ended into a private drive. Abandoning her car, she removed her bloodstained shorts and tied a blue garbage bag around her waist. With her two remaining guns she made her way through the woods and came upon the house of the Andrew family. Dann entered the house and met a mother and her twenty-year-old son, who were in the kitchen. She claimed she was raped and had shot the rapist in the struggle.<ref name=MOI/><ref name=halperin>{{Cite journal |last = Halperin |first = Jennifer |title = The education of a crusader |journal = Illinois Issues |volume = |issue = |pages = |date = December 1993 |url = http://www.lib.niu.edu/ipo/1993/ii931211.html |doi = |id = |postscript = <!--None--> |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060908061435/http://www.lib.niu.edu/ipo/1993/ii931211.html |archivedate = 2006-09-08 |df = }}</ref> The Andrews were sympathetic<ref name=halperin/> and tried to convince her that she need not fear the police because she had acted in self-defense. Mrs. Andrew gave Dann a pair of her daughter's pants to wear. While she was putting them on, Philip Andrew was able to pick up and pocket the Beretta. He suggested that she call her family. Dann agreed and called her mother, telling her she had done something terrible and that the police were involved. Philip took the phone and explained Dann's story about the rape and shooting, suggesting that Mrs. Wasserman come to get Dann; Mrs. Wasserman said she could not come because she did not have a car.
Mr. Andrew arrived home, and they continued to argue with Dann, insisting she give up the second gun. Dann called her mother again and this time Mr. Andrew spoke with Mrs. Wasserman, asking her to persuade Dann to give up the gun. While Dann spoke with her mother, Mrs. Andrew left the house and alerted the police. Mr. Andrew told Dann that he would not remain in the house if she did not put down the gun, and also left the house. Dann ordered Philip to stay. Just before noon, seeing the police advancing on the house she shot Philip in the chest, but he managed to escape out the back door before collapsing and being rescued by the police and ambulance personnel.
With the house surrounded, Dann went upstairs to a bedroom. The Wassermans and Russell Dann were brought to the house. At about 7:00 p.m., an assault team entered the house while Mr. Wasserman attempted to get Dann's attention with a bullhorn. The police found her body in the bedroom; she had shot herself in the mouth.<ref name=MOI/>
==Aftermath== [[File:Banners and signs at March for Our Lives - 036.jpg|thumb|[[Nick_Corwin|Nicky Corwin]] remembered at [[March for Our Lives]] on 24 March 2018 in Washington, D.C.]] All but one of the victims wounded by Dann recovered from their injuries, including the schoolgirl who was shot and suffered severe internal injuries. The victims, school children, and parents received extensive support to help them cope with the [[PTSD|psychological after-effects]] of the attacks.<ref name=MOI/><ref name=nyt2>{{cite news |last=Wilkerson |first=Isabel |title=Shootings Leave a Suburb in Trauma |work= |pages= |language= |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=1988-05-28 |url=http://www.theawarenesscenter.org/lauriedann.html#Shootings |accessdate=2007-07-28 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070402124116/http://www.theawarenesscenter.org/lauriedann.html |archivedate=2007-04-02 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
Parents and members of the community subsequently devoted many years to [[gun control]] policy.<ref name=MOI/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wls/story?section=news/local&id=6154968|title=School shooting remembered 20 years later|date=May 20, 2008|publisher=ABC local news|accessdate=2008-05-21}}</ref> Philip Andrew gave interviews about gun control from his hospital bed, and later became active in local and state gun control organizations as the executive director of the Illinois Council Against Handgun Violence; he subsequently became a lawyer and then an [[FBI]] agent.<ref name=newsweek/><ref name=halperin/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/features/chi-20-dann-anniversarymay20,0,5288021.story?page=2|title=Old hurts, new lives emerge two decades after Dann shootings|last=Black |first= Lisa |author2=Rubin, Bonnie Miller |date=May 20, 2008|work=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=2008-05-21}}</ref>
The Dann shootings also fueled the debate about criteria for committing [[mental illness|mentally ill]] people to mental health facilities against their will. Some favored the [[involuntary commitment]] of a person who is determined to be mentally ill and incapable of making informed decisions about treatment; [[civil libertarian]]s like Benjamin Wolf (staff counsel for the [[ACLU]] of Illinois<ref name=newsweek/>) opposed the idea saying, "It would be a shame if we cut back on the civil liberties of literally millions of mentally ill people because of the occasional bizarre incident."
A book called ''Murder of Innocence'' was written by [[Eric Zorn]] about the tragedy, and a made-for-television film of the same name was based on it. In the film, Dann's name is changed to Laurie Wade. She was played by [[Valerie Bertinelli]].<ref>{{cite web|title=MURDER OF INNOCENCE (2013)|url=http://filmrise.com/murder-innocence/|website=FilmRise.com|publisher=Fisher Klingenstein Films|accessdate=19 October 2017|date=1 December 2013}}</ref>
==Search for a rationale== Some blamed Dann's family for defending and protecting her in spite of the signs of her deteriorating mental health.<ref name=newsweek/> Investigations were hampered by the Wassermans' refusal to be interviewed by police<ref name=newsweek>{{cite news |author1=Eloise Salholz |author2=Patricia King | title =Falling Through the Cracks | work=[[Newsweek]] | date =1988-06-13 | url =http://www.theawarenesscenter.org/lauriedann.html#Falling | accessdate =2007-07-28 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070402124116/http://www.theawarenesscenter.org/lauriedann.html#Falling|archivedate = 2007-04-02}}</ref> or to provide access to Dann's psychiatric records—the records were eventually obtained by court order. On the night of Dann's death, the Wassermans allowed only a very brief search of her bedroom, after which they cleaned it and removed potential evidence.<ref name=Day/> The police were criticized for not sealing off Dann's room as part of the crime scene.<ref name=MOI/> Parents of the shooting victims subsequently sued the Wasserman family for damages.<ref name=Day/><ref name=MOI/>
Further criticism was directed at Dann's psychiatrists for failing to identify or take action regarding the signs of Dann's decreasing mental stability.<ref name=newsweek/> At the time of her suicide, Dann was taking an unlicensed drug [[clomipramine]].<ref name=Day/><ref name=drug>{{cite news |last=Gibson |first=Ray |title=Winnetka Killer Treated With Psychiatric Drug |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |date=1988-06-02 |url=http://www.theawarenesscenter.org/lauriedann.html#Treated |accessdate=2007-02-14 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070213052715/http://www.theawarenesscenter.org/lauriedann.html |archivedate=2007-02-13 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The effects of this drug were initially considered as contributing factors to Dann's mental well-being, but ultimately ruled out.<ref name=drugFDA>{{cite news |title=Drug Dann Used Gets FDA Approval |pages= |language= |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |date=1988-06-08 |url=http://www.theawarenesscenter.org/lauriedann.html#Drug |accessdate=2007-07-28 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070402124116/http://www.theawarenesscenter.org/lauriedann.html |archivedate=2007-04-02 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
Two newspaper clippings were found among Dann's possessions after her death. One described a man who randomly killed two people in a public building. The other described a depressed young man who had attempted to commit suicide in the same way that Dann did; he survived and discovered that his brain injury had cured him of his obsessive-compulsive disorder.<ref name=Day/>
One theory of Dann's rationale was that she targeted people who had "disappointed" her in some way: her ex-husband, her former sister-in-law (through the firebombing attempts at her children's schools and daycare), her ex-boyfriend and his wife, the family who was moving away, as well as former friends and babysitting clients.<ref name=MOI/>
Dann was also briefly investigated as a possible suspect in the [[Chicago Tylenol murders]], but no direct connection was found.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=mNkVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=8RIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3227,6319355&dq=tylenol+laurie+dann&hl=en|title=Tragedy in Winnetka: the answers are few|date=25 May 1988|work=Milwaukee Sentinel|accessdate=30 December 2009}}</ref>
In his book ''[[The Myth of Male Power]]'', author [[Warren Farrell]] suggested that Laurie Dann's actions were an example of women's violence against men. He claimed, erroneously, that all of Dann's victims were male, that she burned down a Young Men's Jewish Council, burned two boys in a basement, shot her own son, and alleged that she killed an eight-year old rapist.<ref>{{cite book | last =Farrell | first =Warren | title =The Myth of Male Power | publisher =Berkley Books | year =1993 | location =New York | url = | doi = | isbn = 978-0-425-18144-7 | page =216 }}</ref> [[Men's rights]] activists,<ref>{{cite web | author = Equal Parents of Canada | title = Brief to the Special Joint Committee on Child Custody and Access | publisher = | date =1998-03-31 | url =http://pages.interlog.com/~parental/committe/brief.htm#Farrell | accessdate =2007-02-16 }}</ref> academics,<ref>{{cite book | last = Fekete | first = John | title = Moral Panic:Biopolitics rising | publisher =Robert Davies Publishing | year =1994 | location = | isbn = 978-1-895854-09-1 | pages =31, 339 }}</ref> and the media have repeated Farrell's errors and conclusion.<ref>{{cite news | title =Corrections and Clarifications: Peter Raeside takes a look at the views of 'men's liberationist' Warren Farrell | work=[[The Globe and Mail]] | date =1993-09-04 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =Kay | first =Barbara | title =The last white ribbon | pages = | language = | publisher =[[National Post]] | date =2007-12-05 | url=http://www.barbarakay.ca/articles/view/101}}</ref> Farrell later issued a correction on his web site.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Myth of Male Power|url=http://warrenfarrell.org/Resources/index.html|accessdate=2011-03-22|quote= "While Laurie Dann did go into a boys' bathroom and not a girls' bathroom, and tried to kill the boys for whom she was a babysitter, the Chicago Tribune on May 21, 1988, Section 1, does list two women who were direct victims of Laurie Dann, and a mother who was an indirect victim when she tried to rescue her two sons who had been taken to a basement by Laurie Dann who immediately lit a fire in the basement. Therefore my suggestion that she was a parallel force to the celebrated University of Montreal killer who focused on women, was not accurate."}}</ref>

[[Image:Li Torê - Le taureau de Liège.jpg|thumb|upright|''Li Tore'']] '''Léon Mignon''' ([[Liège]], 9 April 1847 – [[Schaerbeek]], 30 September 1898) was a Belgian sculptor working in a [[Realism (arts)|realist]] idiom, known for his depiction of [[bull]]s.
Born at Liège, Léon Mignon completed his studies at the Académie royale des Beaux-Arts de Liège in 1871. He made his first showing at the Salon of Ghent, and obtained a fellowship from the Fondation Darchis for further study in Italy.
He set up his studio in [[Paris]] in 1876 in collaboration with [[Paul de Vigne]], then settled permanently at [[Schaerbeek]]. He won a gold medal at the [[Salon (Paris)|Paris Salon]] for his sculpture ''Li Tore'', the Bull-Tamer (''illustration'') which provoked polemics from critics for its combination of nudity with forthright realism.
''Li Tore'', set up at Liège, became the mascot of the students, who hid it in the cellars of the Académie to protect it during [[World War II]]. The bull has become an [[emblem]] for all Liège, with the city motto ''"Liège, forcer l’avenir!"'', "Liège, make the future happen!"
A bronze on a similar theme, his ''Le Dompteur de Taureaux'' (1881), which had been noticed at the retrospective exhibition of Belgian sculpture the previous year (in its plaster model), and was championed by Gustave Rolin-Jaequemyns, Minister of the Interior, stands on the Terrasses d'Avroy, Liège. Though a scarf had been added to the model to disguise the figure's nudity, the sculpture scandalised the editors of the Catholic daily, ''La Gazette de Liège.''<ref>[http://www.wittert.ulg.ac.be/expo/19e/album/173_mignon_tore.html Vers la modernité. Le XIXe siècle au Pays de Liège].</ref>
One among his ''[[animalier]]'' sculptures is to be seen at the [[Botanical Garden of Brussels]]: ''The Olive Tree, or Peace'', representing an agricultural worker with his ox. His early ''Combat de taureaux dans la campagne romaine'' is conserved in the Musée Royal des Beaux-Arts, Brussels.
Other sculptures include ''Hide-and-Seek'' and ''Lady Godiva''.
Both Schaerbeek and Liège possess a rue Léon Mignon.

{{small|([[Public relations|Diploma in Public Relations]])}} | occupation = [[Managing Director]] | years_active = 1983 — present | nationality = [[Uganda]]n | ethnicity = | citizenship = [[Uganda]] | residence = [[Kampala]], [[Uganda]] | known_for = [[Business]], [[Management]] | networth = | home_town = | title = |religion = }} '''Mathias Katamba''' is a [[Uganda]]n [[economist]], [[business executive]], [[banker]] and [[entrepreneur]]. He is the designated [[Managing Director]] and [[Chief Executive Officer]] of [[DFCU Bank]], the second-largest commercial bank in Uganda, effective January 2019.{{cite web|date=31 October 2018 |url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/Dfcu-appoints-Katamba-announces-Kisaame-exit/688334-4830474-c21sm1/index.html | title=Dfcu appoints Katamba, announces Kisaame exit | access-date=31 October 2018 |newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] | first=Dorothy |last=Nakaweesi |location=Kampala}} Before that, he was the managing director and CEO of [[Housing Finance Bank]], a [[commercial bank]], co-owned by the Ugandan government and the [[National Social Security Fund (Uganda)]], a semi-autonomous retirement pension organisation for non-government employees in Uganda.{{cite web|title=Katamba quits Housing Finance, linked to dfcu | url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/Business/Finance/Katamba-quits-Housing-Finance-dfcu-/688608-4826600-klc7c3/index.html |date=29 October 2018 |access-date=31 October 2018 |newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] |first=Dorothy |last=Nakaweesi |location=Kampala}} ==Background== He was born in [[Central Region, Uganda|Central Uganda]]. ==Education== Katamba had his early education in Uganda. He then entered the [[University of Greenwich]], in England, graduating with the degree of [[Economics|Bachelor of Arts in Economics]]. His degree of [[Financial Management|Master of Science in Financial Management]] was obtained from the [[University of East London]], also in the [[UK]]. He also holds the postgraduate [[Public relations|Diploma in Public Relations]], awarded by the [[Chartered Institute of Public Relations]] (CIPR), another UK institution. Over the years, he has attended advanced leadership courses from several institutions, including [[Harvard Kennedy School]] and [[Wharton Business School]].{{cite web|title=Progression Capital Africa: Mathias Katamba| url=http://www.progressioncapitalafrica.com/mathias.html|accessdate=24 April 2014| publisher=Progression Capital Africa}} ==Work experience== Even while still in school, Katamba exhibited entrepreneurial skill, by starting a business during the break between middle and high school.{{cite web| url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/13/689257|title=My First Job: Mathias Katamba|publisher=[[New Vision]]|date=26 July 2009|first=Archive|last=Newvision| accessdate=24 April 2014}} For the past 10 to 15 years, he has been intimately associated with [[Uganda]]'s banking industry. He is credited with: *The transformation of [[Pride Microfinance Limited]] from a [[Non-Government Organization]] (NGO), into a [[Banking in Uganda|Tier III]] Deposit-taking microfinance financial institution (MFI). * The transformation of '''Uganda Finance Trust Limited''', from a [[Banking in Uganda|Tier III]], Deposit-Taking MFI into a [[Banking in Uganda|Tier 1]] commercial bank, [[Finance Trust Bank]].{{cite web|title=When Finance Trust Made The Turn of Its Life|url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/Business/Prosper/-/688616/943460/-/iyj35uz/-/index.html|first=Fredrick|last=Masiga|date=22 June 2010| accessdate=24 April 2014|publisher=[[Daily Monitor]]}} In 2011, following 5 years at the helm of [[Uganda Finance Trust Limited]],{{cite web|title=Katamba Says Adieus to Banking|date=20 September 2011| url=http://www.archives.in2eastafrica.net/katamba-says-adieus-to-banking/| first=Reporter|last=In2EastAfrica|accessdate=24 April 2014|publisher=[[Daily Monitor]] via In2EastAfrica.net}} he took a beak from commercial banking until he was appointed to is present position in April 2014. Prior to his present position, he was Managing Partner and co-founder of ''Progression Capital Africa (PCA)'', a US$40 million private equity fund based in [[Mauritius]]. Before joining Finance Trust Bank, he worked at some national and regional, notable financial institutions; including [[Orient Bank]], [[PostBank Uganda|Postbank]] and [[Barclays Africa]].{{cite web|title=Mathias Katamba Appointed New Housing Finance Bank Managing Director|url=http://www.sbreview.net/index.php/terms-of-use-and-privacy-policy/smes/components/content-component/article-categories/793-mathias-katamba-appointed-new-housing-finance-bank-managing-director| first=Editor|last=By|date=24 March 2014|accessdate=24 April 2014|publisher=Summit Business Review}} ==See also== * [[National Social Security Fund (Uganda)|NSSF (Uganda)]] * [[List of banks in Uganda]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.nssfug.org/ Website of National Social Security Fund (Uganda)] {{DEFAULTSORT:Katamba, Mathias}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Ganda people]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Greenwich]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of East London]] [[Category:Ugandan bankers]] [[Category:Ugandan economists]] [[Category:Ugandan businesspeople]] [[Category:Chief executive officers]] [[Category:Ugandan business executives]]

'''Me Me Lai''' (born 3 November 1951), sometimes billed as '''Me Me Lay''', is a Burmese-British actress and television host who worked mainly in British and Italian films, most notably in the horror genre.
==Life== She was born on the night of 3 November 1951 in [[Burma]] to a Burmese mother and an English father. She moved to [[England]] in her teens, where she soon started her acting career, at first in television series like ''[[Paul Temple]]'' and ''[[Jason King (TV series)|Jason King]]''. Soon, she made the transition to acting in movies, starting with the 1971 Mike Raven horror movie ''[[Crucible of Terror]]'', soon followed by the 1972 sex comedy ''[[Au Pair Girls]]'' directed by [[Val Guest]].
Lai came into her own during the era of [[Cannibal film|Italian cannibal films]], playing lead roles in two genre-defining movies: ''[[Man from Deep River]]'' (1972) by [[Umberto Lenzi]], and ''[[Ultimo Mondo Cannibale|Last Cannibal World]]'' (1977) by [[Ruggero Deodato]]. Lai appears nude throughout most of the film, which includes an explicit shot of her [[vulva]]. Additionally, she also had a part in ''[[Eaten Alive!]]'' (1980), again by [[Umberto Lenzi]], in which one of her scenes from ''Last Cannibal World'' was re-used. Outside the cannibal genre, she had a brief role as a Chinese brothel girl in [[Blake Edwards]]'s 1978 comedy ''[[Revenge of the Pink Panther]]''.
Me Me Lai also was co-hostess of British game shows ''[[The Golden Shot]]'' and ''[[Sale of the Century (UK game show)|Sale of the Century]]'', and appeared on the 1970s [[Yorkshire Television]] programme ''Origami'', with [[Robert Harbin]].
Her last movie was [[Lars von Trier]]'s ''[[The Element of Crime]]'' in 1984.
==Filmography== * ''[[She'll Follow You Anywhere]]'' (1971) - Bride * ''[[Crucible of Terror]]'' (1971) - Chi-San * ''[[Au Pair Girls]]'' (1972) - Nan Lee * ''[[The Man from Deep River]]'' (1972) - Marayå * ''[[Ultimo Mondo Cannibale|Last Cannibal World]]'' (1977) - Pulan * ''[[Revenge of the Pink Panther]]'' (1978) - Chinese Lady of Easy Virtue * ''[[Licensed to Love and Kill]]'' (1979) - Female Madam Wang * ''[[Eaten Alive!]]'' (1980) - Mowara * ''[[The Element of Crime]]'' (1984) - Kim
===Television appearances=== * ''[[Paul Temple]]'' (1970) - Masseuse * ''[[Hine (TV series)|Hine]]'' (1971) - Miss Mini * ''[[Spearhead (TV series)|Spearhead]]'' (1981) - Mimi * ''[[The Optimist (TV series)|The Optimist]]'' (1983) - Karate Girl

'''Meryl McMaster''' is a Canadian photographer whose best-known work explores her Indigenous heritage.
==Work== Her first major series ''Ancestral'' from 2008 ''"''appropriates ethnographic portraits, which she then projects onto her photographic subjects: herself and her father,"<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://reconstruction.eserver.org/Issues/151/Walker.shtml|title=Representing the Self through Ancestry: Meryl McMaster's Ancestral Portraits|last=Walker|first=Ellyn|date=2015|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> noted artist and curator [[Gerald McMaster]].
==Awards== McMaster trained at the Ontario College of Art and Design University where she won the OCADU Medal. Other professional recognition includes the REVEAL Indigenous Art Award, the Charles Pachter Prize for Emerging Artists, the Canon Canada Prize, the Eiteljorg Contemporary Art Fellowship, and the Doris McCarthy Scholarship. McMaster was long-listed for the 2016 Sobey Art award.<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title="Ottawa Visual Artist McMaster on Long List for $50,000 Art Prize"|last=|first=|date=April 14, 2016|work=Ottawa Citizen|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> In March 2018, she was named one of three inaugural winners of the New Generation Photography Award, which supports the careers of young artists working in lens-based media.<ref>{{cite web|title=New Generation Photography Award {{!}} Scotiabank|url=http://www.scotiabank.com/ca/en/0,,11850,00.html|website=www.scotiabank.com|accessdate=19 April 2018|language=en}}</ref>
==Exhibitions== McMaster's work was the subject of a solo survey exhibition ''Confluence'' organized by Carleton University Art Gallery (CUAG) and curated by Heather Anderson.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books/about/Meryl_McMaster.html?id=4KwTDAEACAAJ&redir_esc=y&hl=en|title=Meryl McMaster: Confluence|last=Anderson|first=Heather|last2=Moser|first2=Gabrielle|last3=turions|first3=cheyanne|date=2016|publisher=Carleton University Art Gallery|isbn=9780770905958|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cuag.ca/index.php/exhibitions/331|title=Carleton University Art Gallery|website=www.cuag.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-03-24}}</ref> The exhibition was on view at CUAG from May 2 - August 28, 2016 and travelled to five other venues including the Richmond Art Gallery (RAG), the [[Thunder Bay Art Gallery]], Lethbridge University Art Gallery, and [[The Rooms, Newfoundland and Labrador|The Rooms]].<ref name="carleton">{{cite book|last1=Carleton University Art Gallery|title=Meryl McMaster: Confluence|date=2016|publisher=Carleton University Art Gallery|location=Ottawa|isbn=9780770905958}}</ref> Her work was prominently featured in ''Every. Now. Then: Reframing Nationhood'' at the Art Gallery of Ontario during the summer of 2017.<ref name="AGO">{{cite book|last1=Hunter|first1=Andrew|title=Every.Now.Then: Reframing Nationhood|date=2017|publisher=Art Gallery of Ontario|location=Toronto|isbn=9781894243957}}</ref> Her work has been acquired by various public collections within Canada and the United States, including the [[Canadian Museum of History]], the [[Art Gallery of Ontario]], the Canada Council Art Bank, the [[Eiteljorg Museum of American Indians and Western Art|Eiteljorg Museum]], the [[National Museum of the American Indian]], the [[Ottawa Art Gallery]], the [[Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art]] and [[Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada]].
=== Group Exhibitions === * ''Embodiment,'' [[Museum London]], December 23, 2017 - April 1, 2018 * ''Native Portraiture: Power and Perception'', [[Tacoma Art Museum]], February 10, 2018- February 10, 2019 * ''Niigaanikwewag'', [[Art Gallery of Mississauga]], February 22 - April 15, 2018 * ''Recover All That Is Ours,'' Campbell River Art Gallery, March 1 - April 25, 2018 * ''ÀDISÒKÀMAGAN/NOUS CONNAÎTRE UN PEU NOUS-MÊMES/ WE’LL ALL BECOME STORIES'', [[Ottawa Art Gallery]], April 28 - September 16, 2018 * ''Identity (Material Self: Performing the Other Within)'', MOCCA Toronto, part of CONTACT Photography Festival, 2014
=== Solo Exhibitions === * ''Confluence,'' University of Lethbridge Art Gallery, January 18 - March 15, 2018 * ''In Between Worlds,'' [[Montreal Museum of Fine Arts]], September 8 - December 3, 2017 * ''The Fifth World,'' [[Mendel Art Gallery]], April 3 - June 7, 2015 * ''Second Self,'' Latcham Gallery, 2011
==Collections== McMaster's work is in the collections of the Art Gallery of Ontario,the [[Canadian Museum of History]], the Canada Council Art Bank, the Eiteljorg Museum, the [[National Museum of the American Indian]], the [[Ottawa Art Gallery]], the [[Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art]] and [[Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada]].
== Further reading == * Walker, Ellyn, ''The Fifth World,'' ''RACAR: revue d'art canadienne / Canadian Art Review'' Vol. 42, No. 2, Continuities Between Eras Indigenous Art Histories / Continuité entre les époques Histoires des arts autochtones (2017), pp. 124–126. * Jurjans, Katrina, "ʻMaterial Self: Performing the Other Withinʼ Speaks of the Liminal Space Between Physical, Mental, and Cultural States", ''Opus Magazine'' * ''Meryl McMaster: Confluence,'' exhibition catalogue with essays by Heather Anderson, Gabrielle Moser, and cheyanne turions, (Ottawa: Carleton University Art Gallery, 2016) {{ISBN|0770905951}}, 9780770905958 * ''Every. Now. Then. Reframing Nationhood,'' exhibition catalogue edited by Andrew Hunter, Toronto: Art Gallery of Ontario, 2017. {{ISBN|9781894243957}}

Henri Dubief (1925-1925) | birth_date = 1869 | birth_place = [[Thenia]], [[Alger (department)|Algiers department]], [[Kabylie]], [[Algeria]]. | death_date = 1959 | death_place = Thenia, Algiers department, Kabylie, Algeria. | spouse = Fatma Cherifi
Khdaouedj Tafat Bouzid
Yamna Afiri. | party = | religion = [[Islam]], [[Sunni Islam|Sunnism]], [[Maliki]]sm. | signature = | signature_alt = }} '''Mohamed Seghir Boushaki''' ({{IPA-ar|محمد الصغير بوسحاقي|lang}}), (born {{date|1869-11-27}} in [[Thénia]], [[Boumerdès Province]], [[Kabylie]], [[Algeria]]; died 1959 in Thenia, Algeria) was an Algerian [[Berbers|Berber]] [[politician]] after the [[French conquest of Algeria]].{{cite web|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6466914t|title=Journal officiel de la République française. Débats parlementaires. Sénat : compte rendu in-extenso|date=19 May 1921|website=Gallica.bnf.fr}} == Presentation == Mohamed Seghir Boushaki was born in 1869 in the village of "Thala Oufella" ({{lang-kab|ⵟⵀⴰⵍⴰ Oⵓⴼⴻⵍⵍⴰ}}) called "Soumâa" (called {{lang-ar|الصومعة}}) because of the ruins of [[:fr:Benian ntâa Soumâa|Benian ntâa Soumâa]].{{cite web|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b72002410|title=Carte de l'Algérie divisée par tribus / par MM. E. Carette et Auguste Warnier ; Membres de la Commission Scientifique de l'Algérie|first1=Ernest (1808-1890) Fonction indéterminée|last1=Carette|first2=Auguste (1810-1875) Fonction indéterminée|last2=Warnier|date=1 January 1846|website=Gallica.bnf.fr}} This ancient Berber citadel of Benian ntâa Soumâa was built by King Nubel when the region of [[Thenia]] was the capital of [[Kabylie]] and [[:fr:Mitidja|Mitidja]] in [[North Africa during Antiquity]].{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/Tarikh.Al-jazair.Al-am/kitab#page/n541/mode/2up |title=كتاب تاريخ الجزائر العام للشيخ عبد الرحمان الجيلالي |website=Archive.org |date=2010-07-21 |accessdate=2017-02-28}} The lands ranging from "Oued Boumerdès" and "Oued Mghaldène" in the west to "[[:fr:Oued Isser|Oued Isser]]" to the east of the village "Thala Oufella (Soumâa)" belonged to the tribe of "Aïth Aïcha" to which Mohamed belonged Seghir Boushaki before the [[French conquest of Algeria]].{{cite web|url=https://www.europeana.eu/portal/fr/record/9200365/BibliographicResource_1000054848897.html |title=Carte de l'Algérie divisée par tribus / par MM. E. Carette et Auguste Warnier ; Membres de la Commission Scientifique de l'Algérie | Carette, Ernest (1808-1890) and Warnier, Auguste (1810-1875) - Europeana |website=Europeana.eu |date= |accessdate=2017-02-28}} Just two years after the birth of Mohamecd Seghir, all of Kabylie rallied to the "[[Mokrani Revolt]]" on March 16, 1871 to expel the [[Troupes coloniales|French colonial troops]] from the plain and the heights.{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/RepertoireAlphabtiqueDesTribusEtDouarsDeLalgrie1879/N5860320_PDF_1_-1DM#page/n93/mode/2up|title=Repertoire Alphabétique des tribus et douars de l'Algérie 1879|publisher=|accessdate=25 February 2017}} After the defeat of the [[Rahmaniyya|brotherhood of the Rahmaniya]] in this [[Kabyle people|Kabyle]] uprising, the tribal leaders were deported to [[New Caledonia]], among them "Ahmed Ben Belkacem" the chief of the "Aïth Aïcha" who was close to Mohamed Seghir.{{cite web|url=http://www.bordj.info/spip.php?article1467|title=Liste des déportés algériens en Nouvelle-Calédonie, 1867-1895 - Bordj info|first=|last=R.B.|website=Bordj.info}} "Ahmed Ben Belkacem", born in 1837 and son of Ahmed, was deported under the "Number 18744".{{cite web|url=http://www.bordj.info/IMG/jpg/Docu2.jpg |format=JPG |title=318 List |website=Bordj.info |accessdate=2017-02-28}} == Childhood == Mohamed Seghir Boushaki grew up in a large family where his elder brother "Ali Boushaki" (1855 - 1965) was his model.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.dz/books?id=OyvgS7tbAxQC&pg=PA40#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Imperial Identities: Stereotyping, Prejudice and Race in Colonial Algeria|first=Patricia M. E.|last=Lorcin|date=16 July 1999|publisher=I.B.Tauris|via=Google Books}} Their father "Mohamed Boushaki" (1834-1889), known as "Moh Ouaâli" ({{lang-ar|موح واعلي}}}, was one of the survivors of the French expedition against the town of [[Dellys]] from May 7 to May 17, 1844 and which had decimated dozens of villages of Kabylie, including "Thala Oufella (Soumâa)".{{cite web|url=https://books.google.dz/books?id=mUBYtw9hRNMC&pg=PA189#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=saint arnaud marechal de france|first=Louis de|last=Charbonnières|date=1 January 1960|publisher=Nouvelles Editions Latines|via=Google Books}} Thus, Mohamed Seghir's grandfather, "Ali Boushaki" (1823 - 1844) who was married to "Khdaouedj Dekkiche" of [[Souk El-Had]], was one of the Kabyle [[martyr]]s during the fighting against the French Conquest of Kabylie, leaving his son "Moh Ouaâli" orphaned.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.dz/books?id=sL3Tvgrs0DEC&pg=PA56#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Une grande figure, Saint-Arnaud maréchal de France|first=Louis de|last=Charbonnières|date=1 January 1960|publisher=Nouvelles Editions Latines|via=Google Books}} The massacre of [[Jacques Leroy de Saint Arnaud]] completed and the village of "Thala Oufella (Soumâa)" devastated, the widowed grandmother "Khdaouedj Dekkiche" could only preserve her child "Moh Ouaâli" taking him with her to her parents in the village of "Igueraïchene" {{lang-ar|إيقرعيشن}} at [[Souk El-Had]] until her puberty and the reconstruction of his native village in "Aïth Aïcha" tribe.{{cite web|url=http://www.cerclealgerianiste.fr/index.php/archives/encyclopedie-algerianiste/histoire/histoire-militaire/generalites-militaires/232-le-marechal-de-saint-arnaud-l-algerie-et-la-france|title=Le maréchal de Saint-Arnaud, l'Algérie et la France - Géneralités militaires|website=Cerclealgerianiste.fr|accessdate=2017-02-28}} After his return to "Thala Oufella" in 1852 at the age of 18, "Mohamed Boushaki (Moh Ouaâli)" married his cousin "Aïcha Ishak-Boushaki" who bore "Ali Boushaki" In 1855 and then of "Mohamed Seghir Boushaki" in 1869.{{cite web|url=http://encyclopedie-afn.org/24_OFFICIERS_DE_L%E2%80%99ARM%C3%89E_BELGE|title=24 OFFICIERS DE L’ARMÉE BELGE - 1830-1962 ENCYCLOPEDIE de L'AFN|website=Encyclopedia-afn.org|accessdate=2017-02-28}} == Education == Mohamed Seghir Boushaki began his [[Islamic studies|coranic studies]] in the reconstructed [[Zawiya (institution)|Zawiya]] in the village of "Thala Oufella" near the [[mausoleum]] of his great-grandfather "[[:fr:Sidi Boushaki|Sidi Boushaki]]" (1394-1853) who was one of the [[Berbers|berber]] [[scholar]]s and [[theologian]]s before the arrival of the [[Ottoman Algeria|Ottomans]] in [[Algeria]].{{cite web|url=http://jeanyvesthorrignac.fr/wa_files/INFO_20614_20MENERVILLE.pdf |format=PDF |title=Menerville |website=Jeanyvesthorrignac.fr |accessdate=2017-02-28}} Meanwhile, the plain of [[Mountain pass]] of "Aïth Aïcha" tribe, north of "Thala Oufella" village, was colonized as early as 1871 by [[Alsace|Alsatian]] and [[Lorraine]] farmers who came from [[France]] to found the town of [[Ménerville]]{{cite web|url=http://anom.archivesnationales.culture.gouv.fr/geo.php?lieu=Bellefontaine%20(Alg%C3%A9rie) |title=Recherche géographique |website=Anom.archivesnationales.culture.gouv.fr |date= |accessdate=2017-02-28}}{{,}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.mekerra.fr/images/alsaciens/alsaciens-lorrains-emigration.pdf |format=PDF |title=Alsaciens - Lorrains en Algerie |website=Mekerra.fr |accessdate=2017-02-28}} Thus, from 1874 to 1881, Mohamed Seghir grazed the herds of the village with his brother Ali and his cousins while continuing his [[Islam|Muslim teaching]] in his native village.{{cite web|url=https://www.departement06.fr/documents/Import/decouvrir-les-am/rr191-indigenes.pdf |format=PDF |title=INDIGENES ET COLONISATION DANS LA PRESSE NICOISE DE LA BELLE EPOQUE |website=Departement06.fr |accessdate=2017-02-28}} After the creation of the [[:fr:Bureaux arabes|Arab offices]] in Kabylie and the establishment of the [[:fr:État civil français en Algérie|registers of the civil state]] by the governor [[Louis Tirman]], new [[patronym]]s were attributed to the families of "Aïth Aïcha" tribe, and [[identity papers]] were handed to the villagers, allowing Mohamed Seghir Boushaki to continue his studies at [[Tizi Ouzou]] in the "Zawiya of Sheikh Mohand Ameziane" where he became acquainted with many of the futur notables of the [[Great Kabylie]]{{cite journal|url=http://www.cairn.info/resume.php?ID_ARTICLE=RHJ_016_0093|title=Le statut des musulmans en Algérie coloniale|first=Patrick|last=Weil|date=22 February 2017|publisher=|issue=16|pages=93–109|via=Cairn.info}}{{,}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.seddouk-ouffella.com/documents/article/la-tarika-rahmania|title=Seddouk Ouffella, village de Cheikh Ahaddad|website=Seddouk-ouffella.com|accessdate=2017-02-28}} The deep [[recitation]]s and [[exegesis]] received by Mohamed Seghir in the Tizi Ouzou Zawiyas, as well as the measured attendance of French settlers, allowed him to anchor in the [[Arab-Berber|Berber-Arab culture]] on the one hand, and to open up on the accomplished fact of the European presence in Kabylie of another coast, thus endowing him with the major [[trilingual]] asset for the pursuit of his political and social journey. == Work == [[File:Confédérations et tribus de la Grande Kabylie (Tamawya Taqbaylit) Algérie.jpg|thumb|[[:fr:Tribus de la Kabylie|Kabylie tribes]]]] After ten years of [[Islamic studies]] in Great Kabylie, Mohamed Seghir Boushaki settled in his village "Thala Oufella (Soumâa)" in 1891 and began to work in [[agriculture]] and [[commerce]].{{cite web|author=Kouider Djouab |url=http://www.djazairess.com/fr/lnr/244086 |title=La ville "lieu du Soldat", une histoire méconnue |website=Djazairess.com |date= |accessdate=2017-02-28}} He specializes in [[Ceratonia siliqua|carob tree]] [[arboriculture]] by weaving a professional [[carob bean]] harvesting network for sale in the state and for processing into [[locust bean gum]] and [[carob bean]] [[molasses]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20170222082624/http://dspace.univ-tlemcen.dz/bitstream/112/304/1/Etude-de-la-valeur-nutritive-de-la-caroube-de-differentes-varietes-Algeriennes.pdf] He soon gained notable profits which allowed him to rent a house in the [[French Colonial|French colony]] of "[[Thénia|Ménerville (Thénia)]]" bordering "Oued Arbia" in which he married in 1898 at the age of 29 with "Fatma Cherifi" issue of a rich family residing in "[[Sidi Daoud]]" along "[[:fr:Sebaou|Oued Sebaou]]".{{cite web|url=https://www.memoria.dz/jui-2012/figures-historiques/17-ans-lutte-l-emir-visit-trois-fois-la-kabylie |title=En 17 ans de lutte, l’Emir a visité trois fois la Kabylie |language=fr |website=Memoria.dz |date= |accessdate=2017-02-28}} Mohamed Seghir assiduously transformed the mesh of collection of [[carob bean]] in Kabylie into a network of inter-village alliances by marriage in the former [[Algiers Department]] regrouping the current wilayas of [[Algiers]], [[Boumerdes]], [[Tizi Ouzou]], [[Bouira]], [[Blida]] and [[Tipaza]].{{cite web|url=http://www.elmoudjahid.com/fr/mobile/detail-article/id/15651 |title=Histoire : Sidi M'hamed Bou Qobrine le saint aux deux tombeaux |website=Elmoudjahid.com |date=2011-08-18 |accessdate=2017-02-28}} While remaining a fervent supporter of the [[Sufism|Sufi]] [[Tariqa]] of the [[Rahmaniyya]], he frequently frequented the two [[mosque]]s of [[Sidi M'hamed Bou Qobrine]] in [[Bounouh]] ([[Boghni]]) and [[Mohamed Belouizdad|Hamma]] (Algiers), and as soon as he had his first boy in 1907, he named him "M'Hamed Boushaki" in memory of the kabyle [[theologian]] "M'Hamed Ben Abderrahmane El Azhari".{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.djazairess.com/fr/horizons/108610 |title=Sidi M'hamed Bou Qobrine |website=Djazairess.com |date= |accessdate=2017-02-28}} His intense commercial activity allowed him to attend the weekly markets throughout Kabylie where trading transactions and marriage agreements were negotiated.{{cite web|url=http://www.histoire-en-questions.fr/guerre%20algerie/deux%20peuples-marche%20kabyle%20.html |title=Le marché en Kabylie pendant la guerre d'algerie |website=Histoire-en-questions.fr |date= |accessdate=2017-02-28}} == World War I == [[File:Plan de Thénia des Béni Aïcha dans le territoire des Khachna à l'est d'Alger.jpg|thumb|[[Thénia]] in Khachna Region]] Mohamed Seghir Boushaki lost his first wife "Fatma Cherifi" in 1914 shortly before the outbreak of the [[World War I]] when he had reached the age of 45, leaving him several orphaned children to his charge and responsibility.{{cite web|url=https://sourcesdelagrandeguerre.fr/?p=3240|title=Retrouver un soldat algérien dans les archives françaises|date=28 May 2014|publisher=|accessdate=25 February 2017}} He then quickly remarried with "Khdaouedj Tafat Bouzid" from the village "Aïth Thafath" in [[Chabet el Ameur]], who took care of the orphans and then bore him several other new toddlers.{{cite web|url=http://lerhumel.free.fr/Ebooks/Description%20de%20l'Alg%E9rie%201847.pdf |format=PDF |title=Description et Division De L'Algerie |website=Lerhumel.free.fr |accessdate=2017-02-28}} The [[French colonial empire|colonial French]], surrounded by the German troops and [[Stormtrooper]], appealed to the young Algerians in the ranks of its army in the metropolis with the promise to give them in exchange more rights citizens in Algeria and why not the total independence.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.dz/books?id=zK-hAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA360#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Chroniques tizi-ouziennes et regionales, 1914-1928|first=Jean de|last=Crescenzo|date=1 January 2010|publisher=Lulu.com|via=Google Books}} Several young kabyles of the Khachna and Great Kabylie were recruited on French front in Europe, among them close relatives of Mohamed Seghir.{{cite web|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k63719824 |title=La Tranchée : organe officiel de l'Amicale des mutilés du dépt. d'Alger et de la Fédération départementale des victimes de la guerre | 1937-12 |language=fr |website=Gallica.bnf.fr |date= |accessdate=2017-02-28}} One of these kabyle soldiers is the son of his brother "Ali Boushaki", his nephew "Abderrahmane Boushaki" who was a [[corporal]] in the "[[:fr:1er régiment de tirailleurs algériens|1st regiment of Algerian sharpshooters]]" from 1914 to 1918.{{cite web|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6475945b |title=Journal officiel de la République française. Lois et décrets | 1923-06-21 |language=fr |website=Gallica.bnf.fr |date= |accessdate=2017-02-28}} The distinctions and decorations after the return of the nephew "Abderrahmane Boushaki" mutilated from France gave him as well as his family and his tribe a growing notoriety in the French colonial administration in Algeria after 1918.{{cite web|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6586446v |title=L'Algérie mutilée : organe de défense des mutilés, réformés, blessés, anciens combattants, veuves, orphelins, ascendants de la Grande Guerre : bulletin officiel de l'Amicale des mutilés du département d'Alger | 1925-04-01 |language=fr |website=Gallica.bnf.fr |date= |accessdate=2017-02-28}} == Militant path == [[File:ELD - Tirailleurs algériens blessés installés dans les autobus d'ambulance.JPG|thumb|[[:fr:1er régiment de tirailleurs algériens|1st regiment of Algerian sharpshooters]]]] Mohamed Seghir Boushaki began his [[militant]] [[career]] in [[politics]] as part of the [[Assimilation (French colonialism)|French colonial administration]] from 1918 onwards{{cite journal|url=http://insaniyat.revues.org/13001?lang=ar|title=Tizi-Ouzou : historique d’un col et son urbanisation|first=Saïd|last=Doumane|date=31 December 2011|publisher=|issue=54|pages=13–29|via=insaniyat.revues.org|doi=10.4000/insaniyat.13001}}{{,}}.{{cite web|url=http://perso.netopi.fr/lkeller/palestro/souvenirs/archives/cfa.htm |title=Arrivée du train à Palestro |website=Perso.netopi.fr |date= |accessdate=2017-02-28}} Mohamed Seghir's [[political strategy]] was not to move to Algiers to reside there because comfortable transport was available by the [[railway line]] connecting Tizi Ouzou to Algiers which had been completed in 1888 after that linking Bouira to Algiers had previously been inaugurated in 1886{{cite web|url=http://www.cerclealgerianiste.fr/index.php/archives/encyclopedie-algerianiste/territoire/villes-et-villages-d-algerie/algerois/97-tizi-ouzou |title=Tizi-Ouzou | Algérois |website=Cerclealgerianiste.fr |date= |accessdate=2017-02-28}}{{,}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.piedsnoirs-aujourdhui.com/reali9.html |title=Les Chemins De Fer |website=Piedsnoirs-aujourdhui.com |date= |accessdate=2017-02-28}} Aged 49 at the end of the [[World War I]] with nearly ten children in his charge and responsibility, Mohamed Seghir could not venture to live in the Algiers [[Macrocosm and microcosm|microcosm]] by taking the risk of forgetting himself and dissolving in the details of the colonial city life far from the expectations of the [[Kabylian]] villagers perched on the heights of their mountains and contemplating the European settlers who robbed them of their arable land and their pastures. The new privileged status of his nephew "Abderrahmane Boushaki" as a [[veteran]] allowed the "[[Igawawen|Arch of Aïth Aïcha]]" to rebuild the "Zawiya of [[:fr:Sidi Boushaki|Sidi Boushaki]]", destroyed in 1844 at the village of "Thala Oufella (Soumâa)", with a [[prayer]] room, a [[Madrasa|Coranic school]], a [[basement]] with [[Water well|well]], and a house for the [[Hafiz (Quran)|Quran teacher]]. A French [[architect]] had designed the Zawiya of the village in a [[Berbers|Berber]]-[[Moorish]] style{{cite journal|url=http://www.persee.fr/doc/medit_0025-8296_1964_num_5_2_1118|title=Les hommes et leurs activités dans la plaine des Issers|first=Yves|last=Sarthe|publisher=|volume=5|issue=2|pages=133–145|doi=10.3406/medit.1964.1118}}{{,}}.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.dz/books?id=L-AJ174uPtwC&pg=PA79#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Alsaciens et Lorrains en Algérie: histoire d'une migration, 1830-1914|first=Fabienne|last=Fischer|date=1 January 1999|publisher=SERRE EDITEUR|via=Google Books}} The arrival of the rich baker "Mohamed Naïth Saïdi" from the region of [[Larbaâ Nath Irathen]] to settle in the colonial town of [[Thenia|Ménerville (Thenia)]] was a decisive turning point in the area of "Aïth Aïcha", because he married a cousin of Mohamed Seghir Boushaki, And built an entire district in a [[Moorish]] style in the center of which a first mosque was built in [[Lower Kabylia]] after [[French colonization]]. It followed the successive arrival of many Kabylian families from [[Djurdjura]], such as "Redjouani" and "Djennadi", to settle among the European settlers in [[Thenia|Ménerville (Thenia)]] and thus promote the emergence of a nationalist consciousness halfway between Tizi Ouzou and Algiers.{{cite web|url=http://www.umc.edu.dz/images/N_65-66-MEYNIER.pdf |format=PDF |title=L’Algérie et les Algériens sous le système colonial. Approche historico historiographique |author=Gilbert Meynier |website=Umc.edu.dz |accessdate=2017-02-28}} == Jonnart Law == [[File:Charles Jonnart 1918.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Charles Jonnart]]]] The consecration of the process of reappropriation of public, institutional and [[social space]] in Kabylie by the original inhabitants found a legal breach through the [[Jonnart Law]] proclaimed on [[4 February]] 1919 by [[Charles Jonnart]] and allowing the Algerians to elect and be elected to the [[People's Municipal Assembly|municipal assemblies]]{{cite web|url=http://www.algeria.com/forums/history-histoire/22056-les-premi%E8res-%E9lections-alg%E9riennes-1919-1925-a.html |title=Les premières élections algériennes (1919-1925) |website=Algeria.com |date=2007-11-30 |accessdate=2017-02-28}}{{,}}.{{cite web|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k75791317 |title=L'Echo d'Alger : journal républicain du matin | 1919-12-02 |language=fr |website=Gallica.bnf.fr |date=1919-12-02 |accessdate=2017-02-28}} Thus, the first post-war [[municipal elections]] took place in Algeria on November 30, 1919, in which Mohamed Seghir Boushaki and [[:fr:Khaled el-Hassani ben el-Hachemi|Emir Khaled]] participated{{cite web|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k7579128r |title=L'Echo d'Alger : journal républicain du matin | 1919-11-29 |language=fr |website=Gallica.bnf.fr |date=1919-11-29 |accessdate=2017-02-28}}{{,}}.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.dz/books?id=zK-hAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA107#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Chroniques tizi-ouziennes et regionales, 1914-1928|first=Jean de|last=Crescenzo|date=1 January 2010|publisher=Lulu.com|via=Google Books}} The struggle of Mohamed Seghir after 1919 revolves around the struggle in [[:fr:Statut juridique des indigènes d'Algérie|colonial legality]], while remaining hostile to naturalization but also fighting for equality between native Algerians and French colonizers in a very difficult context{{cite journal|url=http://www.persee.fr/doc/remmm_0035-1474_1966_num_2_1_929|title=Enquête sur les origines du nationalisme algérien. L'émir Khaled, petit-fils d'Abd El-Kader, fut-il le premier nationaliste algérien ?|first=Charles-Robert|last=Ageron|publisher=|volume=2|issue=1|pages=9–49|doi=10.3406/remmm.1966.929}}{{,}}.{{cite web|url=http://kabyleuniversel.com/2011/06/01/lemir-khaled-et-la-naissance-du-mouvement-nationaliste-algerien/ |title=L’Emir Khaled et la naissance du mouvement nationaliste algérien |website=KabyleUniversel.com |date= |accessdate=2017-02-28}} The election of [[Mayor]] of [[Thenia|Ménerville (Thenia)]] and his deputies took place on Sunday, December 7, 1919, in the elections of the Municipality where "César Boniface" as [[mayor]], and his deputies "Auguste Schneider", "Georges Egrot" And "Samuel Juvin", were elected all with 23 votes out of a total of 24 voters{{cite web|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k75791406 |title=L'Echo d'Alger : journal républicain du matin | 1919-12-11 |language=fr |website=Gallica.bnf.fr |date=1919-12-11 |accessdate=2017-02-28}}{{,}}.{{cite web|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k7579130t |title=L'Echo d'Alger : journal républicain du matin | 1919-12-01 |language=fr |website=Gallica.bnf.fr |date=1919-12-01 |accessdate=2017-02-28}} Mohamed Seghir was elected as [[City council (France)|city councilor]] representing the [[:fr:Douar|Douar]] of "Thala Oufella (Soumâa)" in the Municipality of Ménerville within the "César Boniface" team for 5 years from 1920 to 1925. Several other [[:fr:Conseillers municipaux en Algérie|Algerian councilors]] sat at the Ménerville Town Hall next to Mohamed Seghir and represented their respective Douars surrounding the colonial city. == Entryism == [[File:الأمير خالد.jpg|thumb|[[:fr:Emir Khaled|Emir Khaled]]]] As early as 1920, Mohamed Seghir Boushaki with [[:fr:Emir Khaled|Emir Khaled]] integrated the political strategy of [[wikt:entrenchment|entrenchment]] into the administrative apparatus and the colonial cultural sphere, equipped with the elective immunity that enabled them to travel the [[Department of Algiers]] without hindrance to meet the nationalist elites of all edges. This electoral [[entablature]] enabled Mohamed Seghir to benefit from several privileges of the position of municipal councilor such as obtaining a concession to operate a farmland of 70 hectares located south-east of the city of Merverville on the flank of the village "Thala Oufella (Soumâa)" and a short distance from [[:fr:Oued Isser|Oued Isser]]. The "Emir Khaled" took advantage of this [[entryism]] and [[Entryism|infiltration]] to visit also the villages and villages of the Department of Algiers, as his grandfather the [[Emir Abdelkader]] also used to preach more rights to Algerians than those granted by the [[Jonnart Law]]. An abundant political activity of Mohamed Seghir with the Emir Khaled continued until the exile of this last in 1923 by the colonial administration towards [[Egypt]] to try to temper the emancipatory impetus Algerian and Kabyle. In 1924, Mohamed Seghir obtained a permit to open a "Moorish Café" in downtown Ménerville overlooking the bustling Avenue de la Republique, where his son M'Hamed Boushaki (1907-1995) went To work with his brothers until the outbreak of the [[Algerian War|Algerian independence revolution]] in November 1, 1954.{{cite web|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k57765481 |title=La Tafna. Journal de l'arrondissement de Tlemcen | 1907-09-11 |language=fr |website=Gallica.bnf.fr |date= |accessdate=2017-02-28}} Little by little Mohamed Seghir became part of the colonial political game and began to position his cousins and relatives in administrative and service jobs in the "Canton of Alma (Boudouaou)" and in Algiers in order to reinforce the [[Kabyle people|Kabyle]] presence in the capital of their despoiled ancestral land. == Sufism == [[File:Bounouh CheikhBenAbderrahmane 22Mar.png|thumb|[[:ar:زاوية بونوح|Bounouh Zaouiya]]]] Mohamed Seghir Boushaki did not however break his spiritual and family ties with the followers of the Zawiyas Rahmaniyya of Tizi Ouzou who often visited him at his home in Ménerville, made a passage to his "Moorish Café" during their movements and sat as him in the 27th electoral circle of [[Tizi Ouzou]] like him in the 29th constituency of [[Boudouaou|Alma (Boudouaou)]]. During the religious festivals, human foot convoys of Kabyle Sufis linked the villages of the "Aïth Aïcha" with those of the "Aïth Guechtoula" of Boghni with psalmodies, recitations and intonations all along the route of about 40 km. The [[pilgrim]]s and Kabyle disciples started from the Zawiyas of [[:fr:Sidi Boushaki|Sidi Boushaki]] to reach the [[:ar:زاوية بونوح|Bounouh Zaouiya]] in order to celebrate the [[Mawlid]] each year.{{cite web|author=Nawel Ben |url=http://www.djazairess.com/fr/lemidi/1009150501 |title=Bounouh ou le bercail de Sidi Abderrahmane |website=Djazairess.com |date=2010-09-15 |accessdate=2017-02-28}} Mohamed Seghir then built a volunteer house of passengers at "Thala Oufella (Soumâa)" to welcome these [[Sufi]] disciples during their religious wanderings. He had previously sent his son "M'Hamed Boushaki" as well as his other brothers to study in the "[[Boumerdès|Boumerdassi]] Zawiya" south of [[Tidjelabine]].{{cite web|url=http://ethnopolis-net.over-blog.com/2015/01/confreries-soufies-en-kabylie.html |title=Confréries soufies en kabylie - Ethnopolis |website=Ethnopolis-net.over-blog.com |date= |accessdate=2017-02-28}} Meanwhile, his elder brother "Ali Boushaki" (1855-1965) had taken a [[theologian]] route to become one of the [[mufti]]s of [[:fr:Basse Kabylie|Lower Kabylie]] according to the [[Maliki]] rite and was named Mokaddem of the tarika Rahmaniyya in the region between The [[:fr:Mitidja|Mitidja]] and the [[Djurdjura]], as well as his position as [[Imam]] of the preaching at the Mosque of Ménerville. == Lobbying == [[File:L'hémicycle du Sénat français en septembre 2009.jpg|thumb|[[Senate (France)|French Senate]]]] Councilor Mohamed Seghir Boushaki excelled from 1920 to 1925 in political, social and religious lobbying during his first political mandate following the promulgation of the Jonnart Act.{{cite web|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k75826757 |title=L'Echo d'Alger : journal républicain du matin | 1927-08-12 |language=fr |website=Gallica.bnf.fr |date= |accessdate=2017-02-28}} Thus Mohamed Seghir mobilized the ardor of many Algerian councilors for the making and signing of "Petition No. 30" dated July 18, 1920, where he protested with several of his colleagues to the [[Senate]] against the provisions of a bill tabled in the Chamber by the [[French Government]] on the regulation of the [[Indigénat]] system in Algeria and the accession of Algerians of origin to [[political rights]].{{cite web|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k7581527h |title=L'Echo d'Alger : journal républicain du matin | 1925-05-06 |language=fr |website=Gallica.bnf.fr |date= |accessdate=2017-02-28}} This "Petition No. 30" by Mohamed Seghir and his associates was examined by the [[:fr:Liste des sénateurs des Landes|Senator of the Landes]] of the time who was [[:fr:Charles Cadilhon|Charles Cadilhon]] as [[:fr:Rapporteur parlementaire|rapporteur]] of the senatorial session under the [[French Third Republic]].{{cite web|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k7581529b |title=L'Echo d'Alger : journal républicain du matin | 1925-05-08 |language=fr |website=Gallica.bnf.fr |date= |accessdate=2017-02-28}} Mohamed Seghir had thoroughly studied the decision-making mechanisms of the resolutions of the Petitions Committees under Rule 100 of the Rules of Procedure of the [[Senate (France)|French Senate]] which stipulated that any senator could ask for the report in public sitting of a petition whatever the classification which the commission has assigned to him at his request, addressed in writing to the President of the Senate, so that this report is presented in the sitting the Senate. After the expiry of the period prescribed for the processing of a [[petition]], the resolutions of the Committee shall become final in respect of petitions which are not to be the subject of a public report and shall be referred to in the [[Journal officiel de la République française]].{{cite web|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k75841984 |title=L'Echo d'Alger : journal républicain du matin | 1935-05-25 |language=fr |website=Gallica.bnf.fr |date=1935-05-25 |accessdate=2017-02-28}} Thus "Petition No. 30" came into existence and was thoroughly discussed before being published in the Official Journal of May 20, 1921.{{cite web|url=http://www.archivesnationales.culture.gouv.fr/chan/chan/pdf/sm/C_14629_15246.pdf |format=PDF |title=Les archives de la Chambre des députés sous la Troisième République (1919-1942) |website=Senat.fr |accessdate=2017-02-28}} It was the "[[:fr:Sénat (Troisième République)|Senate of the Third Republic]]" which had debated this petition under the presidency of [[Léon Bourgeois]].{{cite web|url=http://www.senat.fr/comptes-rendus-seances/3eme/pdf/1920/07/S19200730_1603_1646.pdf |format=PDF |title=Journal Officiel |date=1920-07-31 |website=Senat.fr |accessdate=2017-02-28}} == Office terms == [[File:Hôpital de Thénia.jpg|thumb|Thala Oufella (Soumâa) Mountain in [[Thenia]]]]

'''Pirouz Davani''' (1961–1998~) ({{lang-fa|پیروز دوانی}}) is, or was, an [[Iran]]ian [[leftist]] activist and [[Editor-in-chief|editor]] of the ''Pirouz'' ([[Persian language|Persian]]: ''"Victorious"'') newspaper. He disappeared on 28 August 1998 while leaving his residence in [[Tehran]]. Some have suggested that Davani was murdered.<ref name=payvand>[http://www.payvand.com/news/03/aug/1151.html ''Iranian journalist Pirouz Davani, missing for 5 years, is glaring case of impunity''] by [[Reporters Without Borders]] (Payvand, 29 August 2003)</ref>
==Early career== Pirooz Davani joined the [[Iranian Revolution]] against the [[Pahlavi dynasty]] as a youth. After the revolution succeeded he was arrested in 1981 "for his alleged links to the [[communist]] opposition" and was imprisoned.<ref name=payvand/>
Following the 1988 mass execution of political prisoners, he is reported to have launched a campaign against the government. "In winter of 1991, Pirooz was again arrested for his activities and after spending six months in solitary confinement, was sentenced to four years in prison. He was released from prison in 1995".
Following the election of president [[Mohammad Khatami]] he "established a cultural institute to publish and promote new interpretation of left's struggle for [[democracy]] in Iran", which "lead to creation of the Organisation of Unity for Democracy in Iran."<ref>[http://www.greenleft.org.au/2003/556/29471 Write On: Letters to Green Left Weekly - Pirooz Davani] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090622133245/http://www.greenleft.org.au/2003/556/29471 |date=2009-06-22 }} letter by Ardeshir Gholipoor</ref>
He later established the ''Pirouz'' [[newspaper]] which was openly critical of the Government.
==Disappearance== In September 1998, Davani's brother Majid announced that Davani had been "abducted" by "[[Plainclothes law enforcement|plain-clothes officers]]" from Iran's [[Ministry of Intelligence of Iran|Ministry of Intelligence]].<ref name=IPS>[http://www.iran-press-service.com/articles/arrests_continue.html ''Meanwhile, arbitrary arrests continue unabated''] ([[Iran Press Service]], 3 September 1998)</ref>
Davani is thought he may have been a victims of Iran's [[Chain murders of Iran|"chain murders"]] of Iranian dissidents, though his body has never been recovered and no records of imprisonment have ever been published.<ref name=RSF/> His disappearance occurred several months before the murders of four other Iranian [[dissident]]s in November 1998.<ref>[http://www.iran-press-service.com/ips/articles-2004/july/hunger_strike_22704.shtml ''A dozen of prominent Iranian political prisoners observes hunger strike''] by Safa Haeri ([[Iran Press Service]], 21 July 2004)</ref> In December 1998, [[Amnesty International]] issued a public statement that they had received reports that Davani's mother had been contacted anonymously and told her son had been killed. According to unconfirmed reports at the time, she suffered a fatal [[heart attack]] upon hearing the news.<ref name=amnesty>[https://www.amnesty.org/es/documents/mde13/023/1998/es/ ''Amnesty International calls for independent investigation into killings''] ([[Amnesty International]], 3 December 1998)</ref>
In November 2004, [[Reporters Without Borders]] reported:<ref name=RSF>[http://www.ifex.org/iran/2004/11/25/impunity_continues_to_triumph_in/ ''Impunity continues to triumph in Iranian justice system, says RSF''] - Press Release, [[Reporters Without Borders]] (Reprint: [[International Freedom of Expression Exchange|IFEX]], 25 November 2004)</ref>
:''The intelligence ministry officially recognized in January 1999 that some of its agents were involved and announced dozens of arrests. Fifteen intelligence ministry agents were convicted in January 2001 for the murder of the Forouhars. Three were sentenced to death. The other 12 received prison sentences. Three other suspects were acquitted. The Supreme Court upheld the verdict but only two persons were sentenced to 15 years in prison. The authorities never tried to establish the circumstances of Davani's disappearance...''
