'''Richard Coote, 1st Earl of Bellomont''' (sometimes spelled '''Bellamont''', 1636 – 5 March 1700/01<ref name=dates>In the [[Julian calendar]], then in use in England, the year began on 25 March. To avoid confusion with dates in the [[Gregorian calendar]], then in use in other parts of Europe, dates between January and March were often written with both years. Dates in this article are in the Julian calendar unless otherwise noted.</ref>), known as '''The Lord Coote''' between 1683–89, was a member of the English Parliament and a colonial governor. Born in [[Kingdom of Ireland|Ireland]], he was an early supporter of [[William III of England|William III]] and [[Mary II of England|Mary II]], siding with them in the [[Glorious Revolution]].
In 1695 he was given commissions as governor of the provinces of [[Province of New York|New York]], [[Province of Massachusetts Bay|Massachusetts Bay]], and [[Province of New Hampshire|New Hampshire]], which he held until his death. He did not arrive in the [[New World]] until 1698, and spent most of his tenure as governor in New York. He spent a little over a year in Massachusetts, and only two weeks in New Hampshire. His time in New York was marked by divisive politics resulting from [[Leisler's Rebellion]] (1689–91), and difficult and ultimately unsuccessful negotiations to keep the [[Iroquois]] from engaging in peace talks with [[New France]]. Frontier issues were also in the forefront during his time in Massachusetts and New Hampshire, where lumber and security from the [[Abenaki]] threat dominated his tenure.
He was a major financial sponsor of [[William Kidd]], whose [[privateering]] was later deemed to have descended into [[piracy]]. Bellomont engineered the arrest of Kidd in Boston, and had him returned to England, where he was tried, convicted, and hanged.
==Early life and career== Richard Coote was born in [[Kingdom of Ireland|Ireland]] in 1636. He was the second son, but the first to survive infancy, of Richard Coote, third son of [[Sir Charles Coote, 1st Baronet]], and Mary, daughter of Sir George St George. His father was created [[Earl of Bellomont|Baron Coote of Coloony]] in 1660 (on the same day as his uncle was created [[Earl of Mountrath]]), and he succeeded his father as Baron Coote on the latter's death on 10 July 1683.<ref>De Peyster, pp. 5–6</ref>
Little is recorded of his early years.<ref>De Peyster, p. 6</ref> In 1677 he is known to have killed a man in a duel for the affections of a young lady. He did not marry her, however, and in 1680 he married Catherine, the daughter of Bridges Nanfan and the eventual heir to [[Birtsmorton Court]] in [[Worcestershire]].<ref>Clifford and Perry, p. 34</ref> They had two sons.<ref name=Burke135>Burke, p. 135</ref>
Following the accession of the pro-Catholic [[James II of England|James II]] to the English throne, Coote, a Protestant, moved to the Continent and served as a captain of horse in the Dutch army.<ref name=DP9/><ref name=H125>Henning, p. 125</ref> Because of the family's record of service to [[Charles II of England|Charles II]], his absence from court eventually drew the king's attention, and he was summoned back to court in 1687.<ref name=DP9>De Peyster, p. 9</ref> He was one of the first to join [[William III of England|William of Orange]] in the [[Glorious Revolution]] of 1688 that brought [[William III of England|William III]] and [[Mary II of England|Mary II]] to the throne. He was rewarded for this loyalty with an appointment as [[Treasurer to the Queen]] in 1689, a post he held until 1694.<ref name=H125/><ref name=DB10/> It also drew unfavourable attention in the Irish Parliament. That body, still under the influence of James, [[Bill of attainder|attainted]] him and seized his lands. As a result of this, William on 2 November 1689 created him Earl of Bellomont,<ref name=DB10>De Peyster, p. 10</ref> and granted him over {{convert|77000|acre|ha}} of forfeited Irish lands. The land grant was highly controversial in Parliament, and was eventually rescinded by William.<ref>Clifford and Perry, p. 35</ref> He was also rewarded with the governorship of [[County Leitrim]].<ref>Wills, p. 43</ref>
Bellomont was [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Droitwich (UK Parliament constituency)|Droitwich]] from 1688 to 1695.<ref name=DNB>{{cite DNB|wstitle=Coote, Richard|last=Stephens|first=Henry Morse|authorlink=Henry Morse Stephens}}</ref> In the 1690s he became involved in the attempts by [[Jacob Leisler]]'s son to clear his father's name. Leisler had been a leading force in [[Leisler's Rebellion|the New York rebellion]] against the [[Dominion of New England]] established by King James. Upon the arrival of [[Henry Sloughter]] as governor of New York, Leisler was arrested, tried, and executed for treason, and his properties were seized. Leisler's son Jacob Jr. traveled to England to argue the case for restoration of the family properties. Bellomont sat on the Parliamentary committee that examined the evidence, and spoke in Parliament in support of the Leisler's case. He strongly stated his view that Leisler and son-in-law Jacob Milborne had been "barbarously murdered" by Sloughter's actions in a letter to Massachusetts colonial agent [[Increase Mather]]. Young Leisler's efforts were successful: Parliament voted to reverse the attainder, and ordered that the family properties be restored.<ref>Leonard, p. 152</ref>
==Colonial governor== The death in 1695 of Sir [[William Phips]] vacated the governorship of the [[Province of Massachusetts Bay]]. Colonial agents lobbied to select either [[Wait Winthrop]] or [[Joseph Dudley]], both native sons, to replace Phips, but the king, wanting someone who would better represent crown authority, selected Bellomont. Since William wanted someone who could exert authority over more of New England, he was also given the governorships of [[Province of New Hampshire|New Hampshire]], and [[Province of New York|New York]].<ref>Dunn, pp. 308–10</ref><ref name=DP24/> The major concern that Bellomont was instructed to address was ongoing problems with [[piracy]], including the open commerce with pirates that went on in [[New York City]] and [[Colony of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations|Rhode Island]].<ref>Leonard, p. 153</ref>
[[File:Pyle pirate relaxing2.jpg|thumb|right|upright|[[Howard Pyle]]'s depiction of [[William Kidd]] aboard his ship in New York Harbor]] Bellomont's commissions were not finalized until 1 June 1697.<ref name=DP24>De Peyster, p. 24</ref> While they were being worked on, New York colonial agent [[Robert Livingston the Elder|Robert Livingston]] proposed to Bellomont that a [[privateer]] be outfitted to combat piracy, and recommended [[William Kidd]] be its captain.<ref name=L154/><ref>De Peyster, p. 25</ref> This scheme received the assent of King William, who issued a [[letter of marque]] to Kidd for the purpose, as well as a special commission for dealing with pirates. Bellomont raised £6,000 (including £1,000 of his own money, and funds from some of the Lords of the Admiralty) to outfit Kidd's ship.<ref name=L154>Leonard, p. 154</ref>
===New York=== Bellomont sailed for New York in late 1697, accompanied by his wife and her cousin, [[John Nanfan]], who had been appointed Lieutenant Governor of New York. The voyage was exceptionally stormy, and Bellomont's ship was blown well south, eventually putting into [[Barbados]] before continuing on to New York. He arrived in New York City on 2 April 1698. Bellomont's stylish dress, good looks, and positive relationship with the king predisposed New Yorkers to like him, but he very quickly ran into difficulties and began making enemies.<ref>De Peyster, pp. 31–33</ref>
His attempts to enforce the [[Navigation Acts]] predictably turned merchants and traders against him. These attempts were also poorly executed by colonial officials whose interests lay more with those merchants than they did with the crown.<ref>Leonard, p. 155</ref> He raised the anger of Leisler's opponents by implementing the parliamentary act he had helped pass, and saw through the restoration of Leisler's properties.<ref>De Peyster, p. 37</ref> There was so much opposition within his council to this that he ended up purging the council of those opposed.<ref>Leonard, p. 156</ref> Bellomont also approved the exhumation of the remains of Leisler and his son-in-law Jacob Milborne, which had been unceremoniously buried under the gallows from which they had been hanged. He sanctioned a proper burial, and provide an honour guard of 100 soldiers for the service.<ref>De Peyster, pp. 41–42</ref>
Bellomont's support of the Leislerians proved to be costly, not just in terms of New York politics, but in Indian diplomacy as well. [[Benjamin Fletcher]], Bellomont's predecessor in office, had taken advantage of the long period between Bellomont's appointment and arrival to make some questionable land grants, including extended leases to properties normally allocated for the governor's use,<ref>De Peyster, pp. 33–35</ref> and in territories that were still claimed by the [[Iroquois]]. When the provincial assembly passed a law retracting all of these irregular grants, it predictably angered a number of large landowners.<ref name=L157/> Land grants made in Iroquois territory to [[Godfridius Dellius]], the influential pastor of the [[Dutch Reformed Church]] in [[Albany, New York|Albany]],<ref>Doyle, p. 309</ref> and others were a specific subject of Iroquois complaints. Even though Bellomont's law was passed, the grantees appealed to the Board of Trade, and the bill never received royal assent.<ref>De Peyster, p. 44</ref>
[[File:Hector-Calliere.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Hector de Callière]] was governor of [[New France]] while Bellomont governed New York.]] Bellomont denied Dellius and other anti-Leislerians positions of importance in dealing with the Iroquois, resulting in the loss of experienced negotiators.<ref>Richter, p. 192</ref> This affected internal Iroquois politics, since supporters of interaction with the English lost influence when their English counterparts were sidelined.<ref>Richter, p. 193</ref> This came at a particularly delicate time, when Bellomont was working to strengthen the [[Covenant Chain]] that had been neglected by Fletcher.<ref name="Richter, p. 191">Richter, p. 191</ref>
After the [[Treaty of Ryswick]] ended war between the French and English in 1697, the French continued to make war on the Iroquois (primarily through their Algonquian allies in the [[Great Lakes]] region), and inflicted significant casualties on them. The Iroquois sought the assistance of the English to combat this, threatening to make peace with the French if they did not receive help.<ref>Richter and Merrell, p. 52</ref> Bellomont and French Governor General [[Louis-Hector de Callière]] both claimed dominance over the Iroquois, and each refused to acknowledge the other's right to intercede on their behalf.<ref>Richter, p. 187</ref> When Callière summoned the Iroquois to Montreal for negotiations in 1699, Bellomont was alerted, and successfully manoeuvred the Iroquois into not going by sending an emissary to Montreal and troops to Albany under Lieutenant Governor Nanfan.<ref>Richter, p. 194</ref> The English emissary was unsuccessful in swaying the French from their course of action, and French-allied Algonquians made incursions deep into Iroquois territory in 1700.<ref name=R188/>
In negotiations with the Iroquois, Bellomont overlooked some of the social elements that Iroquois customs demanded, with the result that the parties ended with differing views of how successful their councils were. Bellomont believed they went well, even though it was fairly clear that the Iroquois negotiators were unhappy with how the discussion had gone.<ref name="Richter, p. 191"/> He promised them the construction of a fort at [[Onondaga Reservation|Onondaga]], and even convinced the legislature to appropriate £1,000 for its construction, but the Iroquois were evasive on accepting this "gift", and never showed English engineers suitable locations for a fort.<ref>Richter, pp. 208–09</ref> Bellomont's attempts to prevent the Iroquois from dealing with the French were negated by the French military successes of 1700, which brought the Iroquois to a peace council that resulted in the 1701 [[Great Peace of Montreal]].<ref name=R188>Richter, p. 188</ref>
===Massachusetts and New Hampshire=== [[File:Elisha Cooke SR.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Bellomont's Massachusetts advisor, [[Elisha Cooke, Sr.]]]] In May 1699 Bellomont sailed for [[Boston]].<ref name=L157>Leonard, p. 157</ref> Bellomont spent 14 months in New England in 1699 and 1700, spending a few weeks of that time in New Hampshire and the rest in Massachusetts.<ref>Palfrey, pp. 175, 216</ref> In Massachusetts he was treated politely, but his attempts to implement the crown's policies ran into trouble, as they had in New York. He was refused a salary by the colonial legislature, although the "gift" of £1,000 he received was more than that typically given other governors of the province.<ref>Palfrey, pp. 176–77</ref> The legislature also made repeated attempts to limit appeals to London of judicial decisions handed down by provincial courts. Bellomont, as he was required to do, forwarded laws passed by the legislature to the Board of Trade for approval; these laws were repeatedly struck down because of provisions that attempted to limit royal prerogatives.<ref>Palfrey, pp. 172–75</ref> He also sided politically against Lieutenant Governor [[William Stoughton (Massachusetts)|William Stoughton]], who was an ally of Joseph Dudley, a Massachusetts native who had presided over the trial of Jacob Leisler. Instead he took council with the populist leader [[Elisha Cooke, Sr.]]<ref>Palfrey, p. 171</ref>
Not long after his arrival in Boston, Bellomont engineered the arrest of William Kidd. Rumors had reached the colonies that Kidd had descended into piracy, and he came to be viewed by Bellomont and the other high-profile investors in Kidd's ship as a liability. In November 1698 the Admiralty issued orders to all colonial governors to apprehend Kidd.<ref>Zacks, p. 230</ref> When he was informed by an agent of Kidd's in June 1699 that Kidd was in the area, Bellomont sent a message back to Kidd, promising clemency.<ref name=Z231>Zacks, p. 231</ref> Kidd responded that he would come, sending some of his treasures as a present to Lady Bellomont; she refused them.<ref>Zacks, p. 239</ref>
After Kidd's arrival in Boston on 3 July, Bellomont demanded from Kidd a written account of his travels, which Kidd, after haggling over the time, agreed to deliver on the morning of 6 July. When he did not do so, Bellomont issued a warrant for his arrest. It was executed as Kidd was en route to see Bellomont at midday the same day.<ref>Zacks, pp. 248–50</ref> Kidd then attempted to negotiate his freedom, using the secret locations of his treasure and a captured prize ship as bargaining chips.<ref>Zacks, pp. 253-54</ref> Although a portion of Kidd's treasure was recovered, it did not buy Kidd's freedom, and he was shipped to London in April 1700, where he was tried, convicted, and hanged.<ref>De Peyster, pp. 47–52</ref> In contrast to the relative secrecy with which he conducted some of his communications with Kidd,<ref name=Z231/> Bellomont was scrupulous in his dealings with other potentially questionable merchant and pirate business, despite being offered as much as £5,000 to overlook illicit activities.<ref>De Peyster, p. 51</ref>
Matters of frontier security and the lumber trade dominated his brief administration in New England.<ref>Palfrey, pp. 187, 217–18</ref> New England was recognized as an important source of ship masts for the [[Royal Navy]], and the Board of Trade and the Admiralty sought to reserve suitable trees for the crown's benefit. In both provinces he encountered opposition to entrenched land and timber interests that resented the intrusion of surveyors onto their lands, and interfered with their taking of lumber from lands that had not been granted and were thus reserved to the crown.<ref>Malone, pp. 17–20</ref>
In New Hampshire the timber dispute was overlaid by ongoing disputes between local landowners and [[Samuel Allen (New Hampshire)|Samuel Allen]], a London merchant who had acquired the territorial claims of the heirs of [[John Mason (governor)|John Mason]], the province's founder, and was pursuing them against those landowners.<ref name=D332/> Allen, who had been commissioned governor of the province in 1692,<ref>''American Quarterly Register'', p. 272</ref> only came to the colony in 1698 to take a direct interest in its affairs. During Bellomont's brief visit to New Hampshire in July and August 1699, Allen attempted to buy him to his side. Allen offered his daughter (with a large dowry) as a marriage match for the earl's son; Bellomont refused the offer.<ref name=D332>Doyle, p. 332</ref><ref>Palfrey, pp. 215–17</ref>
===Abenaki relations=== [[File:Abenakis.jpg|thumb|left|upright|18th century depiction of an [[Abenaki]] couple]] The frontier situation that Bellomont encountered during his time in Massachusetts and New Hampshire was somewhat tense, because the [[Abenaki]] of northern New England (like the Iroquois in New York) had not been involved in the Treaty of Ryswick that ended King William's War. In the aftermath of the war they and the settlers of Maine and New Hampshire were extremely mistrustful of one another.<ref>Morrison, pp. 142–43</ref> The Abenaki felt threatened by English encroachment on their lands, and the settlers feared a return to significant French-inspired raiding of their settlements. Bellomont issued proclamations to distribute among the Abenaki denying plans to take their lands, but was unable to ease the underlying tensions.<ref>Morrison, p. 147</ref> One reason for this was his naive assumption that Abenaki concerns were rooted in a French Catholic conspiracy. When English negotiators attempted to separate the Abenaki from their Jesuit missionaries, this upset ongoing trade negotiations, and did nothing to assuage Puritan New England concerns over the activities of "Popish Emissaries" intriguing to make war on them.<ref>Morrison, pp. 148–51</ref> The colonial legislature passed a law banning Roman Catholics from territory claimed by the province, which included Abenaki territory claimed by Governor Sir [[William Phips]] in 1693.<ref>Morrison, p. 149</ref> Bellomont engaged in fruitless attempts to convince the eastern Abenaki to migrate west, where they would come under Iroquois influence; this was unsuccessful, in part because the Abenaki and Iroquois had a history of conflict.<ref name=Mor142>Morrison, p. 142</ref> Despite these difficulties, he managed to achieve a precarious peace with the Abenaki in January 1699.<ref>Morrison, p. 143</ref>
Abenaki relations were also complicated by misunderstandings about sovereignty. The Abenaki viewed themselves as sovereign, while the English believed them to be subjects, either to themselves or to the French. A prisoner exchange involving English held by the Abenaki and Indians held by the English was frustrated when Bellomont believed that it would be sufficient to negotiate with his counterpart in [[Quebec City|Quebec]] to obtain the release of the English prisoners.<ref name=Mor142/>
==Return to New York and death== He returned to New York in 1700, where he resumed actions against piracy and illegal shipping.<ref name=DP57/> Following a conference with the Iroquois at Albany in early 1700/1 (which Bellomont characterized as "greatest fatigue [I] ever underwent"), he returned to New York City,<ref>Richter, p. 207</ref> where he succumbed to a severe case of [[gout]] on 5 March 1700/01. He was buried in the chapel of Fort William. When the fort was dismantled, his remains were moved to the yard of [[St. Paul's Chapel]].<ref name=DP57>De Peyster, p. 57</ref> [[File:St. Paul's Chapel, Manhattan (WTM by official-ly cool 037).jpg|thumb|right|upright|[[St. Paul's Chapel]] yard, location of Bellomont's grave]] Lieutenant Governor Nanfan acted as New York's governor until the arrival of [[Edward Hyde, 3rd Earl of Clarendon|Lord Cornbury]] in 1702.<ref>Bonomi, p. 59</ref> Nanfan, during his brief tenure, reached the peace agreement that eluded Bellomont. In an agreement negotiated later in 1701, the Iroquois [[Nanfan Treaty|signed an agreement]] putting their westernmost territorial claims (spanning from present-day [[Erie, Pennsylvania]] to [[Chicago]] and northern [[Michigan]]) under the English crown's protection.<ref>Richter, p. 212</ref>
==Family, titles, and legacy== Bellomont's eldest son, [[Nanfan Coote, 2nd Earl of Bellomont|Nanfan, Lord Coloony]], succeeded to the earldom on his death. His second son [[Richard Coote, 3rd Earl of Bellomont|Richard]], succeeded in turn as 3rd earl on his elder brother's death. On the 3rd earl's death without surviving male heirs, the earldom became extinct, while the barony devolved on his cousin, [[Charles Coote, 1st Earl of Bellomont|Sir Charles Coote]], who was later also created [[Earl of Bellomont]]. He died without male issue, and all of the titles were then extinguished.<ref name=Burke135/>
Bellomont's rule in New York was not remembered fondly. One political opponent, noting that the provincial debt rose substantially during his tenure, wrote that the memory of Bellomont "will stink in the nostrills of all good men",<ref name=B90>Bonomi, p. 90</ref> and Robert Livingston reported that the debt was "a greater Debt than I had ever seen".<ref>Bonomi, p. 91</ref> Bellomont's personal affairs were also difficult to tie up: his creditors tried (unsuccessfully) to prevent his wife's departure from the province in order to compel settlement of his personal debts. Bellomont's financial issues were not unique in this respect. Later governors (including Nanfan and Cornbury) were arrested on charges of malfeasance and personal indebtedness at the behest of their political opponents. New York's debt problems were not resolved until the [[Robert Hunter (governor)|Hunter]] administration in 1717.<ref name=B90/>

'''Richard M. Eyre''' (born 1944)<ref>Birth year is from one an entry in the [[United States Copyright Office]] catalog. See: {{cite web | title=Life before life : origins of the soul ... knowing where you came from and... | work=[[United States Copyright Office]] catalog | url=http://cocatalog.loc.gov/cgi-bin/Pwebrecon.cgi?SC=Author&SA=Eyre%2C%20Richard%2C%201944-&PID=olihnTa_bH7nLcBdx1uLP7hiWFB-&BROWSE=3&HC=1&SID=2 | accessdate=2009-06-08}}</ref> is a consultant, speaker, and author of many books. He was also a candidate for the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] nomination for [[Governor of Utah|Utah Governor]] in 1992.
==Education== Eyre holds degrees from [[Utah State University]] and [[Brigham Young University]] and an [[MBA]] from [[Harvard Business School|Harvard]].<ref>[http://clubs.harvard.edu/olc/pub/HAA/university/officers.jsp?chapter=116 Harvard Alumni Association Club of Utah - Officers<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> His wife, Linda J. Eyre, has a degree from [[Utah State University]].
==Publications== The Eyres have written over a dozen books, with several of them becoming bestsellers. These include ''Teaching Your Children Values'', which was the first parenting book to make it to the position of #1 New York Times bestseller since [[Dr. Spock]]'s book.{{citation needed|date=June 2008}} Eyre's ''Spiritual Serendipity: Cultivating and Celebrating the Art of the Unexpected'' was published by [[Simon & Schuster]] in 1997.<ref>[http://agelesslearner.com/books/bookstore.html Ageless Learner Bookstore<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Other books by Eyre include ''The Discovery of Joy'' (1974), ''Teaching Children Joy'' (1986), ''The Birth We Call Death'' with [[Paul H. Dunn]], ''Life Before Life'' (2000) and ''How to Talk to Your Children About Sex,'' written with Linda. Besides writing these non-fiction works, Eyre wrote a novel entitled ''The Awakening''.<ref>[http://mormonlit.lib.byu.edu/lit_author.php?a_id=91 Mormon Literature Database - Eyre, Richard M<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> A more recent book by the Eyres, ''Empty Nesting Parenting: Adjusting Your Stewardship as Your Children Leave Home'', has been recommended as reading for parents of college students.<ref>[http://www.lssu.edu/admissions/parents/books.php Lake Superior State University :: Admissions :: Books and Guides<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.deanofstudents.ilstu.edu/parent/understanding-your-student.shtml Understanding Your Student: Parents: Dean of Students Office<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>http://www2.uca.edu/divisions/student/orientation/PDF%20Documents/Books.pdf</ref>
Linda Eyre has also written several books on being a mother on her own or with other female authors.
The Eyres have hosted the program ''Families Are Forever'' on the [[VISN]] Network.<ref>''[[Church News]]'', December 18, 1993.{{full|date=September 2018}}</ref> They have 9 children, and have lived in both [[Washington, D.C.]] and [[Salt Lake City, Utah|Salt Lake City]], [[Utah]].
==Religion== Richard Eyre is a member of [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (LDS Church). As a young man, Eyre served as a [[Missionary (LDS Church)|missionary]] in [[New York City]].<ref>[http://www.charlespresspub.com/religionscontribs.html Contributors to How Different Religions View Death and Afterlife, 2nd Ed<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> He later served as a [[mission president]] in the church's [[England]] [[South London|London South]] [[Mission (LDS Church)|Mission]]. Baptisms spiked in the mission after the results of an opinion poll on parenthood conducted by Eyre were published in such publications as the [[London Evening Standard]].<ref>[http://www.lds.org/ensign/1977/08/news-of-the-church/the-church-in-the-headlines "The Church in the Headlines"], ''[[Ensign (LDS magazine)|Ensign]]'', August 1977, p. 75.</ref>
Eyre wrote the [[Encyclopedia of Mormonism]] article on Joy.<ref>''Selection for the Encyclopedia of Mormonism: Jesus Christ and His Gospels'', p. 310-311</ref> He also wrote the section on the views of LDS Church in ''How Different Religions View Death and Afterlife: Second Edition'' Edited by [[Christopher Jay Johnson]] and [[Marsha McGee]].<ref>[http://www.charlespresspub.com/religions2.html How Different Religions View Dea<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Politics== During the [[Ronald Reagan|Reagan]] administration, Eyre served as the director of the White House Conference on Parents and Children.<ref>[http://www.meridianmagazine.com/parentsjournal/050720value.html Meridian Magazine :: Meridian Family Value Archive: The Meridian Family Value of the Month<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Eyre has also been a long-time advocate of [[School choice|schools of choice]] and [[school voucher|voucher programs]]. He was a candidate for the governorship of Utah with this as one of his major campaign planks in 1992. Eyre won the support of the Republican State convention but lost to [[Mike Leavitt]] in the later Republican primary.<ref>http://www.schoolchoiceutah.com/documents/PressRelease_2007_09_12.pdf</ref> Eyre has since been a major supporter of vouchers, and was one of the key speakers for the voucher proposition on Utah's 2007 ballot.<ref>{{cite news | author=Benson, Lee | title=Yay or nay to vouchers? I vote ... | work=[[Deseret Morning News]] | date=October 21, 2007 | url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/1,5143,695220518,00.html | accessdate=2009-06-08}}</ref>
Linda has also served as a member of the Utah State University board of trustees.<ref>[http://www.usu.edu/generalcatalog/2002-2004/pdf/01DAdmin02.pdf 2002-2004 USU board of trustees]</ref>
==Other==
The Eyres also serve as board members of [[CHOICE humanitarian]] and have been involved in projects to bring wells to villages in such countries as [[Bolivia]].<ref>{{cite news | author=Genessy, Jody | title=East High hoopster enjoys a watered-down vacation | date=January 19, 1999 | work=[[Deseret News]] | url=http://archive.deseretnews.com/archive/674857/East-High-hoopster-enjoys-a-watered-down-vacation-Eyre-helps-town-in-Bolivia-get-water-basketball.html | accessdate=2009-06-08}}</ref>

[[Lexi Roscoe]] }} '''Robbie Roscoe''' is a [[Character (arts)|fictional character]] from the [[Television in the United Kingdom|British]] [[Channel 4]] [[soap opera]], ''[[Hollyoaks]]'', played by [[Charlie Wernham]]. He made his first screen appearance on 2 April 2013.{{cite web|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|title=Soapland's joiners, movers and leavers|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/information/a130011/soaplands-joiners-movers-and-leavers.html|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=([[Hearst Magazines UK]])|accessdate=27 March 2013|date=26 March 2013}} Robbie is part of the Roscoe family and the first member to be introduced. On 19 March 2013, a [[Channel 4]] press release revealed that Robbie "leads the way for a family of boys to descend on ''Hollyoaks'', headed by [[Gillian Taylforth]] as mother, [[Sandy Roscoe|Sandy]]."{{cite web|title=Hollyoaks|url=http://www.channel4.com/info/press/programme-information/hollyoaks2|work=[[Channel 4]]|publisher=([[Channel Four Television Corporation]])|accessdate=26 March 2013|date=19 March 2013}} Wernham's casting was confirmed on 27 March 2013. Wernham auditioned for the show the previous year, attending his second audition on 24 October 2012.{{cite web|title=Billericay comic celebrates turning 18 in style|url=http://www.echo-news.co.uk/news/local_news/10002264.Billericay_comic_celebrates_turning_18_in_style/|work=[[The Echo (Essex)|The Echo]]|publisher=([[Newsquest]])|accessdate=28 March 2013|date=25 October 2012}} Daniel Kilkelly from [[Digital Spy]] later revealed Robbie is a "troublesome new student" and he would befriend established character [[Callum Kane]] ([[Laurie Duncan]]).{{cite web|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|title='Hollyoaks': John Paul and Doug grow closer - spoiler pictures|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s13/hollyoaks/scoop/a468393/hollyoaks-john-paul-and-doug-grow-closer-spoiler-pictures.html|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=([[Hearst Magazines UK]])|accessdate=26 March 2013|date=26 March 2013}} The writer added that Robbie's headteacher [[Patrick Blake (Hollyoaks)|Patrick Blake]] ([[Jeremy Sheffield]]) thinks he can control his behaviour. But Robbie soon begins to cause trouble.{{cite web|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|title='Hollyoaks': Meet newcomer Robbie Roscoe - pictures|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s13/hollyoaks/scoop/a468862/hollyoaks-meet-newcomer-robbie-roscoe-pictures.html|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=([[Hearst Magazines UK]])|accessdate=28 March 2013|date=27 March 2013}} Robbie's notable storylines have included: working for [[Trevor Royle]] ([[Greg Wood (actor)|Greg Wood]]); discover [[Darren Osborne]] ([[Ashley Taylor Dawson]]) is his half-brother; bullying his teacher, [[John Paul McQueen]] ([[James Sutton (actor)|James Sutton]]), with [[Finn O'Connor (Hollyoaks)|Finn O'Connor]] (Keith Rice); his relationship with John Paul's niece [[Phoebe McQueen]] ([[Mandip Gill]]); being reunited with his father [[Rick Spencer (Hollyoaks)|Rick Spencer]] (Victor Gardener); pushing his twin brother [[Jason Roscoe]] ([[Alfie Browne-Sykes]]) off a cliff; working with [[Ben Bradley (Hollyoaks)|Ben Bradley]] ([[Ben Richards (actor)|Ben Richards]]) to bring down Trevor; and his affairs with his brother [[Freddie Roscoe]]'s ([[Charlie Clapham (actor)|Charlie Clapham]]) wife and Finn's sister [[Sinead O'Connor (Hollyoaks)|Sinead O'Connor]] ([[Stephanie Davis (actress)|Stephanie Davis]]) and Jason's wife [[Holly Cunningham]] ([[Amanda Clapham]]), and his infatuation with sister-in-law and teacher [[Nancy Hayton|Nancy Osborne]] ([[Jessica Fox (actress)|Jessica Fox]]). It was announced on the 25 March 2016 that Robbie and Jason would be departing from the programme and the twins left the serial on 28 March 2016. ==Development== Robbie was created to pave the way for the rest of the Roscoe family to be introduced. Robbie was introduced as a sixth form student who was going to be trouble.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s13/hollyoaks/scoop/a468862/hollyoaks-meet-newcomer-robbie-roscoe-pictures.html#~poMxToY5z95JJd|title=Hollyoaks meet newcomer Robbie Roscoe|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=20 September 2015}} Wernham auditioned for the show the previous year, attending his second audition on 24 October 2012. Daniel Kilkelly from [[Digital Spy]] later revealed Robbie is a "troublesome new student" and he would befriend established character [[Callum Kane]] (Laurie Duncan). The writer added that Robbie's headteacher [[Patrick Blake (Hollyoaks)|Patrick Blake]] ([[Jeremy Sheffield]]) thinks he can control his behaviour. But Robbie soon begins to cause trouble. It was announced that Robbie would have a crush on teacher Nancy. The crush begins when she is helping him prepare for his exams.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s13/hollyoaks/news/a572226/hollyoaks-jessica-fox-nancy-is-flattered-by-robbie-crush.html#~poMBRziMm38hQY|title=Hollyoaks' Jessica Fox: 'Nancy is flattered by Robbie crush'|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=20 September 2015}} Jessica Fox who plays Nancy said that she didn't like how Nancy was getting on. Wernham briefly departed Hollyoaks to film [[The Bad Education Movie]].{{cite web|url=http://www.whatsontv.co.uk/hollyoaks/news/hollyoaks-star-charlie-wernhams-bad-education-like-mitchell-i-have-a-problem-with-authority|title=Hollyoaks Star Charlie Wernham's Bad Education 'Like Mitchell I have a problem with authority'|work=[[What's On TV]]|accessdate=30 August 2015}}
Hollyoaks wrote Robbie out by sending him to prison for the assault on [[Dirk Savage]].{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s13/hollyoaks/news/a637428/hollyoaks-robbie-and-freddie-face-the-police-in-e4-first-look-episode.html#~pmQCRmY19oJTBH|title=Hollyoaks: Robbie and Freddie face the police in E4 first look episode|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=30 August 2015}} During the Hollyoaks Summer 2015 trailer, it was shown that Robbie and Holly would hook up.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DTH6C7jgutI|title=Official Hollyoaks Trailer: Six Weeks of Summer (Starts 20th July 2015)}} Charlie Wernham stated in an interview that Holly would be torn between Robbie and Jason.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvshowsupdate.net/soaps/s13/hollyoaks/news/a662595/hollyoaks-spoilers-holly-will-be-torn-between-robbie-and-jason-charlie-wernham-reveals.html|title=Hollyoaks spoilers: Holly will be torn between Robbie and Jason, Charlie Wernham reveals|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=30 August 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151211062813/http://www.tvshowsupdate.net/soaps/s13/hollyoaks/news/a662595/hollyoaks-spoilers-holly-will-be-torn-between-robbie-and-jason-charlie-wernham-reveals.html|archivedate=11 December 2015|df=dmy-all}} So far [[Ben Bradley (Hollyoaks)|Ben Bradley]] is the only one who knows about this affair between them and he is using Robbie to get information on Trevor in exchange he won't tell Jason about the affair. When discussing Holly and Robbie's affair, Wernham explains to Digital Spy "Robbie and Holly sleeping together comes out of nowhere and it shocks both of them. I think it sparks something in Robbie and he realises that he has feelings for her, which is not good when Holly is going out with his brother! That will be an ongoing thing. I didn't know it was going to happen until I read the scripts. At first I thought it was going to be a one-off thing and they'd be trying to hide it from Jason, but it's not - Robbie starts to develop feelings for her." In an interview Wernham admitted that he would be surprised if his on-screen brother would let Robbie's affair with Holly go.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/soaps/hollyoaks/news/a779023/hollyoaks-star-charlie-wernham-robbie-feels-terrible-about-betraying-jason/|title=Roscoe rivalry! Hollyoaks star Charlie Wernham doubts Jason will forgive Robbie for Holly affair|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=11 January 2016}} When Robbie's departure was announced Wernham stated "This time, I felt that it was the right time for me to do other things - given my age, the amount of time I'd been in the show and where my character was at." in an interview.{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/hollyoaks-says-goodbye-robbie-jason-7629771|title=Hollyoaks says goodbye to Robbie and Jason Roscoe... but will the twins be leaving in body bags?|work=[[Daily Mirror]]|date=25 March 2016|accessdate=25 June 2016}} ==Storylines== Robbie arrives for his first day at college where the headteacher [[Patrick Blake (Hollyoaks)|Patrick Blake]] ([[Jeremy Sheffield]]) warns him not to cause trouble. He is mentored by [[Callum Kane]] ([[Laurie Duncan]]) but decides to truant college. Robbie begins to terrorise [[Doug Carter]] ([[PJ Brennan]]) and vandalise his delicatessen business. Doug reports Robbie to Patrick, much to his annoyance. Robbie and Callum notice Doug kissing [[John Paul McQueen]] ([[James Sutton (actor)|James Sutton]]) as they deface Patrick's car. Robbie puts pictures of the incident around college and John Paul loses his job. Robbie asks Callum to help him sell drugs and he agrees. Robbie helps [[Ste Hay]] ([[Kieron Richardson]]) deliver drug orders to buyers. Robbie steals a van with Callum and [[Sinead O'Connor (Hollyoaks)|Sinead O'Connor]] ([[Stephanie Davis (actress)|Stephanie Davis]]) and runs over Sinead's brother [[Finn O'Connor (Hollyoaks)|Finn O'Connor]] (Keith Rice). Rather than help him, they drive off and Robbie threatens Sinead to convince Finn to lie to the police. Robbie plans an armed robbery at Price Slice and enlists the help of Finn and Callum, but Callum changes his mind and attempts to prevent the robbery but he is shot in the struggle. When Robbie's mother [[Sandy Roscoe|Sandy]] ([[Gillian Taylforth]]) learns of the robbery she sends him to stay with his aunt. Robbie and Finn begin terrorising John Paul. They begin by teasing him about his sexuality and the situation ends when Finn rapes John Paul after hitting him over the head with a statue. Weeks later, when Finn is in hospital after a quad bike accident, Robbie continues teasing John Paul, locking him in a store cupboard and then teasing him over his sexuality again. This concludes when John Paul hits Robbie. When visiting Finn in hospital, Robbie finds out that he raped John Paul and is horrified, threatening to call the police. Since his discovery, Robbie begins to change and starts to stick up for John Paul, changing his statement when John Paul is up in court for hitting him. However, Finn changes it back and John Paul goes down. Robbie ditches his bad boy attitude and begins working towards his A-levels with the help of cover teacher [[Nancy Hayton|Nancy Osborne]] ([[Jessica Fox (actress)|Jessica Fox]]). He begins dating [[Phoebe McQueen]] ([[Mandip Gill]]). However, he begins to develop feelings for Nancy as she starts to help him with his A-level work more and kisses her. Phoebe finds texts on his phone apologising to Nancy and later sees them getting close. She decides to tell Nancy's boyfriend and ex-husband [[Darren Osborne|Darren]] ([[Ashley Taylor Dawson]]), who is Robbie's half-brother. However, they later reconcile. Bad news for Robbie as he discover that his father [[Rick Spencer (Hollyoaks)|Rick Spencer]] (Victor Gardener) arrived on town to see him and Jason, but more tragedy strikes as Jason was suffered body dysmorphic disorder, and their father is knocked unconscious by Joe and later dies in hospital after being given an overdose of morphine by an unknown killer. Robbie and Jason are led to believe Joe's punch killed Rick and Jason forgives Joe, though Robbie resents him and begins to act recklessly by stealing cars and assaulting Dirk Savage after he belittled him in the street because Robbie was anonymously blackmailing [[Dirk Savage]] ([[David Kennedy (actor)|David Kennedy]]). Robbie eventually owns up to his mistake and turns himself in to the police. A day before being released John-Paul visits him to tell him that Phoebe has been shot. The next day, Robbie is released and goes straight to hospital and barricades himself in Phoebe's hospital room, terrified she will die during her brain surgery. Joe and Freddie talk him out and Phoebe has a successful operation. Phoebe then tells him it was Grace who shot her, and Robbie tries to get revenge on Grace. Before he can do any harm, Joe tells him that it was him who shot Phoebe. Robbie then disowns Joe and proposes to Phoebe, which she agrees. When Robbie went to buy an engagement ring, Phoebe is murdered by the Gloved Hand Killer. Believing Joe to be the reason she died, Robbie attacks him with a crowbar, causing him to lose the use of his legs. Joe then lies to the police for Robbie. Nancy comforts Robbie after Phoebe's death eventually leading to them having sex after Phoebe's funeral. Robbie then returns to work for Trevor and when he finds out that he's planning to kill [[Kim Butterfield]] ([[Daisy Wood-Davis]]). He asks Trevor to let him send her out of the country instead. Trevor however puts drugs in Kim's bags and when Jason pull them over Robbie runs off with the bag to let Kim escape. Robbie and Jason argue, with Robbie revealing he told Jason's fiancée [[Holly Cunningham]] (Amanda Clapham) that her mother, [[Cindy Cunningham|Cindy]] ([[Stephanie Waring]]), kissed him. The fight turns physical ending with Robbie pushing Jason off a cliff. Robbie flees the scene and later has sex with Holly. [[Ben Bradley (Hollyoaks)|Ben Bradley]] ([[Ben Richards (actor)|Ben Richards]]) arrests Robbie but gives him a choice: inform him on Trevor or he'll make sure that Robbie will go back to prison and that Jason will know that he slept with Holly. Robbie agrees to work for him and informs him that Trevor and [[Ashley Davidson]] ([[Kierston Wareing]]) are planning to kidnap Patrick. Trevor and Ashley realise that somebody told the police and kidnap Holly, suspecting it was her. Robbie then texts Jason and he manages to convince Trevor and Ashley to let Holly go. Robbie then tells Ben he cannot work for him anymore and goes to tell Holly that he loves her, but found out that Jason bet him to it and they are back together, however Robbie and Holly pursue an affair behind Jason's back. Months later, Jason finds out about Robbie and Holly on his and Holly's wedding day after [[Nico Blake]] ([[Persephone Swales-Dawson]]) sends a video of Robbie confessing his love to Holly, from [[Dr. Charles S'avage]]'s (Andrew Greenough) laptop, to Jason out of jealousy. Jason ends up taking steroids again and tries to force himself on to Holly. After convincing from Freddie, Holly lies to Robbie and tells him that she slept with Jason again, ending things between them. In March 2016, Robbie and Jason decide leave to live in [[South Africa]] with Sandy, choosing life with each other over life with Holly and in April 2016 he never found out that Lindsey had killed him and Jason's dad Rick or Phoebe. ==Reception== When describing Robbie in an interview, Channel Four made a comment that Charlie wasn't a toe rag like Robbie.{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/programmes/hollyoaks/articles/all/an-interview-with-charlie-wernham/|title=An Interview With Charlie Wernham|work=[[Channel 4]]|accessdate=20 September 2015}} The affair between Holly and Robbie has been described as "scandalous".{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/soaps/hollyoaks/news/a662595/hollyoaks-spoilers-holly-will-be-torn-between-robbie-and-jason-charlie-wernham-reveals/|title=Hollyoaks spoilers: Holly will be torn between Robbie and Jason, Charlie Wernham reveals|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=10 December 2015}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Hollyoaks}} {{Hollyoaks characters|past}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Roscoe, Robbie}} [[Category:Hollyoaks characters]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 2013]] [[Category:Fictional mechanics]] [[Category:Fictional twins]] [[Category:Fictional bartenders]] [[Category:Fictional blackmailers]] [[Category:Fictional bullies]]

kept on his chin]] [[Satyajit Ray]] ({{Audio|SatyajitRay2.ogg|listen}}; 2 May 1921 – 23 April 1992) was an Indian filmmaker who worked prominently in [[Cinema of West Bengal|Bengali cinema]] and who has often been regarded as one of the great directors of [[world cinema]].{{cite web |title=Sight and Sound Poll 1992: Critics |publisher=[[California Institute of Technology]] |url=http://alumnus.caltech.edu/~ejohnson/sight/1992_1.html |accessdate=3 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150618053015/http://alumnus.caltech.edu/~ejohnson/sight/1992_1.html |archivedate=18 June 2015 |df= }} * {{cite web |title=A Slanted Canon |author=Kevin Lee |publisher=Asian American Film Commentary |date=5 September 2002 |url=http://www.asianamericanfilm.com/archives/000026.html |accessdate=3 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/684ysTg3l?url=http://www.asianamericanfilm.com/archives/000026.html |archivedate=31 May 2012 |df=dmy-all }} * {{cite web |title=Greatest Film Directors and Their Best Films |publisher=[[Filmsite.org]] |url=http://www.filmsite.org/directors5.html |accessdate=3 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150419012235/http://www.filmsite.org/directors5.html |archivedate=19 April 2015 |df= }} * {{cite web |title=The Greatest Directors Ever by ''Total Film'' Magazine |publisher=[[Filmsite.org]] |url=http://www.filmsite.org/greatdirectors-totalfilm2.html |accessdate=3 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140426215114/http://www.filmsite.org/greatdirectors-totalfilm2.html |archivedate=26 April 2014 |df= }} Ray was born in [[Calcutta]] (now Kolkata) to a [[Bengali people|Bengali]] family and started his career as a [[Visualizer (advertising)|junior visualiser]].{{sfn|Robinson|1989|pp=56–58}} His meeting with French film director [[Jean Renoir]], who had come to Calcutta in 1949 to shoot his film ''[[The River (1951 film)|The River]]'' (1951), and his 1950 visit to London, where he saw [[Vittorio De Sica]]'s ''Ladri di biciclette'' (''[[Bicycle Thieves]]'') (1948), inspired Ray to become a film-maker.{{sfn|Robinson|1989|pp=42–44}}{{sfn|Robinson|1989|p=48}} Ray made his directorial debut in 1955 with ''[[Pather Panchali]]'' and directed 36 films, comprising 29 feature films, five documentaries, and two short films. Although Ray's work generally received critical acclaim,{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2002/may/02/artsfeatures1|author=Malcolm, Derek|authorlink=Derek Malcolm|publisher=[[Guardian.co.uk]]|title=The universe in his backyard|location=London|date=2 May 2002|accessdate=3 February 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150115230831/http://www.theguardian.com/culture/2002/may/02/artsfeatures1|archivedate=15 January 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://satyajitray.ucsc.edu/articles/anartweddedtotruth|author=Swagrow, Michael|authorlink=Michael Sragow|publisher=''[[The Atlantic]]''|title=An art wedded to truth|date=28 September 1994|accessdate=3 February 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150531150336/http://satyajitray.ucsc.edu/articles/anartweddedtotruth|archivedate=31 May 2015}} his film ''Pather Panchali'' and ''[[Ashani Sanket]]'' (1973) were criticised for "exporting poverty" and "distorting India's image abroad".{{sfn|Ganguly|2010|pp=6–7}} His ''[[The Apu Trilogy|Apu Trilogy]]'' (1955–1959) appeared in ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''{{`s}} [[Time's All-Time 100 Movies|All-Time 100 Movies]] in 2005.{{cite journal|url=http://entertainment.time.com/2005/02/12/all-time-100-movies/slide/the-apu-trilogy-1955-1956-1959/|title=Time 100: The Apu Trilogy|publisher=''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''|author=Schickel, Richard|authorlink=Richard Schickel|date=12 February 2005|accessdate=3 February 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020152934/http://entertainment.time.com/2005/02/12/all-time-100-movies/slide/the-apu-trilogy-1955-1956-1959/|archivedate=20 October 2013|df=dmy-all}} Aside from directing, Ray composed music and wrote screenplays for films, both his own and those by other directors.{{sfn|Robinson|1989|pp=352–364}} Often credited as a fiction writer, illustrator, and calligrapher; Ray authored several short stories and novels in [[Bengali language|Bengali]], most of which were aimed at children and adolescents.{{cite web|url=http://www.satyajitray.org/booksandvideo/books_by_ray.htm|title=Books written by Satyajit Ray|publisher=satyajitray.org|accessdate=4 February 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130330095223/http://www.satyajitray.org/booksandvideo/books_by_ray.htm|archivedate=30 March 2013|df=dmy-all}}{{sfn|Robinson|1989|pp=296–305}} Some of his short stories have been adapted into films by other directors, including his only son, [[Sandip Ray]]. [[File:The last Jew in Vinnitsa, 1941.jpg|thumb|''The last Jew in Vinnitsa'']]'''''The last Jew in Vinnitsa''''' is a photograph taken during [[the Holocaust in Ukraine]] showing a Jewish man near the town of Vinnitsa ([[Vinnytsia]]) about to be shot dead by a member of ''[[Einsatzgruppen|Einsatzgruppe D]]'', a mobile [[death squad]] of the Nazi [[Schutzstaffel|SS]]. The victim is kneeling beside a mass grave already containing many bodies; behind a crowd of SS and [[Reich Labour Service]] men watch.<ref name="pa5355"/>
==History== The photograph dates from some time between mid-1941, when [[Operation Barbarossa#Ukraine and Moldavia|the Germans occupied]] the [[Vinnytsia Oblast|oblast (region) of Vinnytsia]], and 1943.<ref name="pa5355">{{cite web|url=https://collections.ushmm.org/search/catalog/pa5355|title=Photograph Number 64407: German soldiers of the Waffen-SS and the Reich Labor Service look on as a member of an Einsatzgruppe prepares to shoot a Ukrainian Jew kneeling on the edge of a mass grave filled with corpses.|work=Collections Search|publisher=[[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]]|accessdate=4 April 2018}}</ref> During this period there were numerous massacres of Jews in the oblast,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yadvashem.org/yv/en/about/institute/killing_sites_catalog_details_full.asp?region=Vinnitsa|title=Vinnitsa|work=Online Guide of Murder Sites of Jews in the Former USSR|publisher=[[Yad Vashem]]|accessdate=4 April 2018}}</ref> including in the town itself on 16 and 22 September 1941 and April 1942, after which those spared were sent to labour camps and the [[Yerusalimka]] quarter largely razed.<ref name="pa5355"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yadvashem.org/untoldstories/database/index.asp?cid=686 |title=Vinnitsa, Vinnitsa County, Vinnitsa District, Ukraine |work=The Untold Stories |publisher=Yad Vashem |accessdate=4 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://www.rtrfoundation.org/webart/UK-arch-d2.pdf |format=PDF |title=The Holocaust in Vinnitsa Oblast |last=Vinokurova |first=Faina A. |date=2002 |work=Jewish Roots in Ukraine and Moldova |publisher=Routes to Roots Foundation |pages=332–335 |accessdate=4 April 2018}}</ref>
The photograph was circulated in 1961 by [[United Press]] (UP) during the [[trial of Adolf Eichmann]].<ref name="bulmash">{{cite web|url=http://digital.kenyon.edu/bulmash/1085/|title=2012.1.397 : "The Last Jew in Vinnitsa"|year=2016|work=Bulmash Family Holocaust Collection|publisher=[[Kenyon College]]|accessdate=4 April 2018}}</ref> UP had received it from Al Moss (b.1910) a Polish Jew who acquired it in May 1945 shortly after he was liberated from [[Allach (concentration camp)|Allach concentration camp]] by the [[American 3rd Army]].<ref name="bulmash"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://collections.ushmm.org/search/catalog/vha3081|title=USC Shoah Foundation Institute testimony of Al Moss|publisher=[[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]]|accessdate=4 April 2018}}</ref> Moss, living in Chicago in 1961, wanted people "to know what went on in Eichmann's time".<ref name="bulmash"/> The UP copy was published over a full page of ''[[The Forward]]''.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ouzan|first1=Francoise S.|last2=Mikhman|first2=Dan|title=De la mémoire de la Shoah dans le monde juif|year=2008|publisher=CNRS éditions|language=French|isbn=9782271067630|page=306|chapter=La mémoire de la Shoah dans le vécu des Juifs aux Etats-Unis jusqu'au procès Eichmann}}</ref>
Some later sources say that the original physical image was in an ''Einsatzgruppe'' member's photograph album,<ref name="bulmash"/> or removed from the pocket of a dead soldier;<ref name="Knopp2014"/> and that written on its reverse side was "Last Jew in Vinnitsa",<ref name="bulmash"/><ref name="Patterson2016"/> now sometimes used as the image's name.<ref name="bulmash"/><ref name="Patterson2016"/><ref name="Knopp2014"/><ref name="Sanneh2015"/>
==Significance== The photograph has become iconic. Some features are unusual among well-known Holocaust pictures: it was taken during the Holocaust rather than after its end, and presumably by someone complicit in the killing; it depicts ''Einsatzgruppen'' rather than [[Nazi concentration camps|concentration]] or [[extermination camp]]s; the focus is on a solitary victim rather than a multitude.<ref name="Patterson2016"/><ref name="gee2017"/><ref name="Rakitova2016"/><ref name="Staines2010"/><ref name="Wollaston2010"/><ref name="SollbergerBöning2016">{{cite book |last=Boehlke |first=Erik |editor-last1=Sollberger|editor-first1=Daniel |editor-last2=Böning|editor-first2=Jobst |editor-last3=Boehlke|editor-first3=Erik |editor-first4=Gerhard |editor-last4=Schindler |title=Das Geheimnis: Psychologische, psychopathologische und künstlerische Ausdrucksformen im Spektrum zwischen Verheimlichen und Geheimnisvollem |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=WgA-DQAAQBAJ&pg=PA238 |accessdate=5 April 2018 |date=2016-10-10 |publisher=Frank & Timme |language=German |isbn=9783732903016 |pages=238–239 |chapter=Geheime Botschaften in Bildern; 5 Entdeckungen bei genauem Hinsehen }}</ref>
The photograph has been reproduced, with different degrees of [[Cropping (image)|cropping]],<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130316042954/http://www.yivoinstitute.org/digital_exhibitions/index.php?mcid=81&mid=196 |title=Nazis executing a Jew at the edge of a mass grave, Vinnitsa, Ukraine. |archivedate=16 March 2013 |url=http://www.yivoinstitute.org/digital_exhibitions/index.php?mcid=81&mid=196 |work=Images of the Holocaust: Photos from the YIVO Archives|publisher=YIVO Institute for Jewish Research|accessdate=5 April 2018}}</ref> in many books and museum exhibits about the Holocaust.<ref name="Rakitova2016">{{cite book|last=Rakitova|first=Maya|title=Behind the Red Curtain|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oeGiDQAAQBAJ&pg=PT11|accessdate=5 April 2018|date=2016-11-01|publisher=Azrieli Foundation|isbn=9781988065229|pages=11–12}}</ref><ref name="Staines2010">{{cite journal|last=Staines|first=Deborah R.|year=2010|title=Auschwitz and the camera|journal=Mortality|volume=7|issue=1|pages=13–32|issn=1357-6275|doi=10.1080/13576270120102544}}</ref><ref name="Wollaston2010">{{cite journal|last=Wollaston|first=Isabel|year=2010|title=The absent, the partial and the iconic in archival photographs of the Holocaust|journal=Jewish Culture and History|volume=12|issue=3|pages=439–462|issn=1462-169X|doi=10.1080/1462169X.2012.721494}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/photo/2011/10/world-war-ii-the-holocaust/100170/#img02 |title=World War II Part 18: The Holocaust |last=Taylor|first=Alan|date=16 October 2011|journal=[[The Atlantic]]|accessdate=5 April 2018}}</ref> Books include ones by [[Guido Knopp]]<ref name="Knopp2014">{{cite book|last=Knopp|first=Guido|title=Der zweite Weltkrieg: Bilder, die wir nie vergessen|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=xUmOBAAAQBAJ&pg=PT172|accessdate=5 April 2018|date=2014-09-10|publisher=Edel|language=German|isbn=9783841903358|pages=146–151|chapter=»Der letzte Jude von Winniza«}}</ref> and [[Michael Berenbaum]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Berenbaum|first=Michael|title=The World Must Know: The History of the Holocaust as Told in the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum|year=1993|publisher=Little, Brown|isbn=9780316091343}}</ref> Exhibits include in Berlin at "Questions on German History" in the [[Reichstag building]] from 1971 to 1994,<ref name="Patterson2016">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/oct/25/tread-warily-when-you-try-to-enlist-the-past|title=A photograph seen once, long ago, haunted me – and taught me to distrust memory|last=Patterson|first=Glenn|date=25 October 2014|work=[[TheGuardian.com]]|accessdate=5 April 2018}}</ref> and then at [[Topography of Terror]]<ref name="gee2017">{{cite web|url=http://blog.smu.edu/studentadventures/2017/human-rights-holocaust-germany-2017/looking-for-answers/|title='Photography describes everything and explains nothing'|last=Gee|first=Denise|date=16 March 2017|work=SMU Adventures|publisher=[[Southern Methodist University]]|accessdate=5 April 2018}}</ref> and the [[Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe]];<ref name="memorialmuseums">{{cite web|url=https://www.memorialmuseums.org/denkmaeler/view/305/Memorials-to-the-Murdered-Jews-of-Vinnytsya#|title=Memorials to the Murdered Jews of Vinnytsya|work=Information Portal to European Sites of Remembrance|publisher=Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe|pages=Tab "Victims" |nopp=Y|language=English and German|accessdate=5 April 2018|location=Berlin}}</ref> the [[Institute of National Remembrance]] in Poland;<ref name="memorialmuseums"/> the [[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]];<ref name="pa5355"/> and [[Yad Vashem]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yadvashem.org/holocaust/this-month/july/1941-3.html|title=July 1941, a Member of the Waffen-SS Shoots a Jew at a Mass Grave in Vinnitsa, Ukraine|work=Yad Vashem Photo Archives|publisher=Yad Vashem|pages=2626/4 |nopp=Y|accessdate=5 April 2018}}</ref>
The photograph was used on the cover of [[Agnostic Front]]'s 1984 album ''[[Victim in Pain]]'', in an ambiguous reference to the [[Nazi chic]] then part of the [[New York hardcore]] scene.<ref name="Sanneh2015">{{cite journal|last=Sanneh|first=Kalefa|date=9 March 2015|title=United Blood: How hardcore conquered New York.|journal=[[The New Yorker]]|pages=82–89: 86|url=https://archive.org/stream/The_New_Yorker_March_9_2015_USA#page/n87}}</ref>
